Bush not only let Noriega and the others go unpunished, he opted to continue paying Noriega $110,000 annually ``for his CIA liaison,'' wrote Kempe, who works for The Wall Street Journal. ``Even back in 1976, Bush realized that paying Noriega didn't mean buying him,'' he wrote. ``New intelligence in the fall linked Noriega to a chain of three bombings aimed at American property and civilians.'' The White House did not immediately return telephone calls for reaction Sunday night. The book is to be published in March by G.P. Putnam's Sons.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Lawyers Say They Won't Plea Bargain
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega are rejecting the idea of a plea bargain, saying they will go to trial if they fail to have all drug charges dismissed. ``The government chose to bring General Noriega to trial and they shall have their trial,'' Frank Rubino, one of several lawyers defending the former Panamanian ruler against U.S. indictments, said Sunday on ABC's ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' Another lawyer, Steve Kollin, told CBS' ``Face the Nation'' that prosecutors had not offered a plea bargain, nor had he sought one. ``General Noriega is innocent of these charges,'' Kollin said. ``Plea bargaining takes place when somebody is guilty, in my opinion.'' President Bush last week, however, did not rule plea bargaining out as an option. And the Baltimore Sun reported in today's editions that the U.S. government has made an offer to a co-defendant of Noriega as it seeks to bolster its case against the former Panamanian strongman. The U.S. Attorney's office has made a ``very preliminary'' offer to Lt. Col. Luis del Cid, a former key Panamanian Defense Forces official who surrendered to U.S. authorities before Noriega sought sanctuary in the Vatican Nuncio. Specifics of the offer were not reported. Del Cid is accused of acting as liaison, courier and emissary for Noriega in his transactions with drug dealers. Plea bargains usually result in a guilty plea to lesser charges in exchange for information the government can use in other cases. Such action would prevent a trial and release of documents sensitive to national security or embarrassing to the government that Noriega's lawyers might want for the defense. Noriega's attorneys would not say whether they had specific secret federal documents in mind. ``The defense team here will file motions appropriate to receiving that information, whatever information is necessary to represent the general properly,'' Kollin said. Rubino said the defense had been concentrating on getting the case dismissed and had not begun looking for evidence to clear Noriega in a trial. ``This would all be speculation as to what the government may have,'' Rubino said. ``One thing I have never done in 16 years of practicing law is to guess what may happen.'' Both he and Kollin said pretrial publicity has made it impossible for Noriega to get a fair trial. ``Pretrial publicity is amazing in the amount,'' Rubino said. ``Not only the amount but the type of publicity. ``The president of the United States said (Noriega) was a thug and purveyor of drugs to children. Obviously, how can someone strike that from their mind and give this man a fair trial?'' Rubino said he would argue that the case should be dismissed because Noriega was ``maximum leader'' of Panama when he was seized and therefore immune from U.S. prosecution as head of state in a foreign country. ``The intention of this administration is to make sure that Mr. Noriega gets a fair trial,'' John Sununu, Bush's chief of staff, said on CBS. ``We ought not to do anything that creates a different category for the defendant once he enters the judicial system,'' Sununu said in response to a question about plea bargaining. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft, who appeared on ABC, said the administration was not worried about documents that could embarrass the White House and wouldn't try to block them. He said, however, he didn't know if any documents existed relevant to the case that might harm national security. ``As far as I know there aren't any,'' Scowcroft said. ``You had the attorney general saying he didn't anticipate any problems of that character. I don't know whether the files have been searched to the ultimate.'' He emphasized that the case against Noriega was based on drug trafficking. ``That's a fairly narrow part of his whole relationship with the United States,'' Scowcroft said. Noriega began providing intelligence information about Latin America to the U.S. government in the 1950s, while a student at the military academy in Peru. Questions about his drug dealing began while Richard Nixon was president and have arisen repeatedly through both Republican and Democratic administrations. However, Noriega's usefulness as an intelligence source always appeared to overshadow the suspected drug dealing and no action was taken until the recent indictments.

DOC.HEAD: Some Episcopal Bishops Hope to Rebuke Colleague Who Ordained Gay Priest
DOC.TEXT: A group of Episcopal bishops are seeking penalties against a colleague for ordaining an avowed homosexual as a priest. Bishop William Wantland of Eau Claire, Wis., said he and other bishops plan to formally charge Newark Bishop John S. Spong with violating the church's doctrinal teachings. A minimum of 10 bishops is needed to support a formal charge against a bishop. Wantland said he has ``far more'' than 10. Last month, Spong ordained gay Deacon J. Robert Williams into the priesthood at the All Saints Episcopal Church in Hoboken. Church traditionalists said Spong violated a resolution of the church's General Convention that declares the ordination of a practicing homosexual to be inappropriate. Spong has said he considers the 1979 resolution adopted by the church's governing body as advisory, not church doctrine. He noted that the resolution had been opposed by 20 bishops, including Presiding Bishop Edmond L. Browning. In response to the planned charges, Spong said he welcomed any inquiry into his actions.

DOC.HEAD: Key Index Rises, Dollar Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with closing Nikkei, dollar. Pickup 8th graf ``The U.S....'
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange rose back after an early setback Monday, while the U.S. dollar edged up against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 144.52 yen, up 0.37 yen from Friday's close of 144.15 yen. It started trading at 144.55 yen and ranged between 144.47 and 144.75 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, market's key index, regained 20.20 points for the day, or 0.05 percent, ending at 38,294.96. The index, a 438.12-point loser on Friday, lost 145.13 more points during morning trading as a decline in bond prices discouraged market players, but it rose back in the afternoon as investment trust companies conducted index-related buyings, dealers said. The Nikkei's plunge Friday, the largest single-day loss since a 647-point drop posted Oct. 16, followed news reports that Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev had canceled all foreign appointments. But Radio Moscow Saturday denied the reports, and former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe announced the same day that he had received a formal invitation to meet with Gorbachev in Moscow Jan. 15. Instability in the foreign exchange market was also responsible for sending the index lower, said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. ``The U.S. Federal Reserve's stance _ whether it will move toward easy monetary policy or not _ has not yet been made clear. And this is making the exchange rate move nervously,'' he added. In currency dealings, the market sentiment for the dollar remained strong since the dollar rose last Friday following the Gorbachev rumor, but participants were reluctant to push the currency higher as they were afraid of additional intervention by the Bank of Japan, traders said. The central bank was seen selling some $100 million around 144.60 yen shortly after the Tokyo market opened Monday. Traders said dollar buying by institutional investors and export firms for dollar-based account settlements kept the dollar strong.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank and IMF Guide Shift from Communist Economies
DOC.TEXT: Eastern European governments trying to move from communist economies are turning for guidance to a pair of worldwide bodies based in Washington. They are the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, both owned by 152 countries that have many different mixes of public and private ownership. The United States takes a leading role in both organizations. A senior IMF official said last week that the fund is in contact with all the major Eastern European countries. The Soviet Union has said it wants to join, but the United States has opposed that, saying the country is far from a market economy. Poland and Hungary are already members. The new Czechoslovak government says it would like to be. Managing Director Michel Camdessus of France put the final touches to an accord with Poland that has brought decontrol of prices, a convertible currency and other measures the fund traditionally advises. The fund and bank influence governments mostly through loans and the conditions attached to them. They promote conservative policies: sale of state-owned industry, reduced government deficits, abolition of price controls, holddowns of wages, promotion of exports and cuts in subsidies.
DOC.HEAD: Market Weak on East European Debt
DOC.TEXT: Eastern European governments have fallen in love with free markets, but at least one free market doesn't love them. The more democratic governments that have taken over from the hard-line communists in Eastern Europe are still liable for the debts incurred primarily during the 1970s when Western bankers thought the Soviet bloc was a good credit risk. But there is waning hope among Western financial dealers that the loans will ever be paid in full, even as Western governments are seeking ways to support the democracy movement so that Western bankers and businesses will invest in Eastern Europe. Western bankers fear the new Eastern European governments will set their sights more on internal development programs and less on paying off old debts. The old debts of Poland and some other Eastern European countries are bought on the so-called secondary market by speculators who want to collect the interest still paid on them by the borrowers. Speculators also hope that they can sell the debt at a higher price or that some day the debtor government will pay in full. Polish debt was selling in July for as much as 41 cents on the dollar of the debt's original value. But Friday, Polish debt was selling at just 17.5 cents on the dollar, and the debts of Hungary and Bulgaria have started to show signs of weakness.

DOC.HEAD: Woman, Six Children, Killed in Foster Home Fire
LaserPhoto MY1
DOC.TEXT: A family ``just trying to help people'' began regrouping today from a fire that raced through their eight-bedroom house, killing six foster children and an elderly houseguest who had been homeless. The owners of the house, Robert and Lois Mitchell, escaped unhurt from early Sunday's fire, said Barbour County Coroner David Childs. The Mitchells were able to escape with their three children and two other foster children. The Mitchells' daughter, Michelle, who helped her brothers rescue the two children but failed to reach the others, said her mother was extremely upset. ``All she can say is, `My babies are gone,''' the daughter said. The fire destroyed their large one-story house in rural east Alabama The cause of the fire was under investigation, said state Fire Marshal John Robison. Two girls and four boys were among the victims. Childs identified them as Kimberly Gilbert, 8; her 10-year-old brother, Jessie; Kimberly Walker, 5; and her brothers Larry, 10, Jessie, 7, and Marketta, 4. Also killed was Florene Burgess, 66. The Mitchells had taken the homeless woman in ``out of the goodness of their hearts'' at the request of a judge, Childs said. ``This is a case of folks who were just trying to help people,'' Childs said. ``There is no indication of foul play. She took all the children to church on Sunday and kept them in good shape and all.'' The children who died had been assigned there by the state Department of Human Resources, Childs said. ``This is the worst tragedy I've ever seen,'' said Childs, who has been coroner for three years. ``This is the most (deaths) we have ever had in a house fire in Barbour County.'' The coroner said Mrs. Mitchell told him she thought the fire started near the hot water heater, adding that the home itself was not being heated. Michelle Mitchell, 23, said she was able to wake her brothers, Eric, 23, and Michael, 21. The three rescued Kevin Boyer, 2, and Brenda Gilbert, 12 but couldn't get to the others. ``These children will always be in our memories. We loved them like our own flesh and blood. We will miss them dearly,'' Miss Mitchell said in tears. Mike Gibson, a spokesman for the state Department of Human Resources, said he understood the house had smoke detectors. All private foster homes in the state are inspected before they are certified, he said. The Mitchells were licensed to care for the large number of children at their home, one of 4,000 license private foster homes in Alabama, said county District Attorney Sam LeMaistre Jr. ``I think the fact that you see so many children in homes is an indication that we've got a shortage of foster homes not only in Barbour County but in the state and across the nation,'' LeMaistre said. ``Funds are limited for foster care.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins For Computer Student Accused Creating `Worm'
DOC.TEXT: The trial of an Ivy League student accused of crippling thousands of computer systems nationwide is viewed by computer security experts as a chance to garner support for tougher anti-hacker laws. ``It's a no-lose situation because the trial will showcase the weaknesses of computer security and current computer security law,'' said Harold Highland, professor emeritus of computer science for the State University of New York and editor of ``Computers & Security,'' a trade journal. Jury selection was to begin today in the first criminal trial under the 1986 federal Computer Fraud and Abuse Act. Robert T. Morris Jr., a 24-year-old suspended Cornell University graduate student, is accused of designing and setting loose a computer ``worm'' that reproduced wildly in November 1988. The worm immobilized an estimated 6,000 computers linked to a research network, including computers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration facility at Moffet Field, Calif., and the Air Force Logistics Command at Wright Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio. It was at Cornell that authorities said Morris gained access to the Department of Defense network that connects thousands of computers at military facilities, corporate research centers and universities. A Cornell commission concluded that Morris was guilty of ``reckless disregard'' for creating the program. Although the university commission found him responsible, Morris has never admitted creating the program or introducing it into the system. Morris, of Arnold, Md., faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine if convicted. With arguments expected to begin later this week in U.S. District Court, computer security experts say the trial will focus attention on the need for more stringent computer tampering legislation. ``If the government loses, (computer security advocates) will say there is a need for stronger laws. If the government wins, they'll say he did it because the system is weak and we need to tighten up the system,'' Highland said. ``Either way it goes, the pure attention is going to fuel the cry for tougher laws and better security,'' said Christopher A. Breceda, a top officer with American Computer Security Industries Inc., a Nashville, Tenn.-based maker of security systems with worldwide sales. Eugene Spafford, an associate professor of computer science at Purdue University who has written about the case and is expected to be a government witness, said losses from computer crimes in the United States total about $7 billion annually. ``Ten years ago, these kinds of things didn't hurt anybody, but you have to realize now all the places where computers are used and the dangers involved in shutting down a system or damaging data,'' he said. The worm allegedly created by Morris did not destroy any data and prosecutors have not estimated the monetary damage from the worm. But Spafford estimated the one-day paralysis cost between $5 million and $15 million in lost time and in later protective work.

DOC.HEAD: Texans Brace for Two-Party Shootout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, ``The decade ...'' to CORRECT to Meyer sted Meier
DOC.TEXT: Texans won't elect a new governor until November. But they're already being treated to a two-party shootout in the primary contests. State GOP leaders boast they will put the 20th century's second Republican in the Governor's Mansion. Democrats say Republican Gov. Bill Clements' lease on the residence is a temporary one for the party. The 72-year-old Clements' decision not to seek re-election cleared the way for well-funded, wide-open races in both parties. Pundits predict the election could cost $50 million. The candidates in the March 13 primaries include a millionaire cowboy nicknamed ``Claytie''; the 1988 Democratic National Convention keynote speaker; the man who helped organize a rescue raid into Iran; and a former governor hoping for a comeback. ``The decade of the 1980s was characterized by some as the decade of the emergence of the Republican Party in Texas,'' said GOP Chairman Fred Meyer. ``We're looking forward to the decade of the '90s being the emergence of the Republican Party as the majority party of Texas.'' Democratic chief Bob Slagle said that won't happen, not even if popular U.S. Sen. Phil Gramm tops the GOP ticket. ``I think we're going to beat the daylights out of them, to put it politely,'' he said. The Democratic field is headed by a well-known trio: _ Former Gov. Mark White, 49, a Houston lawyer, who was ousted in a 1986 grudge match by Clements, the man White had beaten in 1982. _ State Treasurer Ann Richards, 56, who denounced then-presidential candidate George Bush at the Democratic National Convention for being ``born with a silver foot in his mouth'' and is author of an autobiography that took her on a national talk show tour last fall. _ Two-term Attorney General and former Congressman Jim Mattox, 46, who kicked off his campaign by calling for creation of a state lottery. Leading Republicans are: _ Midland rancher and oilman Clayton ``Claytie'' Williams, 58, who said he's willing to spend $3 million of his own money. _ Dallas lawyer Tom Luce, 49, an associate of billionaire H. Ross Perot who organized a mission into Iran that rescued Perot employees and was recounted in the book ``On Wings of Eagles.'' _ Kent Hance, 47, chairman of the oil-regulating state Railroad Commission, who won headlines worldwide by attending meetings of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. _ Jack Rains, 52, a Houston lawyer and businessman, former secretary of state and campaign strategist for Clements in 1986. Former San Antonio Mayor Henry Cisneros and state Agriculture Commissioner Jim Hightower were once considered likely candidates, but Hightower is seeking re-election and Cisneros is out of politics after questions were raised about his private life. As governor, White pushed through sweeping school reforms that included a rule in which students with failing grades were banned from extracurricular activities such as sports. He also signed a $4.8 billion tax increase and raised more than $1 billion in temporary sales taxes. Hance was one of the leaders of a conservative Democratic coalition known as the ``Boll Weevils'' from 1978 to 1984. He quit Congress to seek the Democratic U.S. Senate nomination and after failing, switched parties in 1985. Ms. Richards, who has had celebrities such as Lily Tomlin and Phyllis George helping her at fund-raisers, said her financial skills are needed in a state severely battered by depressed real estate and oil industries. ``You know, Sam Rayburn used to say that any jackass can kick down a barn, but it takes a carpenter to build one,'' she said of the longtime U.S. House speaker from Texas. The Democrats have signed a good-behavior pledge, while the Republican candidates are bickering like Democrats of old. Hance said Williams, founder of the Claydesta long distance phone company and other enterprises, isn't qualified. Williams is ``a good fellow to go fishing with, but he'd be a disaster'' as governor, Hance said. Williams said Hance is worried about recent polls showing Williams as the front-runner in a campaign where he has pledged a ``real war on drugs'' that includes a plan to send first-time offenders to a military-style ``boot camp.'' Democrats haven't stayed completely above the fray. Mattox, who said a lottery is the answer to the state's budget problems, released a poll showing him leading White and Ms. Richards. In response, Ms. Richards' staff distributed copies of a phone-in survey in which 56 percent of respondents said they believed Elvis Presley is still alive.

DOC.HEAD: Academics Battle to Keep Their Classes Abreast of East European Reform
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Revolutionary changes sweeping Eastern Europe have professors and textbook publishers scratching their heads about keeping up with history in the making. It's a mind-boggling world for Soviet bloc specialists, said Sovietologist Ben Eklof of Indiana University. ``And it's very stressful,'' he said. ``I've begun to wish everyone over there would play baseball for a month or so and give me some time to rethink things.'' The campus confusion started as Soviet bloc governments began toppling in last fall. College syllabuses had to be tossed out and curricula overhauled. ``Some of my colleagues are waiting for things to settle down, but they might as well give up waiting because I don't think that will happen for another generation,'' said Adam Ulam, who directs Harvard University's Russian Research Center. ``It's exciting and tiring at the same time,'' said Henry Krisch, an author and professor at the University of Connecticut. ``It's as though someone in history has hit fast forward and processes that normally take a long time are seen in a short period.'' Independent political journals and newspapers have blossomed in Eastern Europe. Artists and theorists are speaking out. Scholarly exchange and travel opportunities are opening. In many cases, U.S. professors have opted to use newspapers and free-form classroom debate on current events instead of the standard and now outdated texts. ``Right now I'm in a quandary as to whether to offer my course again next fall because I'm not sure if anything of a permanent, published nature will be available,'' said Edwin Gere, a professor at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Publishers have similar problems. The books from which generations of high school and college students learned about the Soviet bloc suddenly need daily revision. ``The academic headaches are reflected in the publisher's office,'' said Frederick Praeger, editorial director at Westview Press Inc. ``You cannot publish books that deal with the current situation in the Soviet Union or Eastern Europe because it changes just about every day,'' Praeger said from his Boulder, Colo., office. ``On the day you publish, the book is out of date.'' Sam Gesumaria, a vice president at Macmillan-McGraw-Hill's school division, said editors in his New York office had updated various social studies texts repeatedly since November. ``All textbook publishers are faced with the same problem right now,'' he said. ``The best we can do is give some sort of information about these changes, but we have to stop short of being conclusive because these events aren't done yet. And we have a long way to go yet, I suspect.'' The Warsaw Pact's transformation may continue for years, but textbook publishers need to deal with an immediate bottom line. They've got to find a way to keep up with the change if they want to keep selling books. Eileen Peters, vice president of Scott Foreman and Co.'s international division, said several publishing houses were considering supplements for college survey texts. ``Professors can change their reading lists from semester to semester,'' she said from her office in Chicago. ``It's critical to have the books up to date, because professors are going to go with the book that has these changes in it.'' Robert V. Daniels, an author and retired University of Vermont professor, said some of the scholars working on specialized texts have been tempted to sit back and wait for the events to unfold. But he rejected the practice. ``That's ivory tower thinking!'' the author of ``Is Russia Reformable?'' said. ``We can't be concerned that current events will spoil our neat conclusions. More than ever we need analyses of where we are.''

DOC.HEAD: Eritrean Insurgents Claim Attack On Two Polish Ships In Red Sea
DOC.TEXT: A spokesman for the Eritrean rebels has claimed responsibility for attacks on two Polish ships in the Red Sea and says any ship carrying weapons to Ethiopia through the sea will be subject to Eritrean fire. ``We were sure that one of the two Polish ships was carrying arms to Ethiopia,'' the Eritrean Liberation Front spokesman, reached by telephone in another Persian Gulf state, said Sunday. He said the Eritrean forces, who have been waging a three-decade war for their region's independence from Ethiopia, fully back freedom of navigation in the Red Sea. But this does not mean that ships carrying arms to Ethiopia will be allowed to use the waterway ``especially those coming from Israel,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition his name not be used. Forces hostile to Ethiopia, including the Sudanese government, have charged that Israel is bolstering Ethiopia militarily with the aim of undermining the regional Arab nations. Shipping sources, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Polish motor vessel Adam Asnyk came under fire from Red Sea shores on Thursday. It had come upon another Polish ship _ Boleslaw Krzywousty _ stranded and ablaze 50 miles from Massawa on the Eritrean coast. ``The Israeli presence in Ethiopia is a source of grave danger to the Eritrean revolution and so we will not hesitate to attack any Israeli ship carrying weapons to Addis Ababa government,'' said the source. He said that with the Soviet-Ethiopian friendship treaty expiring this year, Israel will become the main supplier of weapons, ammunition and military advisers to Ethiopia. The Israelis have replaced the Soviet and Cuban military advisers and experts, he added. The source also threatened the international companies who signed a $70 million contract with Ethiopia to expand the port of Assab, saying their interests would be endangered. He did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Tower of Pisa Closes; Repairs Could Take Years
DOC.TEXT: The Leaning Tower, whose tilt draws hundreds of thousands of tourists a year but could also spell its downfall, has shut its doors for repairs that officials say could take years. Thousands of sightseers climbed the stairs of the 800-year-old tower Sunday before Mayor Giacomino Granchi locked the doors and expressed hope the marble wonder can be reopened soon. He reluctantly signed an order in December authorizing the closure for three months. But Public Works Minister Giovanni Prandini, who led the drive to close the tower, told a nationwide television audience he expected the tower needed to be closed for several years. ``It needs an urgent intervention,'' Prandini said, but conceded there is no agreement yet on the best project to stabilize the tower, which is a national symbol. The 180-foot tower, begun by Bonnano Pisano in 1173, started to tilt almost immediately because the ground shifted underneath. The tower now leans about 13 feet off the perpendicular. Technicians have said the tower shifted less last year than its average annual tilt of the last three decades _ 0.03 inches compared to an average 0.045 inches. Some experts say the tower should stand at least a hundred more years. The tower is an important source of income for Pisa, attracting about 800,000 tourists a year paying $2.80 apiece to climb the spiral staircase. Several thousand tourists turned out Sunday, with an Italian soldier the last to go up the 293 steps before the closing, broadcast by government-run RAI-TV. ``The tower is an important asset which belongs to everybody, including the international community. We must keep this in mind,'' said the mayor. ``We have decided to close the tower for three months to do what has to be done. I don't think it will topple soon and should never close. I ask the minister to take his responsibility.'' Prandini, interviewed in the RAI studios, pledged that a project will be selected by the end of this year but when asked when the tower would reopen replied ``We are talking about a few years.'' ``I can promise that I will do all I can to hasten the re-opening.'' One plan which has been well-received by government experts calls for a wheel-shaped support to be planted around the base of the tower. The support would be connected by concrete spokes to the marble foundation. The Public Works Ministry is awaiting a report on soil conditions to decide whether the plan is feasible. Experts agree the tower must retain its famed lean and not be straightened.

DOC.HEAD: Army Arrests Over 100 Suspects, Six Houses Demolished or Sealed
DOC.TEXT: The army today rounded up more than 100 Palestinians suspected of belonging to PLO-led ``strike forces'' and demolished or sealed six homes during the night, officials said. The arrests were made in sweeps of Arab villages near Ramallah in the occupied West Bank, and the military said the detainees belonged to a terrorist organization recently uncovered in the area. Some of the suspects belonged to strike forces organized by Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization, an army official said. The strike forces are underground groups that enforce orders of the PLO-linked underground leadership of the Palestinian uprising. Military officials said the group was responsible for the Oct. 7 killing of a Palestinian in the West Bank village of Deir Al-Sudan who allegedly assisted Israeli authorities. They were also suspected of stabbing and wounding two other alleged collaborators and of torching and firebombing Arab-owned cars as punishment for helping Israel, said the officials who are not identified in accordance with army regulations. Four houses of alleged strike force members in the Ramallah area were sealed during the night, the officials said. The army defends its policy of house demolitions and sealings by saying it serves as a strong deterrent against future unrest, but it has been criticized by the U.S. government and human rights groups in Israel and abroad as collective punishment. A study released Dec. 20 by the Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies disupted army claims that house demolitions reduced violence. It found that in many cases such measures inflamed the situation. At least 245 houses have been demolished and 120 sealed since the uprising began 25 months ago, according to army figures. Palestinian activists have killed 166 Palestinians, most for alleged collaboration, during the uprising against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, seized in the 1967 Middle East War. At least 646 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli gunfire in the uprising, and 43 Israelis have been slain.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Character Actor Arthur Kennedy Dead at 75
DOC.TEXT: Actor Arthur Kennedy, who was discovered by Jimmy Cagney and excelled in movies such as ``Peyton Place'' and ``Lawrence of Arabia'' and on Broadway, has died of cancer at age 75. Kennedy died Friday evening at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford, where he was admitted in October, said Allan Nixon, a longtime friend and fellow actor. Kennedy, a five-time Oscar nominee, won a Tony Award for his role as Biff in Arthur Miller's ``Death of a Salesman.'' On stage in the 1940s, Kennedy achieved prominence as a character actor in other Miller plays, appearing in ``The Crucible,'' and ``All My Sons.'' Among his film credits were ``The Glass Menagerie,'' ``Elmer Gantry,'' and ``High Sierra.'' Kennedy also starred several Italian and Spanish films during the 1960s and 1970s. In a memorable role as the crusty American correspondent Jackson Bentley in ``Lawrence of Arabia,'' Bentley delivered an off-the-cuff eulogy for T.E. Lawrence, saying: ``He was a poet, a scholar and a mighty warrior. ... He was also the most shameless exhibitionist since Barnum and Bailey.'' Born Feb. 17, 1914, in Worcester, Mass., John Arthur Kennedy attended the Carnegie Institute of Technology and was brought to the attention of Hollywood producers by Cagney, who had seen him perform on stage in Los Angeles. He made his film debut in 1940 as the prodigy brother for whom Cagney sacrifices all in ``City For Conquest.'' During World War II, Kennedy worked at Warner Bros., appearing with Ronald Reagan and Errol Flynn in ``Desperate Journey,'' a 1942 film about three prisoners of war in Nazi Germany who fight their way to freedom. Kennedy received Academy Award nominations for ``Champion'' (1949), ``Peyton Place'' (1957), ``Some Came Running'' (1959), ``Trial'' (1955) and ``Bright Victory.'' Kennedy lived for many years in Los Angeles, but moved to Savannah, Ga. in 1986. Kennedy once told reporters in Savannah that while he occasionally watched one of his old movies on television, he didn't go out of his way to do so. ``It's more or less out of curiosity to see what I looked like,'' Kennedy said. He also expressed little interest in contemporary films, saying the two ``Godfather'' films were the only admirable efforts that came to mind. Kennedy added that he had no great admiration for the current crop of actors either, although his daughter Laurie works as an actress in New York. ``I think they're accomplishing nothing, playing the same part over and over again, generally speaking. It has nothing to do with acting and it doesn't add up to much. They don't gamble with their careers.'' He was to be buried alongside his late wife of 45 years, Mary, at his farm in Nova Scotia, Nixon said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Soaks Northern California, South
DOC.TEXT: More stormy weather today headed toward the Pacific Northwest, which has been battered by heavy rain and high winds since Saturday. The rain was welcome in Northern California but caused mudslides and power outages and threatened flooding in Oregon and Washington. Rain also continued today in parts of the South and the mid-Atlantic Coast. Rain caused flooding Sunday near Albany, Ga., washing out roads and forcing some evacuations, and along the South Carolina coast, where debris left by Hurricane Hugo blocked drains and culverts. In the Northwest, storms sent trees, branches and power lines whirling and caused at least two deaths in Oregon _ an 11-year-old girl struck by a falling tree and a 23-year-old man killed in a car crash on a rain-slickened road. Flood warnings were in effect today along many Oregon rivers, swollen by the weekend storms. Waves 22 feet were forecast along the Washington coast today. Unseasonably warm temperatures threatened to add melting mountain snow to rivers swollen by rain. In California, 6{ inches of rain fell Sunday in Shelter Cove, while 2{ inches fell in Eureka and Redding. At least 2 inches fell in parts of Oregon and Washington. The storms also brought snow for Sierra Nevada and Cascade ski areas suffering through a disappointing winter. More than 6 inches of snow fell in higher elevations, and the National Weather Service predicted as much as another foot today in the Lake Tahoe area. ``Oh, it's wonderful news,'' said Suellen McGeorge, spokeswoman for Squaw Valley ski resort. ``It's a good, heavy wet storm. ... It's really going to help.'' The weather service posted winter storm warnings for this morning in the western mountains of Wyoming, with the heaviest snowfall expected in the Tetons and higher elevations of Yellowstone National Park. High wind warnings, advisories or watches were in effect along the Pacific coast, parts of Montana and Wyoming, northwest Nevada and the foothills of northest Colorado. Winds Sunday gusted to 68 mph in Cheyenne, Wyo., and to 70 mph in the hilltops near Rollinsville, Colo. Fair weather prevailed in much of the Midwest, northern Plains and Upper Great Lakes, with record high temperatures Sunday in the 40s and 50s throughout Iowa and in parts of Nebraska, South Dakota and Minnesota. Rain fell in North and South Carolina, Tennessee, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi and eastern Arkansas. High temperature for the Lower 48 states Sunday was 85 degrees at Vero Beach, West Palm Beach and North Dade County airport near Miami, all in Florida. DOC.HEAD: Papal Nuncio Says Noriega Threatened Massacre Unless Granted Refuge
With PM-After Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The papal nuncio in Panama said Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega threatened to start a massacre unless granted refuge in the Vatican embassy in that country's capital, an Italian newspaper reported. The envoy, Monsignor Jose Sabastian Laboa, was quoted in Rome's Il Tempo on Sunday as saying he didn't have time to consult the Vatican and made the decision by himself. ``I received two phone calls and he (Noriega) also sent an officer with a message,'' Laboa was quoted as saying. ``He gave me a quarter of an hour to decide: accept him or he would immediately start a guerrilla war in the Chiriqui region. He threatened massacres.'' He said he immediately informed Gen. Marc Cisneros of the U.S. Southern Command: ``He was speechless, for them it was a humiliation.'' In other interviews with Italian reporters, the nuncio said Eliecer Gaitan, Noriega's personal security chief, provided decisive help in persuading Noriega to leave the Vatican embassy and surrender to U.S. troops. Laboa said Gaitan told Noriega he was ready to die with him but by holding out they risked the same fate as Mussolini because U.S. troops wouldn't stop Panamanians, who Gaitan said would one day storm the embassy. Mussolini was shot and killed and then hanged by his feet in a public square. Laboa has insisted that Noriega left the embassy on his own accord on Wednesday and previously denied reports that he gave Noriega an ultimatum to leave the mission 10 days after seeking refuge there. Laboa said there was never any talk of granting concessions and that once it was made clear that Noriega would not be sent to another country it came down to getting him to accept guarantees such as not facing the death penalty in the United States. ``He knows Panamanian prisons while I told him those in America have TV and air conditioning,'' the nuncio was quoted as saying in Turin's La Stampa and other newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Charged With Making False Bomb Threat Against Delta
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who police say admitted guilt has been charged with making a false bomb threat that disrupted travel plans for hundreds of Delta Air Lines passengers last week. Colin Goodwin, 17, of Dunshaughlin in County Meath, was formally charged Sunday in a district court. He was released on $1,400 bail and ordered to surrender his passport pending a further appearance in court Feb. 2. Detective Sgt. Daniel O'Riordan said that when the charge was read over to Goodwin, the teenager replied: ``That's right, I made that call.'' Delta said it intensified security after receiving a threat Thursday against its transatlantic operations, which include flights to and from Germany, Ireland, England and France. Passengers were notified about the threats when they checked in, said Delta spokesman Bill Berry in Atlanta, and several hundred changed flights. ``We had several hundred passengers in this four-day period we were in change their travel plans to another carrier,'' Berry said. He said Delta averages 4,000 transatlantic passengers a day, but even the loss of a few means ``we're really concerned.'' Berry said Goodwin was arrested Sunday morning at his home after he allegedly telephoned his most recent threat to Delta's Dublin office. A terrorist bomb explosion was blamed for the Dec. 21, 1988, crash of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, which killed 270 people. Pan Am was criticized afterward for not warning passengers, although U.S. Embassy staffers in Europe had been warned of threats against the airline. Delta passengers were notified about last week's threat when they checked in, Berry said. A week earlier, Northwest Airlines received a bomb threat against a flight from Paris to Detroit, but nothing happened.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Weaker
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against key currencies in European trading this morning, as dealers focused on prospects for the West German mark. Gold was weaker. Peter Kane, chief corporate dealer at Credit Suisse in London, said the Italy's decision to devalue the lira by 3.01 percent on Friday may reduce pressures on the European Monetary System in the short-term but it ``hasn't changed the overall picture.'' ``We will see a gradual strengthening of the mark once again,'' he predicted. David Clark, deputy forex manager at Commerzbank in London, described the lire devaluation as largely a technical move that certainly ``doesn't spell the end of the mark rally.'' In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.52 yen, up 0.37 yen from Friday's 144.15-yen finish. It opened at 144.55 yen and ranged between 144.47 yen and 144.75 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 144.50 yen. The Bank of Japan sold some $100 million shortly after the Tokyo market opened today, and fear of further central bank intervention discouraged later dollar buying, dealers said. Mitsui Bank trader Yoshitsugu Hanada said the dollar-yen rate moved little because the amounts of dollars and yen held by investors were in good balance after wide swings and adjustments following the New Year holidays. The dollar, which ended 1989 trading at 143.40 yen, opened on Jan. 4 at 145.55 yen and was pushed down to 143.40 yen the next day following central banks' intervention in Europe. ``But the basic sentiment for the dollar was getting stronger, and speculative dealers were inclined to buy the U.S. currency whenever it fell,'' Hanada said. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $403.75 an ounce at midmorning, down from $404.50 bid late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $403.50, down $1.00 from late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong closed at $401.56 per ounce Monday, down $2.10 from Saturday's close. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $5.29 a troy ounce, up from Friday's $5.27.

DOC.HEAD: American Once Held in El Salvador Says She Buried Items in Yard
DOC.TEXT: An American woman who was imprisoned in El Salvador after weapons were found buried in the yard of her San Salvador home says she did bury personal objects outside the house but not arms. After a talk at Riverside Church about her experiences in El Salvador, Jennifer J. Casolo said Sunday she buried ``things that I thought the security forces would be in disapproval of.'' ``I had some project proposals for a medical clinic, a chicken coop, things like that. And I had some musical tapes,'' she said. ``In El Salvador it is very common, from the time I got there, for people to bury things.'' She said she hid the items after a Salvadoran trade union was bombed and the homes and offices of churchworkers were raided. Casolo, 28, of Thomaston Conn., worked in El Salvador for Christian Education Seminars, a Texas-based ecumenical group that arranges tours of the country. Her arrest Nov. 26 by government soldiers came in the midst of a major offensive by leftist rebels involved in a decade-long civil war against the government. The soldiers said weapons they unearthed in Casolo's yard had been hidden there for rebels. But Casolo has denied all knowledge of the weapons, saying they had either been placed there to frame her, or had been buried before she moved into the house. She was freed from jail on Dec. 13 and expelled from El Salvador after a military judge cited a lack of evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Birthday a City Holiday, Presidential Library Nearly Completed
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Former President Richard M. Nixon's 77th birthday Tuesday is a holiday in his hometown, which is proudly planning for this summer's opening of the Nixon presidential library. ``The interest has been fantastic. We call it `The Wonder Years' syndrome,'' Hugh Hewitt, director of the library foundation, said as he gazed over the library, a Spanish-style building described as a ``window'' to Nixon's career. The Nixon Presidential Library and Birthplace, 30 miles southeast of Los Angeles, will be the first of two presidential libraries to open in Southern California. The Ronald Reagan Presidential Library opens next year in Simi Valley, 75 miles away. The 40,000-plus residents of Nixon's hometown celebrate their most famous citizen with a holiday Tuesday for the city's approximately 100 employees. The City Council voted in September to make the day a Yorba Linda holiday, the first such local honor for Nixon. ``Fifteen years have elapsed since President Nixon's resignation and history has shown the importance of his presidency, particularly with respect to his brilliance in foreign policy,'' the holiday resolution said. The $20 million library rises prominently in the hilly community among homes valued to $700,000. Construction workers are toiling furiously to meet the July 19 opening. Unlike other presidential libraries, the 45,000-square-foot Nixon library won't be operated with taxpayer dollars. The former chief executive insisted on it. The Nixon library will hold another first among presidential libraries _ it is to open without presidential papers. The federal government took custody of Nixon's presidential materials _ 44 million pages and 4,000 hours of tape recordings _ when he tried to have some of them destroyed. ``Control over the papers has been in litigation for years. We expect them eventually. What we have are reproductions of the Oval Office papers. We have 8,000 core files,'' Hewitt said. Nixon, who lives in Upper Saddle River, N.J., resigned Aug. 9, 1974, after revelations stemming from a botched burglary at Democratic headquarters at Washington's Watergate building during his 1972 re-election campaign. ``It won't be a museum on Watergate, but we're not going to shy away from it, either. It's part of what interests people about Nixon,'' said Hewitt, noting current world events can be traced in part to Nixon's actions in the late 1960s and early 1970s. The library was originally planned in San Clemente, site of the Western White House during the Nixon presidency, but plans stalled amid controversy over another development tied to the library. Visitors on a self-guided tour will start in the library's 293-seat theater with a 16-minute film on Nixon's life. They will walk through the Alger Hiss Chambers and see the vintage ``Woody'' station wagon used on the campaign trail in 1950. Bronze, life-sized figures of 10 world leaders occupy another large room. Also on display will be Nixon's vice presidential papers and book manuscripts, exhibits on the Vietnam War and prisoners of war, Nixon's diplomacy with the Soviet Union and China and his debate with Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev. There also will be a section on former first lady Pat Nixon and the couple's daughters, Tricia and Julie, as well as a garden blooming with the Patricia Nixon Rose.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I've begun to wish everyone over there would play baseball for a month or so and give me some time to rethink things.'' _ Sovietologist Ben Eklof of Indiana University, on the revolutionary changes in Eastern Europe that has professors and textbook publishers scratching their heads about keeping up with history in the making.

``In every class I ever took, the fact that some 200,000 black men fought (in the Civil War) was never mentioned. You can go as far as saying that if they hadn't fought, the North may not have won. I think it's especially good for black Americans to know this, kids who don't necessarily feel that they're a part of this country.'' _ Actor Denzel Washington, who has a starring role as a black Union soldier in the motion picture ``Glory.''

``It's a grand satire.'' _ Alan Abel, a jokester on a hoax he arranged in which a woman claimed she won a $35 million New York state Lotto jackpot after Donald Trump and Malcolm Forbes told her the lucky numbers in a dream.

DOC.HEAD: First Trials For Captured Security Men; Marchers Demand More Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with military trials of security men beginning, elections not yet postponed, other details. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: The first captured security men loyal to ousted President Nicolae Ceausescu went before military tribunals today, accused of resisting the popular revolt that toppled and executed the despised dictator. The first tribunal opened in the south Transylvanian city of Sibiu, ruled until Dec. 22 by Ceausescu's son Nicu. ``A group of terrorists who fought against the people in the army'' faced the military court, a spokesman for the revolutionary government said. Aurel Dragos Munteanu, the spokesman and director of television, told a news conference he did not know how many security men would face trial. He gave no details of the exact charges in Sibiu or other centers of heavy fighting such as Bucharest and the western city of Timisoara, where the revolution began Dec. 17 when security forces massacred anti-government protesters. Thousands of people were killed in the uprising. The accused have no right of appeal, said Munteanu, but media _ foreign and domestic _ will have access to the tribunals. The National Salvation Front, which has been running the country since Ceausescu was ousted Dec. 22, organized the secret military tribunal that ordered the Christmas Day execution of the president and his wife, Elena. It has since abolished the death sentence, so the captured men of crack security units who battled the army after Ceausescu was ousted face a maximim sentence of life in prison. Munteanu said those still under investigation include Nicu Ceausescu and Gen. Iulian Vlad, the former head of Ceausescu's dreaded Securitate security police, which Romania's new leaders have ordered disbanded. Asked about weekend statements from President Ion Iliescu and Vice President Dumitru Mazilu that free elections promised for April could be postponed, Munteanu said he knew of no such postponement as yet. The half-dozen political parties formed or reborn in the two short weeks since Ceausescu was executed have charged that the National Salvation Front would have an unfair advantage in any early poll because of its control of media and the government. They have urged posponement of the balloting so they have more time to organize campaigns. Some political groups have accused Romanian television of boycotting their gatherings while giving ample coverage to the National Salvation Front. Romanian TV cameras did not follow demonstrations by two parties and students in Bucharest on Sunday. Munteanu countered these complaints by stressing he believed in a free media and noting that representatives of the Peasant Party and Liberal Party appeared on television Sunday night to present their groups' programs. ``My personal standard of freedom of the press is the First Amendment to the United States Constitution,'' he said. ``After these parties had registered, they were given access to television,'' he said. ``Previously, there was no legal framework for that.'' The Peasant Party was a power in Parliament before the Communists abolished it in 1947, and both it and the Christian Democrats have traditionally been anti-Communist. Since their renaissance, the two parties have joined forces in preparation for the promised elections and have warned against a Communist resurgence. They see the National Salvation Front, which includes several former Communists in its leadership, as a de facto front for Communism. On Sunday, about 300 supporters of the two parties led an emotional march through the capital in memory for those who fell in the uprising. As they knelt and prayed in the bitter cold that hovered near zero, the marchers were joined by several thousand other people who paced along the ice-covered sidewalks in a solemn half-mile procession. Less than two miles away, about 2,500 students met for a rally at the Polytechnical Institute to press for university autonomy, more student say in determining the curriculum and a postponement of examinations scheduled for Jan. 25. They also want an end to required political indoctrination courses. Nicolae Costel, a Christian Democratic Party official, said thousands more students had gathered in other cities, including Timisoara. During Ceausescu's 24-year reign, courses that extolled the virtues of ``scientific socialism'' were compulsory for all students. Razvan Rusovici, a 21-year-old aeronautical engineering student, expressed hope for the future: ``We want to be more like our Western brothers and study what we really need and not what some ignorant dictator imagines we need.''

DOC.NOTE: For release at 10:40 a.m. EST _ set by source
DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
Bush Calls for Anti-Pollution Efforts by Farmers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with embargoed remarks, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, saying productive agriculture and a clean environment are compatible, urged America's farmers today to support efforts to reduce contamination of groundwater from pesticides and fertilizers. In an address to the American Farm Bureau convention, Bush also said he will press in the 1990 farm bill for ``market-oriented farm policies that allow producers more flexibility to decide what crops to grow.'' ``At the same time, we've got to maintain a safety net to protect farmers from conditions beyond their control,'' the president said in remarks prepared for delivery at the Orange County Civic Center before touring high-tech agriculture and ocean exhibits at Walt Disney's Epcot Center nearby. Bush also used the speech to push a major objective of his on this year's congressional calendar: passage of a cut in the capital gains tax cut. He said a tax reduction ``would apply to the sale of farmland'' and ``will be one of my top priorities in this legislative year.'' ``With continued economic growth, we can keep rural America going strong,'' he said. Bush said farmers have bounced back from trying times in the 1980s, with help from the 1985 farm legislation that led to lower federal crop subsidies and more land in production. ``Surpluses have declined dramatically, and most of of good land has been brought back into production,'' he said. ``Net farm income reached a record level last year. ... The farm credit situation has greatly improved, bringing more financial stability to rural America.'' But Bush added that market-oriented farm policies ``are only a part of the agricultural picture. We've got to expand markets and enhance productivity. We've got to assure the public that America's food is the safest in the world, and we've got to protect our precious environment.'' ``We must recognize that productive agriculture and a sound environment can be compatible, especially in terms of water quality,'' the president said. The administration has already initiated a five-year effort to protect groundwater from contamination by fertilizers and pesticides running off farms, he said. ``We must keep your good land in business _ without unreasonable burdens _ but we must also keep it good land,'' he said. ``I am counting on your leadership as we work to expand farm productivity while safeguarding the environment.'' Without giving details, Bush said the administration also is drafting legislation ``to protect the food supply without overwhelming the agriculture industry.'' He noted that farmers have a major stake in U.S. efforts to foster free trade, including its recent ``bold proposal in the Uruguay Round'' of international trade talks that would phase out export-subsidies in five years and other trade-distorting practices in 10 years. ``Any agreement we sign will be an agreement that's also good for American agriculture,'' he promised. Bush pointed to the emerging economies in Eastern Europe as a prime target for expanded farm exports. U.S. farm exports already are at record levels after three years of growth. The trip was Bush's first public appearance since ex-Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega surrendered last Wednesday to face trial in the United States on drug-trafficking charges. It comes as U.S. officials acknowledged they are having ``some difficulties'' arranging an increased role for the U.S. military in the Caribbean off the coast of Colombia to help intercept drug smugglers' sea and air routes. Bush, asked Sunday as he went jogging about reports that the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and other ships were steaming toward Colombia, said, ``I will address myself ... to that question at a future date.'' When a reporter suggested that Colombian officials were upset, Bush said, ``We don't know all that.'' National security adviser Brent Scowcroft said discussions with Colombian authorities have not begun. However, Bogota's El Tiempo published a communique Sunday by the government of President Virgilio Barco that said the Colombian ``government has not participated, nor will it participate, in any joint operation with United States military forces, air or naval, in the Caribbean Sea.'' ``In international waters it has not participated, nor will it, and in territorial waters it has not authorized (the operations), nor is it considering authorizing them,'' the statement added. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Sunday that he expected the announcement of stepped-up military anti-drug efforts within the next two week and predicted that the Latin nations and ``anybody interested in halting the flow of illicit drugs into the United States will be supportive.''

DOC.HEAD: Lecturer Recalls Lincoln's Days in White House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 9, The Lincolns, and 15, As the war, to CORRECT name of Lincoln son to Tad.
DOC.TEXT: In Abraham Lincoln's day, souvenir-hunters and job-seekers roamed virtually unchecked through the White House night and day, and even the family's pet goats had the run of the executive mansion, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian says. David Herbert Donald of Harvard University kept President and Mrs. Bush and 125 others enraptured Sunday night with his descriptions of the down-to-earth life the Lincolns led during the Civil War. ``This is the first in a series of lectures on the men who've held this office. And it seeks to make them come alive,'' Bush told the audience gathered in the State Dining Room. ``What were they like? How did they live? How was history, the history of America's house, molded by their dreams? ``To occupy this office is to ask those questions and certainly to feel a kinship with those who have gone before,'' said Bush, the 41st president. Lincoln, Donald said, came to Washington in 1861 from Springfield, Ill., with few friends and no administrative experience. He found himself a virtual prisoner in his own home, besieged by job-seekers at every turn. The Kentucky-born Mary Todd Lincoln was regarded as an uncouth frontierswoman by Washington's society elite. Their suspicions grew when four of her brothers and three brothers-in-law enlisted in the Confederate cause. The floors of the mansion's public rooms were covered in oilcloth to make it easier to clean up the spills from overflowing spittoons. Mrs. Lincoln made short work of a four-year appropriation of $20,000 _ $200,000 in today's dollars _ to fix up the mansion, spending it in weeks and running up other bills on credit. ``Merchants showed her the best ... and she bought everything,'' Donald said. Lincoln fulminated, but Congress passed a supplemental appropriation to cover the debts. The Lincolns were the first family to raise children in the White House, with their two youngest sons, Willie and Tad, ages 10 and 8, commandeering the roof for a fort from which they ``fired'' on invisible rebels across the Potomac. Citizens showered them with gifts, including a pony and two goats, which, ``like the public at large, had the run of the White House,'' Donald said. But on Feb. 5, 1862, even as the Lincolns were host to 500 guests to show off the restored mansion, both boys lay seriously ill upstairs with ``bilious'' fever _ possibly typhoid from the White House's foul water supply, Donald said. Willie died two weeks later, leaving both parents grief-stricken. Lincoln recovered, but his wife did not, lapsing into a deep depression and becoming the dupe of spiritualists who held at least eight seances at the White House. Lincoln attended one ``to find out who was preying on his wife's mental instability,'' Donald said. Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation in the fall of 1862, and his Republican Party lost the congressional elections. As the war went poorly, Lincoln ate little and slept poorly in a bedroom separate from his wife. Tad, beset with nightmares, often slept in his father's bed. A year after Willie's death, the Lincolns began entertaining again. Mrs. Lincoln continued her spendthrift ways, buying jewelry and clothing galore, including 400 pairs of gloves in a three-month period. She needed 19 wagons to cart her belongings to a summer residence. Mrs. Bush said after Donald's lecture that she felt ``agonizingly sorry'' for Mrs. Lincoln. ``I hadn't known she had any happy times. All our pictures of her are agonizingly sad,'' she said. ``We always think today our lives are so complicated. Then you look at what Lincoln stepped into. ... Things look pretty good for us.'' Bush said he plans two more presidential lectures this year. He did not say who will give them, but noted, ``I always love Teddy Roosevelt.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Convenes Public Meeting On Ethnic Turkish Question
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with the talks beginning on minority issue, Bulgaria-Turkey talks planned Tuesday. Pickup 12th graf ``Bulgaria _ a ...'; ADDS 1 graf of background.
DOC.TEXT: Communist officials began talks today with members of the opposition, the Turkish minority and Slav majority on ethnic conflicts that erupted in a wave of nationwide protests last week. The meeting at the National Assembly building, chaired by Parliament President Stanko Todorov, was called after four days of nationalist rallies against a decision by Communist leaders allowing ethnic Turks and Moslems to use their Moslem names and practice their religion without restrictions. Ethnic conflicts have become more apparent in some parts of Eastern Europe, where hard-line Communist regimes were replaced by reformist governments last year. The government news agency BTA reported that representatives from all official and opposition groups, as well as delegations from dozens of cities were taking part in the forum, which the agency termed unprecedented in Communist Bulgaria. Todorov on Sunday night called for the weeklong ``social forum'' on ``several aspects of the national question.'' BTA did not identify who was taking part in the forum. It said the meeting today was to discuss how to organize the talks and that formal negotiations would begin Tuesday. However, BTA said the participants unanimously approved an appeal to the people to call off all rallies and strikes to ensure a ``peaceful and business-like atmosphere'' at the talks. At a rally Sunday, Bulgarian demonstrators threatened to start a general strike if their demands were not met that a referendum be held on the minority issue. News media controlled by the 2-month-old leadership that replaced hard-liner Todor Zhivkov reported that local officials who are holdovers from the old regime appeared to be using the ethnic issue to try to stall reform. But the media also reported a resurgence of Turkish nationalism in some areas, quoting witnesses as saying Turkish flags have been seen flying over public buildings in one southern city. Premier Georgi Atanassov said the practice was illegal. The demonstrators demand the repeal of a Dec. 29 order restoring rights to Bulgaria's 1.5 million ethnic Turks and Moslems. That decision reversed the assimilation policy introduced by Zhivkov, who forced ethnic Turks to change their names to Bulgarian ones and barred them from speaking Turkish in public. Nationalists among the Slav majority, who are mainly Orthodox Christian, fear the Turkish minority is growing too fast and poses a threat to the country of nearly 9 million. Slavs also are suspicious of the loyalties of the Bulgarian Turks and ethnic Bulgarian Moslems, known as Pomaks, since Bulgaria won independence in 1877 from the Ottoman Empire, which had ruled it for 500 years. The government of Turkey, which lies on Bulgaria's southeastern border, and some Bulgarian Turks have blamed Zhivkov's hard-line Commmunist followers for instigating the unrest. Bulgarian Foreign Minister Boiko Dimitrov is to meet his Turkish counterpart Mesut Yilmaz in Kuwait Tuesday for a second round of talks on the minority issue. On Friday, thousands of Bulgarian workers walked off the job in at least five cities. Other demonstrations took place over the weekend. ``Bulgaria _ a one-nationality country,'' read banners carried by some of the 10,000 ethnic Slavs who demonstrated in Sofia on Sunday outside Alexander Nevski Cathedral. Standing in zero-degree weather, the protesters booed, hissed or chanted ``Resignation! Resignation!'' as Atanassov and Interior Minister Atanas Semerdzhiev tried to address them. In an apparent attempt to appease the protesters, Atanassov said Bulgarian would remain the official language. But both his and Semerdzhiev's speeches were drowned out. ``A hard time will befall the country whose people is divided,'' the official news agency BTA quoted Semerdzhiev as saying. He appealed to the crowd not to undermine ``the tendencies towards democracy in the country.'' BTA said residents from the southern town of Kardzhali, where almost half the 50,000 inhabitants are ethnic Turks, reported seeing Turkish flags on public buildings. Atanassov, in a television address Sunday, said it was ``inadmissible to raise the flag of a foreign state at demonstrations and rallies in public and private places.'' He said the interior minister had been told to maintain public peace and ``neutralize any anti-constitutional and extremist acts under the framework of law.'' He did not elaborate. A leader of the influential independent trade union Podkrepa, Nikolai Kolev, called for members to ``fight against all destructive forces.'' In a statement broadcast on state TV he said he thought nationalistic protests were being spurred by local officials. While Petar Mladenov, who took over from Zhivkov as party leader Nov. 10, has moved quickly to put new people in the leadership more likely to support democratic reform, few changes have been made at the local level. Some 320,000 ethnic Turks fled Zhivkov's persecution and emigrated to Turkey last summer, but at least 50,000 returned because of a lack of jobs and proper housing. Elsewhere in Eastern Europe, a revolt by ethnic Hungarians against the Romanian government last month turned into a nationwide uprising that ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Rebels Vow Stepped-Up Attacks On U.S. Troops, Local Officials
DOC.TEXT: Communist guerrillas operating around a U.S. base will step up attacks on American soldiers, local officials and other ``anti-revolutionary elements,'' a rebel spokesman said today. The ``new year offensive'' will involve fresh recruits ``ready to strike any time at targets of opportunity,'' said Aryel Miranda, spokesman of the New People's Army brigade based in this city 40 miles north of Manila. Angeles is the home of the U.S. Clark Air Base. Speaking to reporters over a radio link, Miranda said the targets included those near Olongapo City, site of the U.S. Subic Naval Base, 50 miles west of Manila, and the U.S. communications facility at Camp O'Donnel in Tarlac province north of Angeles. ``We will not waste chances,'' Miranda said. ``We will already confront them to hasten the national democratic revolution,'' Miranda said. The rebel spokesman said the offensive against U.S. soldiers and Filipino ``collaborators'' was decided to coincide with talks on the future of the bases, expected to begin by March. The lease on the bases expires in 1991 and a new treaty is needed to extend their stay. He said the guerrillas were not yet prepared to launch direct attacks on U.S. facilities. He added that American civilians or retired U.S. military personnel were not targets of the rebel offensive. He said Friday's assassination of Javier Hizon, mayor of nearby Mexico town, ``was just a first sampling'' of sporadic but intensified attacks by the Mariano Garcia Brigade. Miranda said local officials led by Angeles Mayor Antonio Abad Santos who allegedly are corrupt would be included in the offensive. Abad Santos was not available for comment. The urban guerilla squad was responsible for the killing of two U.S. airmen and another American in October 1987. Last September, guerrillas ambushed and killed two U.S. civilian employees working at Camp O'Donnel to coincide with the visit in Manila of Vice President Dan Quayle. About 40,000 American troops, civilians and military dependents are stationed at the six U.S. military installations in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Subway Hires Workers To Push More Commuters into Jammed Cars
DOC.TEXT: Subway authorities said today they will hire new workers to push commuters into jammed trains at subway stations. More than 130 workers will be deployed at 20 crowded stations in Seoul to help commuters squeeze their way into cars and prevent rush-hour delays, officials said. About 3 million people use four subway lines daily, with 1 million at rush-hours, causing congestion at key stations and slowing the overall operation of the subway system. Seoul plans to build three more subway lines in the 1990s to meet growing public demands.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Clash with Riot Police as U.S. Ambassador Holds News Conference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with further protests, report police opposed Gregg visit, background; picks up 13th pvs, `Chun said...'
DOC.TEXT: Radical students hurling firebombs burned effigies of U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg and President Roh Tae-woo today in the provincial city of Kwangju to protest Gregg's visit, reports said. A separate group of 100 protesters threw human excrement and tear gas powder near a police station several hundred yards from the U.S. Cultural Center residence where Gregg visited, the reports said. About 500 radical students yelling anti-American slogans hurled firebombs and rocks at 900 combat-clad riot police outside the main gate of Chosun University, reported Yonhap, the South Korean news agency. Two black armored vans fired volleys of tear gas shells to break up a campus rally, but groups of students and riot police clashed in hand-to-hand fighting inside the campus for more than an hour, Yonhap said. No injuries or arrests were reported. Gregg apparently did not see the fighting, news reports said. He was the first U.S. ambassador to visit Kwangju, a provincial city 155 miles south of Seoul, since a 1980 civil uprising in which 200 were killed and 1,500 injured. Many Kwangju citizens believe Washington condoned the mobilization of the Korean military to put down unrest and silence government dissent. Washington has repeatedly denied the allegations. ``Gregg came here under a scheme with Roh Tae-woo trying to unilaterally shelve the Kwangju issue,'' yelled a student leader at the rally, Yonhap said. The students vowed to continue their struggle to overthrow Roh's government and punish the United States, which they claim played a role in the uprising. The Hankook Ilbo, a Seoul daily newspaper, said police advised against Gregg's visit, but U.S. officials insisted that an explanation of the American role in Kwangju should be resolved through dialogue. ``I came here not to make an apology but to express regret and condolences to Kwangju citizens,'' Gregg told a news conference in a downtown hotel, according to Yonhap, which said he denied any U.S. involvement in putting down the uprising. Gregg reportedly told journalists the United States urged the South Korean government in 1980 to settle the protests in Kwangju peacefully, ``but our influence was not enough over the South Korean government.'' Anti-American sentiment in strong in Kwangju and the U.S. cultural center has been attacked by radical students 28 times since 1980. It was closed last year after U.S. officials expressed concern for the safety of the staff. Gregg, a former CIA station chief in Seoul, has been the target of protests since he was appointed ambassador last year. On Oct. 13, six radical students broke into his residence and hurled homemade bombs at police before being overpowered. Gregg and his wife, Meg, were unhurt. He arrived in Kwangju on Sunday for a three-day stay. Last week, the U.S. Embassy issued a statement rejecting former President Chun Doo-hwan's reference to an alleged U.S. role in the Kwangju incident. Chun said in parliamentary testimony Dec. 31 that he, then an army general, decided on the military suppression of the uprising after receiving information from the United States that the military threat from communist North Korea was increasing. The U.S. Embassy said the United States did not see any evidence of a heightened threat from North Korea at the time.

DOC.HEAD: $35 Million Lotto Claim Reportedly a Hoax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Taylor, 30, ... to CORRECT name of hotel to Omni Park Central sted Park Central.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY19
DOC.TEXT: A woman said she won a $35 million Lotto jackpot after Donald Trump and Malcolm Forbes told her the lucky numbers in a dream, but a news report today said she later admitted it was a hoax. Charlene ``Charlie'' Taylor pulled the prank with the help of Alan Abel, a jokester whose previous feats included getting his own obituary printed in The New York Times and staging fainting spells in the audience of a ``Donahue'' TV show, the Daily News said. Taylor, 30, said she was a cosmetologist and had shown reporters what she said was a photocopy of the ticket as she staged a champagne party Sunday at $400-a-night suite at the Omni Park Central Hotel in midtown Manhattan. But the photocopy _ which listed the winning numbers 18, 25, 26, 32, 42 and 44 _ was fake, the News said. The newspaper reported that Abel and Taylor admitted the hoax after one of their reporters recognized Abel as the teacher of a class she had once taken on practical jokes. Abel told the News the hoax took six months to plan, involved a dozen actors and was a way to ``provide some levity in the news between the ax murders and hostages. It's a grand satire.'' Taylor told the News she is an actress-comedian from Manhattan. Lottery officials had been cautious all along, saying Sunday night they could not confirm Taylor's claim until she turned in the actual ticket, which Taylor said was ``in a safe place, safely hidden away.'' Her claim to be the winner was broadcast on local television and radio stations and printed in local newspapers. The real holder of the $35 million Lotto jackpot _ the largest individual lottery award in state history _ has yet to come forward. Lottery officials say the lone winning ticket was sold in suburban Westchester County. Taylor told reporters at the hotel Sunday night that the winning numbers came to her in a dream in which Trump and Forbes ``were circling around me, spewing out numbers and they told me the right thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Children Drown in Icy Water
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT spelling of `through.'
DOC.TEXT: Three children, including a brother and sister, fell through ice and drowned in a water-filled coal pit, police said. From marks on the ice, ``you know they were playing one minute and the next minute they were grabbing, clawing and scratching for their lives,'' said Warrick County Sheriff Jeffrey T. Gore. Erin Hernandez, 11, her brother, Nathan, 12, and a friend, Tom McNabb, 12, all of the Boonville area in southwestern Indiana, were pronounced dead late Saturday by Vanderburgh County Coroner Michael Miodus. They fell through a 2-inch layer of ice Saturday afternoon in a pit owned by Peabody Coal Co. The children were submerged in the water for at least a half-hour before rescuers reached them, authorities said. Parents discovered the holes in the ice after the children did not return for lunch as expected. The children had been told to stay away from the pits, ``but they're kids,'' said Elizabeth Hernandez, Erin and Nathan's mother.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Checking Mount St. Helens for Clues to Future Activity
DOC.TEXT: Scientists took samples of gritty ash from the flanks of Mount St. Helens in hopes of learning whether the volcano's latest burst will bring more explosive activity. Three scientists got within 12 miles of the crater on the east flanks of the 8,366-foot mountain Sunday to gather ash from the largest explosion in nearly four years. Dan Dzurisin, acting scientist in charge of the Cascades Volcano Observatory in Vancouver, said the ash appeared to be pulverized material from previously erupted lava. If an examination by microscope shows the ash is from a new surge of magma or molten rock beneath the volcano, however, it could be a sign of more explosions to come, Dzurisin said. Scientists also planned to fly in a helicopter over the crater to determine whether there was an avalanche from the lava dome in the eruption Saturday morning. Dense clouds prevented a flight Sunday, Dzurisin said. The latest eruption, which came without preceding earthquakes, sent ash as far as 90 miles to the east and destroyed two seismometers and two tilt meters in the crater. No injuries were reported. Seismographs and other equipment recorded the two-minute explosion beginning at 5:37 a.m. Saturday. After a couple of hours of small earthquakes beneath the volcano, seismic activity subsided to normal levels, Dzurisin said. In the past few months, there have twice been lesser bursts from the volcano. On Aug. 24, there was a minor eruption with no ashfall detected. On Dec. 8, ashfall was limited to the crater. An eruption like Saturday's, without the small earthquakes in advance to give a warning, is ``relatively new to us,'' Dzurisin said. It was the most significant explosion since a series of small explosions spit ash in the spring of 1986, he said. U.S. Forest Service and Wapato police officials received dozens of calls Saturday, reporting light dustings of a fine, gritty, gray-white ash in and around Yakima in the south-central part of the state. Yakima is about 80 miles from the volcano. The volcano's last significantly large eruption was on March 19, 1982, when mud flowed from the crater six miles to the north fork of the Toutle River, he said.
