The last dome-building eruption, a more quiet process in which molten rock pushes upward to swell the huge mound of cooling lava in the crater, was in 1986. Studying the recent ashfall could indicate whether the eruption was part of a ``last gasp'' or the start of a more explosive phase in the volcanic activity that began in March 1980, Dzurisin said. The cataclysmic explosion of May 18, 1980, leveled 230 square miles, killed 57 people and sent up an ash cloud that circled the globe. It also blew off the top 1,300 feet of the peak.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Groups Threaten To Pull Out Of Reconciliation Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with opposition suspending talks until government officials explain the domestic security situation; picks up 14th pvs, `The Communist...'
DOC.TEXT: Opposition groups today questioned assurances by Communist leaders that East Germany's secret police is being disbanded and alleged that one unit had urged a coup to stop democratic reforms. The opposition group Democratic Awakening today said opposition representatives were suspending talks on East Germany's future with the government until officials explain the domestic security situation. Today's talks were covered on national television. A collapse of the talks could endanger the tenuous acceptance of Communist Premier Hans Modrow's transitional Cabinet by the opposition, which has been unable to present a unified front. Opposition groups earlier had threatened to leave the talks over what they charge are government efforts to preserve a domestic intelligence network that could stifle the reform movement. Rolf Henrich of New Forum, the largest opposition group, disclosed what he said was a draft telex prepared by secret police agents in the city of Gera on Dec. 9, urging authorities in East Berlin to ``paralyze'' the opposition. Henrich said he was uncertain if the telex was ever dispatched, but contended it ``called for a coup'' to end the democratic reform movement. Communist Party chief Gregor Gysi and representatives of other traditionally Communist-allied parties said they were unaware of the message. Democratic Awakening leader Wolfgang Schnur demanded that the national prosecutor's office and the Interior Ministry appear before representatives of the opposition and government later in the afternoon. The Modrow government, formed after a peaceful popular October revolution toppled hard-line Communist leaders, has promised to create the conditions for free and fair elections on May 6. As talks resumed today, the opposition demanded that the government disarm agents of the former State Security Office by Jan. 19 and drop plans to set up a new agency to succeed it before the May elections. Peter Koch, an official named by the government to oversee dissolution of the secret police, said authorities plan to confiscate all of the former agency's arms by the end of this month. Former agents are already barred from access to weapons, he said. Reports last month by the official ADN news agency said the force had been disbanded. Modrow said in an interview Sunday with Austrian television that a security force is needed to prevent the spread of right-wing extremism in East Germany. In today's session, some opposition leaders lashed out at Communist authorities for allegedly trying to portray them as right-wingers. Markus Meckel, a delegate of the opposition Social Democratic Party, said recent government warnings about a rise of neo-Nazism is aimed at justifying authorities' desire to preserve the secret police. The negotiations, launched Dec. 7, includes some 40 delegates from the Communists, other political parties long aligned with them but now independent, and the pro-democracy opposition. The Communist Party has given up its constitutional monopoly on power and has been tarnished by corruption charges against previous Communist leaders. But the opposition has been hard-pressed to offer a credible alternative to continued Communist rule. Pre-election unity announced by six East German reform movements proved short-lived Sunday, with one group announcing it has abandoned the coalition and New Forum saying it prefers to run candidates independently. The United Left pro-reform group has withdrawn from the opposition's Election Alliance 90 coalition announced on Thursday, ADN reported. Bernd Gehrkes of United Left was quoted by ADN as saying that his group was ``misleadingly presented'' in the announcement by the Social Democrats, another of the pro-democracy groups, that six movements were banding together to boost their election chances. Social Democratic leader Steffen Reiche said three days earlier that his party had joined with New Forum, Democratic Awakening, Democracy Now, the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights and the United Left. But at a weekend congress in Leipzig, 150 delegates from New Forum branches around the country declared that election of individual, independent candidates was preferable to voting for political parties or alliances, and that New Forum candidates would rather run alone. Dozens of citizens' groups pressing for social, political, environmental and economic reforms have sprung up throughout East Germany since the Oct. 18 ouster of hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker and the nation's turn toward democracy and open borders.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Planning to Inject Woman With AIDS Virus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT that man alleged to have planned to have second person inject the woman, sted injecting her himself.
DOC.TEXT: A man planned to kill his former girlfriend by hiring a hit man to inject her with the AIDS virus, officials said. Charles Crewse, 55, of Springfield was being held on $100,000 bond in the St. Charles County Jail, accused of conspiring to murder a 36-year-old woman who recently moved to St. Louis from Springfield. He was accused of offering to pay a Springfield man $1,000 to murder the woman by injecting her with the deadly virus, which the accomplice claimed to have access to through contacts at a medical center. The hired man changed his mind and told the former girlfriend in October, said Detective David Asher of the Springfield police department. Crewse was arrested Wednesday after he followed the woman home from work and threatened her and her sister, Asher said. ``It's a bizarre situation, and we felt it was necessary to proceed with charges,'' Asher said. The plot was reported to police in October but officials delayed arresting Crewse until he made further physical contact with her, Asher said. Crewse allegedly planned the murder since July, when the woman ended her relationship with him, he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf of LINWOOD, N.J.-dated 4th item to CORRECT spelling of Rainier, CORRECT grammar.
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Kelly, mother of the late Princess Grace of Monaco and matriarch of the Kelly clan of Philadelphia, died Saturday of pneumonia at a convalescent home. She was 91. She was a former beauty queen and magazine cover girl. Her daughter Grace became a Hollywood actress and later married Prince Rainier of Monaco. Princess Grace died of injuries suffered in an automobile accident in September 1982. Mrs. Kelly's husband, John B. Kelly Sr., was an Olympic rowing champion who parlayed his skills as a bricklayer into a construction empire. He died in 1960. Born on Dec. 13, 1898, the former Margaret Majer met her future husband at a Philadelphia swimming pool when she was a teen-ager. They married in 1924. In her early 20s, she appeared on the covers of several national magazines. An accomplished swimmer and athlete, Mrs. Kelly was the first director of women's athletics at the University of Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Coup Attempt Said More Extensive Than Initially Thought
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf, `Cruz and ...' to UPDATE with general saying rebels had plotted assassinations; Picks up 6th graf, `Mrs. Aquino...'
DOC.TEXT: Last month's coup attempt was staged by more troops than previously thought, and some senior officers believed most of the armed forces were involved in the plot, according to documents obtained today. The assessments were contained in sworn affidavits made to military investigators probing the bloody Dec. 1-9 attempt to topple President Corazon Aquino. The Associated Press obtained copies of the statements from military sources. In one affidavit, a rebel army captain who later defected to the government said coup plotters had expected priests, nuns, government officials and civilians to join mutinous soldiers, repeating the 1986 ``People's Power'' revolt that ousted the late ruler Ferdinand Marcos. Capt. Jose Cruz, assistant chief of staff of logistics for the Philippine military, said the failed coup that officials said left 113 dead was launched to combat alleged corruption, nepotism and inefficiency. Cruz and seven other military officers affirmed their statements Friday before a government panel investigating whether to file rebellion charges against two retired brigadier generals implicated in the failed putsch. Brig. Gen. Oscar Florendo, chief of the Civil Relations Service, said a major enlisted men's fraternity has been linked to the coup attempt and tried to assassinate him and other military officials, the Philippines News Agency reported today. Florendo, quoting two captured rebel soldiers, said the Guardian Brotherhood was involved in the coup attempt. Guardian members have been linked to a previous coup attempt. Mrs. Aquino has also created a presidential commission to investigate the coup attempt, arming it with emergency powers to open bank accounts of suspected plotters. At least five flag officers, four of them at large, were identified by the military as having joined the attempt. At least 20 officers, whose names had not been previously linked to other rebellions, are being investigated for their role in the coup attempt. Col. Abraham Paray, commanding officer of the Light Armored Brigade, said he tried to dissuade rebel officers from using violence when they seized the army headquarters on the first day. Paray said he asked the mutineers who were ``orchestrating their actions'' and was told that most in the military hierarchy was involved except Secretary of National Defense Fidel Ramos, Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa and constabulary chief Maj. Gen. Ramon Montano. He said the rebels identified military backers, including the commander of the elite Scout Rangers, Brig. Gen. Marcelo Blando, who is is hiding, and the chief of the Southern Luzon command, Brig. Gen. Alejandro Galido. Galido has not been charged but was sent on leave for alleged health problems. He denied any role in the coup attempt. ``But considering the big names that they dropped, I gathered the impression that the majority of the Armed Forces of the Philippines had a hand in the takeover,'' said Paray who was among those held captive at the officer's lounge at army headquarters Fort Bonifacio. In another affidavit, Cruz, who was also implicated but acquitted in the August 1987 failed coup, said most Scout Ranger companies joined the mutiny, including those from southern and central Luzon Island. The specific units he cited had not been previously linked to the coup attempt. Cruz said he had attended secret meetings since October with plotters led by a Maj. Abraham Purugganan at the army headquarters. A briefing was held on the eve of the mutiny and final instructions made. ``It was also explained to us that on the morning of Dec 1 when the major services have already occupied their respective areas, the representatives of these major services will converge at the Philippine army headquarters to be joined and attended by government officials, politicians, media, cause-oriented groups, priests and nuns and others,'' Cruz said. He said a junta was to then convene, adding that identities of politicians or members of the junta were not mentioned. Cruz said he decided to defect on the first night and escaped on foot during a power failure in the camp.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets Stand Ruling on Cordless Telephone Privacy
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let stand a ruling that people have no constitutionally protected right to privacy when at home speaking on a cordless telephone. The court, without comment, turned away arguments that law enforcement agents acted unlawfully when, without obtaining a court warrant, they monitored an Iowa family's cordless-telephone conversations. Noting that the technology of cordless phones makes conversations on them more susceptible to interception, a federal judge said, ``Because there was no justifiable expectation of privacy, the interceptions did not violate the Fourth Amendment.'' The Constitution's Fourth Amendment generally bars warrantless police searches and seizures, and since a landmark 1967 Supreme Court decision police have been barred from secretly listening to conversations over traditional phones without court warrants. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the judge's ruling in the Iowa case last June 15, making it binding law in seven states _ Iowa, Arkansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota and South Dakota. Today's Supreme Court action does not carry any direct impact on any state aside from those seven. One of every four American homes has a cordless phone, according to industry estimates. Over nine million of the phones were sold in 1989. The cordless phone relays a speaker's voice from a mobile handset to a base unit through the use of low-power radio transmissions. From the base unit, the signal is transmitted through regular telephone lines. The phone can be used anywhere within a certain distance from the base unit, usually a range of up to 700 feet. Conversations on it, however, may be heard by another cordless phone nearby and on the same frequency. Scott and Sheila Tyler of Dixon, Iowa, received a cordless phone as a gift in June 1983. It was regularly used by the Tylers and their children as another extension phone. Neighbors Rich and Sandra Berodt, who lived several blocks away, soon discovered that their cordless phone would make ringing and dialing noises whenever the Tyler phone was in use. Based on some conversations they listened to, the Berodts suspected that Scott Tyler was involved in illegal drug dealing. They contacted Everett Howard, an investigator with the Scott County Sheriff's Department. Howard encouraged the Berodts to continue the eavesdropping, and supplied them with recording equipment so conversations on the Tylers' phone could be preserved on cassettes. The Berodts' suspicion about drug-dealing proved unfounded, but over several months authorities relied on the tapes to charge Scott Tyler with criminal theft and conspiracy. The tapes, however, were barred as evidence at his criminal trial. Tyler was convicted in late 1984 on charges stemming from his bilking two food companies out of $35,000. He was sentenced to 10 years in prison, but was released after serving 123 days. Tyler and his family later sued the Berodts, Scott County, Sheriff Forest Ashcraft and sheriff's investigator Howard in federal court. The lawsuit contended that the warrantless monitoring of the Tyler cordless phone violated the family's Fourth Amendment privacy rights. U.S. District Judge Harold D. Vietor in Davenport threw out the suit, and the dismissal was upheld by the 8th Circuit court. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for the Tylers said the technological differences between a cordless phone and a traditional phone are not enough ``to remove all Fourth Amendment protection for the daily communications of millions of people.'' ``Americans justifiably expect privacy in their residential phone conversations,'' the appeal said. ``That expectation is not based on faith in technology but on faith in our constitutional system.'' The case is Tyler vs. Berodt, 89-691.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Rebels Claim To Have Repulsed Major Government Offensive
DOC.TEXT: Afghan rebels today claimed they killed 200 Communist soldiers and repulsed hundreds more in a monthlong government assault on guerrilla positions in northwestern Afghanistan. The official rebel information agency MIDIA said 70 rebels died in the fighting, which also destroyed scores of homes in the district of Shireen Tagab, about 75 miles south of Afghanistan's border with the Soviet Union. The rebel agency blamed the destruction on ``indiscriminate bombing and shelling,'' by government troops. Meanwhile MIDIA said Moscow sent two MiG-29 aircraft, reportedly the latest in the Soviet fleet of fighter jets, to Afghanistan along with a group of Soviet pilots. Like most reports from both the rebels and the Afghan government, its authenticity could not be independently verified. The pilots have been stationed in central Afghanistan's Bagram airforce base, the country's largest, MIDIA said. U.S.-backed guerrilla fighters, based in Pakistan, have been fighting for more than 11 years to topple successive Communist governments in Afghanistan. Until a year ago, more than 103,000 Soviet soldiers fought alongside Afghan government troops.

DOC.HEAD: Shades Of Wild West: Armed Bandit With Handkerchief Around Face Robs Train
DOC.TEXT: A bandit wearing a handkerchief to conceal his face pulled a Wild West-style train holdup at a railroad crossing, authorities said. Conrail police and the Ottawa County Sheriff's Department are investigating the robbery of two Conrail crew members aboard a freight train, sheriff's dispatcher Gale Zelms said Sunday. Conrail spokeswoman Barbara Vasco said a man armed with a shotgun boarded the freight train Saturday while it was stopped at a railroad crossing to check an air leak. The bandit, who wore a handkerchief tied around his head, robbed two crew members of personal belongings and then ran off, the spokeswomen said. The 60-car train was en route from Chicago to Newark, N.J. Ms. Vasco said the train was carrying miscellaneous consumer goods. She declined to identify the crew members, citing company policy.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Appeal of Tennessee Student in Free Speech Controversy
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected the appeal of a Tennessee high school student pulled from a race for student council president after giving a speech officials deemed disrespectful. The court, without comment, let stand rulings that officials at Unicoi County High in Erwin, Tenn., did not violate Dean Poling's free-speech rights. Poling was a junior running for student council president when in May 1987 he delivered a school assembly campaign speech critical of the school's administration. ``If you want to break the iron grip of this school, vote for me for president,'' Poling told the assembly audience. He also singled out the school's assistant principal in charge of discipline for criticism. ``The admninistration plays tricks with your mind and they hope you won't notice. For example, why does Mr. Davidson stutter while he is on the intercom? He doesn't have a speech impediment,'' Poling said. Because of the speech, school principal Ellis Murphy disqualified Poling from the student council presidency race. He later was elected president of his senior class. Murphy said Poling's speech had a disruptive effect on the school administration's authority, and had shown insensitivity and bad taste in its remarks about the assistant principal. Poling's parents sued school officials and the school board in their son's behalf, seeking $300,000 in damages for an asserted violation of his free-speech rights. A federal judge threw out the suit without a trial, and the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal by a 2-1 vote last April 18. ``For all we know there may in fact have been an overreaction (by school authorities),'' the appeals court said. ``But a federal court is obviously not the ideal body to try to answer such a question.'' It added: ``Dean Poling appears to be an intelligent and imaginative young man, and probably no more anarchistic than many of his teachers at his age. Like most teen-agers, Dean doubtless feels embarrassment very keenly _ but he may not fully have appreciated that the assistant principals of this world are sentient beings also, some of whom may even be capable of experiencing embarrassment themselves.'' In a dissenting opinion, Judge Gilbert Merritt said Poling's remarks amounted to ``political speech, pure and simple'' and that the action taken against him was unconstitutional. In a landmark 1969 ruling, the Supreme Court said high school students do not ``shed their constitutional rights to freedom of speech or expression at the schoolhouse gate,'' and ruled that officials wrongly had banned the wearing of anti-war armbands. But the court in 1986 gave school administrators broad disciplinary powers that include suspending students who use vulgar language. And in 1988 the justices gave school officials new authority to censor student newspapers and other forms of student expression at school-sponsored events. In the appeal acted on today, Poling said the test for whether student speech is constitutionally protected ``is not rudeness or impoliteness but disruption and disorder.'' The appeal said Poling's 1987 speech was not disruptive and caused no disorder. School officials urged that Poling's appeal be rejected. They said that his speech, unlike the wearing of an anti-war armband, did not just happen to occur on school grounds but was part of a school-sponsored activity. The case is Poling vs. Murphy, 89-678.

DOC.HEAD: Court Won't Reinstate Award in Hired-Killer Case from Texas
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to reinstate a $9.4 million award won, and then lost, by the family of a woman whose husband hired her killer through an ad in Soldier of Fortune magazine. The justices, without comment, let stand a federal appeals court ruling that threw out a much-publicized jury verdict against the magazine. Although the case had been viewed as one testing the scope of free-speech and free-press rights, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals did not invoke those constitutional issues in its ruling last August. Instead, the appeals court relied on Texas liability law. Soldier of Fortune ``owed no duty to refrain from publishing a facially innocuous classified advertisement when the ad's content _ at most _ made its message ambiguous,'' the appeals court ruled. The August decision overturned the $9.4 million award won in a wrongful-death lawsuit filed by the son and mother of Sandra Black, who was killed in her Bryan, Texas, home in 1985. Mrs. Black's husband, Robert, hired John Wayne Hearn for $10,000 to kill her after seeing his ad in a 1984 issue of the magazine. The ad described Hearn as an ex-Marine and ``weapons specialist'' available for ``high risk assignments'' in this country or overseas. Black was convicted and sentenced to death for arranging his wife's murder. He is a prisoner on Texas' death row. Hearn, also convicted of two contract killings in Florida, is serving three life sentences in a Florida prison. A federal jury in Houston ruled that Soldier of Fortune, based in Boulder, Colo., and aimed at adventurers and military enthusiasts, had negligently contributed to Mrs. Black's killing. The jury awarded Mrs. Black's son, Gary, and her mother, Marjorie Eimann, $1.9 million in compensatory damages and $7.5 million in punitive damages. But the 5th Circuit court said, ``Without a more specific indication of illegal intent than Hearn's ad or its context provided ... (the magazine) did not violate the required standard of conduct by publishing an ad that later played a role in criminal activity.'' After last August's ruling, E. Barrett Prettyman Jr., a lawyer for Soldier of Fortune publisher Robert Brown, said the jury's verdict ``would not only have put the magazine out of business but would have had an extraordinarily harmful effect on magazines and publishers of all kinds.'' In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for Mrs. Black's son and mother said the appeals court actually relied on the Constitution's free-speech protections, not Texas law, in ruling for the magazine. ``Regardless of the label the court applies to its reasoning, it appears that the First Amendment was the principal inspiration for its ruling,'' the appeal contended. It said Hearn's ad was not entitled to such protection because it was ``commercial speech related to illegal activity.'' The case is Eimann vs. Soldier of Fortune, 89-790.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Review Dispute Over Welfare Aid in Virginia Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to review a dispute over how much welfare aid some needy families are entitled to receive. The court said it will hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at limiting the payments in a Virginia case. At issue are features of the Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) program. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last March ruled partly in favor of welfare officials and partly in favor of AFDC recipients. The appeals court said Social Security benefits paid to any child in a household must be considered in determining eligibility for AFDC payments to the family. That has the effect of reducing AFDC payments. Virginia families participating in the program said the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, in restricting AFDC benefits, misinterpreted a 1984 budget-cutting law. The 4th Circuit court also ruled that the first $50 a month families receive in Social Security benefits must be disregarded when determining AFDC payments. The Bush administration asked the justices to overturn that part of the appeals court decision. A separate appeal filed in behalf of the Virginia families involved in the case was not acted on today. Justice Department lawyers said the $50-disregard provision, enacted by Congress in 1974, applies only to child support payments made by an absent parent _ and not to Social Security benefits paid to a child of a deceased or disabled parent. The 4th Circuit court disagreed. ``We perceive no distinction between support derived directly from a father's wages and support provided indirectly through'' Social Security, the appeals court said. ``The money to support the child comes directly through the father or indirectly through insurance he earned when working.'' Government lawyers said if the appeals court's view of the $50-disregard provision were adopted nationwide, states and the federal government would have to pump $44 million more each year into the AFDC program. The 4th Circuit court's ruling is binding law in Virginia, West Virginia, Maryland, North Carolina and South Carolina. The government appeal noted that the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals has issued a ruling that conflicts with the 4th Circuit court decision. The case acted on today is Sullivan vs. Stroop, 89-535.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leaders Take Steps to Reassure Lawmakers of Possible Merger
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leaders considering a merger of two political parties met today with their lawmakers in efforts to convince them that the new alliance could curtail opposition infighting. The Republican Democratic Party and the New Democratic Republican Party, the nation's second- and third-largest opposition parties, have agreed in principle to form a new political party by merging forces for mid-year local elections, the first such elections in South Korea in three decades. The combined party then could outshadow the current leading opposition group, the Party for Peace and Democracy, and potentially offer a forceful challenge to the governing party. Kim Young-sam, leader of the Republican Democrats, today said the merger must be completed by March after ``prudently collecting opinions'' within and outside the party. Kim Jong-pil, head of the smallest opposition party, told a caucus of his lawmakers that the ``goal is to shift to a better political system, which can operate better in the long run.'' Kim Jong-pil is related by marriage to former President Park Chung-hee and served as prime minister in the early 1970s. He also was the organizer and first director of the national security agency, formerly called the KCIA. Some lawmakers said they would boycott a move to join with Kim Jong-pil's party because they did not want to be associated with past authoritarian regimes and instead would form an independent voting bloc in Parliament. South Korea has four political parties and most politicians regard the system as unworkable. Repeated efforts among party leaders to compromise have failed. In the 1987 presidential elections, opposition votes were split by two main opposition parties, helping governing party candidate Roh Tae-woo win by a narrow margin. The opposition leaders were blamed by some for ignoring popular demand for a united opposition candidate. Dissidents and radicals, claiming their views are not represented by the four major political parties, have announced plans to organize a progressive political party supported by workers, farmers and the poor.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Take Fresh Look at Labor Union Issue in Idaho Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to take a fresh look at whether labor unions may be sued in state courts for alleged failure to assure safe conditions for workers. The court said it will decide whether the United Steelworkers of America may be sued for alleged negligence in a 1972 Idaho silver mine disaster that killed 91 people. The disaster occurred May 2, 1972, at the Sunshine Mine in Kellogg. The U.S. Bureau of Mines said an underground fire apparently started when timbers and debris ignited spontaneously. The 91 miners died of asphyxiation or carbon monoxide poisoning. Families of dead miners sued the union, alleging that a safety committee member appointed by the union had failed during monthly inspections to point out or correct such problems as corroded oxygen-breathing equipment and padlocked rescue equipment. The Idaho Supreme Court ruled in 1986 that the union could be sued in state court. But the justices told the state court to reconsider its ruling after they, in 1987, gave unions new protection against such state court suits. The 1987 ruling said such suits generally are pre-empted by federal labor law. The justices stressed the need for 50-state uniformity in interpreting requirements of collective bargaining agreements. But the Idaho Supreme Court, in reconsidering the Sunshine Mine case, said the negligence claims were different because a union member was on the inspection team. The suit against the United Steelworkers does not depend upon any interpretation of the union's collective bargaining agreement with the mine owners, the state court said. ``We are not faced with looking at the collective bargaining agreement to determine whether it imposes some new duty upon the union,'' the state court said. ``Rather it is conceded the union undertook to inspect and, thus, the issue is solely whether that inspection was negligently performed under traditional Idaho (personal injury) law.'' The state court relied heavily on a 1988 Supreme Court ruling that reinstated a suit against a union by a woman who said she was fired improperly. The justices in that case said unions may be sued for violating state laws as long as courts can decide the suit without interpreting collective bargaining agreements. The case acted on today is United Steelworkers vs. Rawson, 89-322.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Challenge to Oregon Tax By Alaska, USAir
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today allowed states to impose on airlines a tax partially based on flight time over the states. The court, without comment, rejected a challenge to an Oregon tax described by two airlines as a toll booth in the sky. Lawyers for Alaska Airlines and USAir said, ``Oregon has erected a toll booth at 35,000 feet for interstate airplanes wishing to pass over the state.'' The formula for calculating an airline's property taxes includes the time an aircraft spends in the air over Oregon, even if the plane does not land or take off from there. The two airlines said the tax for such flights almost doubles the amount they owe Oregon each year. Alaska Airlines said it amounted to an extra $750,000 for 1988. The Oregon Supreme Court upheld the levy last February. The state court said the tax is not an assessment on overflights. ``More precisely, the formula reflected that portion of time that each airline's aircraft property spent on the ground or in the air in Oregon,'' it said. The state court also said there is an adequate connection between the tax and the ``benefits, opportunities and protection conferred or afforded'' the airlines by the state. The tax ``need not be assessed only as compensation for services provided,'' it added. The U.S. Supreme Court justices since 1977 has allowed states to tax interstate business if the levy ``is fairly apportioned, does not discriminate against interstate commerce and is fairly related to services which the state provides to the taxpayer.'' Alaska Airlines and USAir argued that Oregon provides no services for overflights. Any monitoring of such flights is done by the federal government, the airlines said. Any help the states might give for emergency landings is compensated by a part of the property tax assessed against schedued landings and departures, they added. Both airlines have flights in and out of Oregon, and they did not challenge the portion of the property tax assessed against those flights. But they said taxing aircraft ``simply because they have flown over that state'' violates the Constitution's due-process guarantees and its protection for interstate commerce. The airlines said Wisconsin and Pennsylvania have similar taxes. The case is Alaska Airlines vs. Oregon, 89-346.

DOC.HEAD: Nebraska Challenge on Farm Support Payments Rejected
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let federal officials place special limits on farm-support payments for married couples. The court, without comment, rejected a challenge to an Agriculture Department regulation that treats a husband and wife as one person when they apply for the payments. The case stemmed from a department rule limiting how much money any person may receive in crop subsidies. A group called Women Involved in Farm Economics, or WIFE, challenged the rule in 1988, when the maximum per-person payment was $50,000. WIFE, founded in Sidney, Neb., in 1976, argued that married couples are barred unfairly from applying for two payments even though other farming partnerships are allowed to apply for multiple payments. The regulation unfairly classified a husband and wife to be one person regardless of their separate interests and responsibilities, the group said. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here upheld the regulation in June, overruling a federal judge who had thrown it out. The appeals court said treating a husband and wife as one person in such cases is reasonable because of their ``financial interdependence.'' ``Married couples, as a group, are more likely than other partners in farming enterprises to share completely in the products of their efforts,'' the appeals court said. The appeals court also noted that Congress now permits a husband and wife to be treated as two people in special circumstances. The amended law says couples may apply for double support payments if each engaged in unrelated farming operations prior to marriage and continue to operate separate farms during their marriage. The case is WIFE vs. Yeutter, 89-366.

DOC.HEAD: Penthouse Publisher's N.J. Casino Suit Killed
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today killed Penthouse magazine publisher Robert Guccione's $400 million lawsuit against the federal government in connection with the FBI's Abscam investigation. The court, without comment, let stand rulings that dismissed Guccione's suit. In Abscam, a highly publicized ``sting'' operation in the late 1970s, FBI agents posed as representatives of phony Arab sheiks looking for investment opportunities. A key figure in the operation was Melvin Weinberg, a con man turned FBI informant and middleman. Guccione said Weinberg promised him that the bogus sheiks would finance an Atlantic City, N.J., casino if Guccione would take part in bribing New Jersey officials to obtain a casino license. The magazine publisher said he refused to go along, and Weinberg then spread rumors that Guccione had financial problems and was connected to organized crime figures. As a result, the suit said, Guccione was unable to secure legitimate financing for a casino from 1979 to 1983. A 1983 Senate report criticized the FBI for its handling of Weinberg. The report said the Guccione episode is ``a chilling reminder of the risks imposed by lax procedures and inadequate supervision of an informant like Weinberg.'' Guccione's suit accused federal officials of negligently supervising Weinberg. The government enjoys broad immunity from being sued, but under the Federal Tort Claim Act has surrendered some of that protection. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last May upheld a judge's ruling that threw out the suit, ruling that the federal law does not permit Guccione to sue. ``The United States is not liable for the intentional (injuries caused by) those carrying out its business, even though (Guccione) alleges a claim of primary negligence on the part of the United States in failing to supervise or otherwise avoid foreseeable risks,'' the appeals court said. The case is Guccione vs. U.S., 89-553.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Revive FBI Agent's Libel Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to revive a FBI agent's multi-million-dollar libel lawsuit over a book about a deadly 1973 confrontation between Indians and federal agents at Wounded Knee, S.D. The court, without comment, let stand rulings that threw out David Price's suit against Peter Matthiessen, author of ``In the Spirit of Crazy Horse,'' and Viking Penguin Inc., the book's publisher. On Feb. 27, 1973, an armed group of Indians with grievances about the federal government's handling of Indian affairs occupied the village of Wounded Knee on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. The FBI, U.S. Marshals Service and Bureau of Indian Affairs police sealed off the village by setting up roadblocks. Before the 71-day standoff ended, two Indians were killed and a deputy marshal was wounded. Two years later, two FBI agents were killed on the reservation. Leonard Peltier, a leader of the American Indian Movement, was convicted and sentenced to life in prison for the two killings. Price, an FBI agent assigned to the Pine Ridge Reservation during much of the 1970s, contended in his suit that the book falsely accused him of corruption and dishonesty for his role in investigating the occupation and shootout. The 1984 suit had sought $25 million in compensatory damages, plus punitive damages, legal fees and court costs. Faced with the suit, the publisher withdrew the book from circulation. A federal judge dismissed the suit in 1988 after ruling that the sued-over statements were expressions of Matthiessen's opinion, and therefore absolutely immune from such legal action. By that time, court records indicate, the defendants had spent over $1 million on the suit. The judge also said Price was a public official and that he had failed to prove the allegedly libelous statements were published with ``actual malice.'' The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal last Aug. 7, agreeing that the published statements about Price are expressed as opinion, not fact. The appeals court said Price had failed ``to persuade us that this is a factual matter capable of the jury's resolution, to show that he could demonstrate its falsity, and to convince us that he could show with clear and convincing evidence that the author had a high degree of awareness of a particular statement's probable falsity.'' The appeals court added: ``That agent Price cannot surmount these obstacles implies no condemnation of him ... In its entirety, `Crazy Horse' focuses more on public institutions and social forces than it does on any public official. The sentiments it expresses are debatable. We favor letting the debate continue.'' In his appeal, Price said the lower courts wrongly portrayed as opinion, and not facts, ``allegations of specific criminal wrongdoing.'' The case is Price vs. Viking Penguin, 89-741.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets Cable TV-Telephone Company Rule Stand in Indiana Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to hear a constitutional challenge to a federal rule banning telephone companies from affiliating with cable television companies in their service area. The justices, without comment, turned away arguments by a small Indiana telephone company that the cross-ownership rule violates its free-speech rights. Government lawyers said the appeal filed by the Northwestern Indiana Telephone Co. (NITCO) should be rejected because the company had failed to raise its free-speech argument with the Federal Communications Commission. NITCO provides telephone service in five communities south of Gary, Ind. The company is owned by Robert and Gerald Mussman; it has been in their family since 1932. The FCC received a complaint in 1983 over NITCO's leasing space on its telephone poles to Northwest Indiana CATV Inc. for cable distribution lines. The cable company is owned by Robert Mussman's son, Rhys. The commission in 1985 ruled that the affiliation between NITCO and the cable company violated the cross-ownership rule in effect since 1970. The commission ordered divestiture of the cable TV facilities in three communities within NITCO's service area. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here upheld the commission's order last April after refusing to rule on NITCO's constitutional challenge because it had not been raised before the commission. Northwest Indiana CATV last July sold the cable systems that were the subject of the commission's divestiture order. The case is Northwestern Indiana Telephone Co. vs. FCC, 89-501.

DOC.HEAD: West German, South African Citizens Kidnapped At Angolan Border
DOC.TEXT: A West German man and his South African girlfriend were kidnapped and taken at gunpoint across the border into Angola while canoeing on Christmas Eve, police and witnesses said today. Axel Puhl, who has lived in the South African-controlled territory of Namibia for 15 years, disappeared into Angola in the area controlled by the U.S.-backed National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA), friends said. He and his girlfriend, Anelise Gevers, were reported missing by workers at a Mission Hospital near the Kavango River when they did not return to their parked vehicles after a canoeing trip. Police said witnesses reported seeing unidentified men firing at the canoes and forcing the two to the Angolan side of the river, where they were taken away at gunpoint. Puhl, 43, works for Phillips Telecommunications, an international company. The West German observer mission in Namibia said it had been notified of the reported abduction and was checking on it.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Appeal of Ohio Chemist Who Sued Texas Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today turned down the appeal of an Ohio biochemist who sued for libel after he was called a ``quack'' and an ``outrageous hoke artist'' for opposing fluoridation of San Antonio's water supply. The justices, without comment, let stand rulings that threw out John Yiamouyiannis' suit against the San Antonio Express-News and columnist Paul Thompson. The rulings also dismissed most of the libel allegations against the Bexar County Medical Society and its spokesman, Dr. Randall Priessig. Yiamouyiannis, a resident of Delaware, Ohio, became involved in the public debate leading to a 1985 referendum on fluoridation in the Texas city. In an Oct. 25 column, Thompson chastised local radio talk show hosts for ``presenting an outrageous hoke artist and imported fearmonger ... as if he had solid credentials.'' ``Any radioman who can't spot the difference between a quack like ... Yiamouyiannis and authorized spokesmen for the medical, dental and research professions of the country ought to be kicked off the air,'' Thompson wrote. The county medical association and Preissig also referred to Yiamouyiannis as a quack, and asserted that he had headed an institution that opposed the pasteurization of milk and vaccines for smallpox and polio. A state judge threw out the libel suit before it reached a jury, and a state appeals court upheld dismissal of most of the allegations. The appeals court said most of the references to Yiamouyiannis ``are assertions of pure opinion,'' and entitled to absolute immunity against libel suits. But the appeals court said the medical association and Preissig could be forced to defend themselves at trial for the statement about the institution Yiamouyiannis was said to have headed. The Texas Supreme Court refused to hear the biochemist's ensuing appeal last Sept. 13. The appeal acted on today sought to reinstate the entire suit. The case is Yiamouyiannis vs. Thompson, 89-673.

DOC.HEAD: Court Will Hear Appeal from Texas of Federal Credit Card Fraud Law
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear a challenge to a federal law aimed at helping victims of crime recover their losses. The justices said they will hear an appeal by a former post office worker in Texas ordered to repay a bank $90,412 he allegedly stole through credit card fraud. The worker pleaded guilty to a single count of credit card fraud specifying only that more than $1,000 had been stolen. Frasiel L. Hughey worked at a post office in San Antonio when he was indicted for mail theft and credit card fraud. He pleaded guilty to one count of running up charges of more than $1,000 on a Mastercard issued by MBank USA to Hershey Godfrey. The government said it had evidence Hughey stole 21 cards issued by MBank and warned him he might be ordered to repay the bank $147,646. Hughey said he should be required to repay only $10,422, the amount he said was charged to Godfrey's card. A federal judge sentenced Hughey to eight years in prison and ordered him to repay $90,412 to MBank. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the restitution order last July. The appeals court gave an expansive intrepretation to the federal Victim and Witness Protection Act. ``At the minimum, the (law) does not limit restitution to the amount specified in an indictment,'' the appeals court said. ``The restitution order (in Hughey's case) had a significant connection with the conviction offense.'' ``One of the principal purposes of the act was to ensure that wrongdoers, to the degree possible, make their victims whole. If restitution were limited to the count of conviction, given the high levels of plea bargaining within our criminal system, in the majority of cases a victim could not be made whole,'' the appeals court said. The appeals court also rejected Hughey's plea that he is too poor to pay. The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court not to disturb the appeals court ruling. The department said limiting the amount of restitution to the amount someone is convicted of stealing would violate Congress's intent to compensate crime victims adequately. The case is Hughey vs. U.S., 89-5691.

DOC.HEAD: Fresh Soviet Troops, Tanks To Leave Hungary This Year
DOC.TEXT: The Red Army will pull out an airborne regiment, two tank battalions and 6,000 troops this year as part of Moscow's unilateral troop withdrawal, a senior Soviet military official said today. The troop cuts, to include also a mechanized infantry regiment, will cover more that 40 military aircraft, 120 tanks, some 180 armored cars and 400 other motorized vehicles, said Col. Gen. Grigory Krivosheyev, Soviet deputy chief of staff. ``The decisive majority of the troops pulled out from Hungary will be demobilized,'' the news agency MTI quoted Krivosheyev as saying. He did not elaborate. The cuts, which started last year, are part of the Soviet army withdrawal plans from Eastern Europe announced by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in December 1988. According to the plan, the Kremlin will remove 50,000 troops stationed in Hungary, Czechoslovakia and East Germany. There are some 52,000 Russian troops stationed in Hungary.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Order Asks U.S., Nicaragua to Investigate Nuns' Deaths
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic order that lost two nuns in a Nicaraguan ambush last week asked today that the deaths be investigated by both the United States and Nicaragua. A statement from the Sisters of St. Agnes urged the two governments ``to investigate fully the circumstances surrounding this tragic incident so that justice can be served.'' Sisters Maureen Courtney, 45, a native of Milwaukee, and Teresa de Jesus Rosales, 24, of Nicaragua were killed in the ambush Jan. 1 in a remote region in eastern Nicaragua. Another nun and a bishop were injured in the attack. The nuns were killed while driving in a white pickup truck marked by yellow crosses. The truck was hit by both a rocket and gunfire before the occupants identified themselves as religious workers. The Nicaraguan government has blamed the attack on U.S.-backed Contra rebels, but a spokesman for the rebels last week denied any involvement. The Fond du Lac-based order's general superior, Sister Jean Steffes, said it was obvious that the loss of innocent lives would continue if there is no resolution of the decade-old civil war in Nicaragua. ``We know that our sisters are being mourned by name, but we grieve for the countless peasants, campesinos and others whose names may not go down in history but who also left loved ones behind,'' the statement said. The group has been serving in Nicaragua since 1945.

DOC.HEAD: Initial Review of Louisiana Higher Education Left to Appeals Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 3rd graf, The justices, to show that stay now lifted.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left it to a federal appeals court to take first crack at deciding whether Louisiana's system of higher education must undergo sweeping changes to help desegregate the state's public colleges and universities. The justices, in a brief order, said they do not yet have the authority to review the case. The order means the case will proceed to the New Orleans-based 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The justices last August blocked any ordered changes, but today's action lifted that postponement. Enforcement of the desegregation plan envisioned by a three-judge federal court could begin unless the 5th Circuit court grants a similar stay. The three-judge court's July ruling would replace four governing boards with a single board over all public higher education in Louisiana, restrict admissions at some universities, limit degree programs most schools can offer and establish a community college system. The ruling also called for the gradual merging of the law schools at Louisiana State University and Southern University, the state's largest predominantly black school. Southern's 13,000 students attend three undergraduate campuses and the law school in Baton Rouge. Of the current four boards, one governs the LSU system, another governs the Southern University system and a third oversees all other schools. Those three boards answer to the State Board of Trustees for Higher Education. ``The present scheme ... has perpetuated illegal segregation in Louisiana's higher education,'' the three-judge court ruled in a case begun in 1974, when Justice Department officials sued in behalf of black students. The four-board system has resulted in violations of a federal anti-discrimination law and the federal Constitution, the three-judge court said. The lower court ordered designation of Louisiana State University as the unified system's flagship school, with the greatest number of graduate and research programs and the strictest admissions requirements. It also called for creation of an intermediate level of four institutions, including Southern, to offer significant doctoral and other graduate programs. Eight other schools, including the predominantly black Grambling State University, would be designated as a third tier and limited to offering undergraduate degrees. Four colleges would become part of the new community college system. Court documents indicate that black enrollment at such historically white schools as LSU, Louisiana Tech, McNeese State, Nicholls State, Northeast Louisiana and Southeastern Louisiana is less than 10 percent while blacks comprise over 99 percent of the enrollments at Southern and Grambling. The three-judge court's ruling was appealed by the Southern University board, Gov. Buddy Roemer's administration and Attorney General William Guste. Roemer and Guste each said his appeal represented the state's ``official'' views in the case, and the governor in December asked the justices to dismiss Guste's appeal. The attorney general's appeal sought to have the three-judge court's ruling thrown out, arguing that ``statistics alone'' on the race of students at each school cannot prove unlawful bias when each school is open to students of any race. The governor's appeal also argued that the three-judge court wrongly ruled that the state was guilty of unlawful bias, but did not attack that portion of the lower court's order requiring one governing board. Roemer has been a champion of a single-board system but has not been able to get the state Legislature to go along with the idea. The Bush administration urged the justices to send the case to the 5th Circuit court and not agree to handle an appeal directly from the three-judge court. Justice Department lawyers argued that the case should have been handled by a lone trial judge and not the special three-judge court. Taking issue with that view, Roemer attorney John N. Kennedy told the justices, ``All of higher education in Louisiana is awaiting final resolution.'' He urged the high court not to send the case to the 5th Circuit court, where any decision is likely to be appealed to the Supreme Court. ``Until this litigation is resolved,'' Kennedy said, ``the operations of Louisiana's colleges and universities remains subject to extraordinary confusion and instability.'' The cases are Louisiana ex rel Guste vs. U.S., 89-556; Southern University Board of Supervisors vs. U.S., 89-557; and Louisiana ex rel Roemer vs. U.S., 89-771.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Shiite Militias Call Brief Truce to Evacuate Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE casualty count, bodies from Amal militia; picks up 8th graf pvs, `Statements by ...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias called a seven-hour truce today to allow the Red Cross to evacuate at least 17 bodies that had been lying in the fields of battle in southern Lebanon. The bodies, wrapped in blankets and plastic bags, belonged to militiamen of the Syrian-backed, mainstream Amal movement, which has been fighting the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God. The cease-fire near three southern villages took place a day after Palestinian guerrillas deployed in southern Lebanon to form a buffer zone to disengage the Shiite militias. But elsewhere in the Iqlim al-Tuffah province, particularly around the villages of Jarjou, Jbaa and Ein Bouswar, Hezbollah and Amal fighters kept up a steady exchange of artillery fire. The 17 victims recovered today raised the overall toll in the 17-day-old inter-Shiite battle to 94 killed and 275 wounded, by police count. The International Committee of the Red Cross dispatched eight ambulances and eight station wagons with medical teams from Beirut to evacuate casualties trapped in the fighting, a Red Cross statement said. It was unclear how many wounded people were evacuated. Statements by the commands of the rival factions in Beirut spoke of dozens of decomposed bodies lying in the fields, in addition to wounded civilians and combatants in urgent need of medical care. Police said both factions withheld fire in the villages of Kfar Hatta, Kfar Milki and Kfar Beit as the Red Cross teams rolled in. About 700 Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas now man a three-mile buffer separating the villages of Kfar Hatta, Kfar Milki and Kfar Beit. That prevents the two sides from launching major ground attacks, but it does not stop them firing artillery shells and rockets over the heads of the Palestinian guerrillas in the buffer. The fighting had raged southeast of the Palestinian refugee camps of Ein el-Hilweh and Mieh Mieh near Sidon, a provincial capital 25 miles south of Beirut. Police has said the guerrillas' intervention was ordered by PLO chief Yasser Arafat to prevent either Shiite faction from gaining territory from which the two camps, Arafat's main power base in Lebanon, can be shelled. Hezbollah's spiritual guide, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, said in an interview published by the conservative Beirut daily newspaper Al-Anwar on Monday that the Shiitte war ``is drawing to an end.'' He did not elaborate. The two Shiite groups for two years have struggled for power within the 1.2 million-strong Shiite community, Lebanon's largest sect.

DOC.HEAD: Man Holds Five Children at Gunpoint
DOC.TEXT: A man who police say has a bullet lodged in his skull from a shooting two months ago was holding five children hostage at gunpoint today in a barricaded apartment, authorities said. The man, whose name was not released, is the father of three of the children, and the other two children are related, police said. Their precise relation was not immediately known. The youngsters range in age from 18 months to 11 years. ``He's assuring us that they're all right,'' said police spokesman Clyde Ross. ``We're taking him at his word at this time.'' Police said that about 10 a.m., nearly 10 hours after the incident began, the man began pushing furniture in front of the door of the apartment in an apparent attempt to barricade himself and the children inside. As he did so, armed SWAT team members with their guns drawn surrounded the block of apartments where the downstairs unit is located. Authorities also said they believe he had slapped at least one of the children, but there was no indication the child was badly hurt. The 30-year-old man apparently was shot about two months ago, and the bullet never was removed from his skull, officials said. Police have talked on the telephone with the man, who was said to be armed with a shotgun, but communication has been sporadic and the man reportedly hung up on police at one point. Officers were called to the west San Antonio apartment complex shortly after midnight following a report that a man was fighting with his wife. The woman escaped the apartment and was treated for facial abrasions at Methodist Hospital, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Latvian Exile's Trial to Start Jan. 18
DOC.TEXT: An alleged Nazi war criminal who fled the United States to avoid possible deportation to the Soviet Union will go on trial in West Germany later this month, authorities said today. Boleslav Maikovskis, 86, will go on trial Jan. 18 charged with murder and complicity in the shooting deaths of 170 residents of a Latvian village during World War II, according to a statement by the state court in Muenster. He also was accused of ordering the hanging of a Jewish resident in the Latvian village of Audrine, the statement said. Maikovskis, a former resident of Mineola, N.Y., fled the United States in 1987. He was facing U.S. deportation proceedings for war crimes allegedly committed when he served as a policeman in Latvia during World War II. The Soviet Union in 1965 sentenced Maikovskis to death in absentia for his alleged role in burning down a village and helping kill more than 130 men, women and children in Audrine. The deaths occurred while Maikovskis allegedly was acting as commander of a pro-Nazi police force in the village during World War II. The United States began deporttaion proceedings against Maikovskis in 1976, but they were delayed by several appeals. His latest appeal was denied by the U.S. Supreme Court in 1986, and he fled to West Germany in 1987. Maikovskis applied for asylum in West Germany, but was arrested in his home in Muenster, near the border with the Netherlands, in October 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Rule on Tax Withholding in Pennsylvania Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to settle a conflict over the government's power to keep taxes withheld from businesses about to declare bankruptcy. The court said it will hear an appeal by the trustee of bankrupt American International Airways seeking to recover $700,000 in taxes paid to the Internal Revenue Service. The airline company had become delinquent by the spring of 1984 in withholding Social Security and income taxes from employee wages and excise taxes collected from passengers. The IRS then ordered the airline to file monthly, instead of quarterly, tax returns and open a special bank account to handle the tax deposits. American International filed for bankruptcy on July 19, 1984, to try and reorganize the business and pay off some of the money owed creditors. That effort failed and three months later a trustee was appointed to liquidate the company. The trustee sought to recover $1.6 million in taxes paid to the IRS in the months leading up to the liquidation. A bankruptcy judge in Pennsylvania permitted the trustee to recover $700,000 from the government and the IRS appealed to the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals based in Philadelphia. The appeals court ruled last June that the trustee may not recover the $700,000. The balance collected by the IRS was not at issue in the decision. The appeals court said that under federal law the withheld taxes must be considered placed in a special fund held in trust for the IRS and are not part of the company's property protected by the bankruptcy proceedings. The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court to take the case even though the government's position was upheld by the 3rd Circuit court. The department said another federal appeals court has issued a conflicting ruling and the high court should resolve the split. The case is Begier vs. IRS, 89-393.

DOC.HEAD: Government Debating New U.S. Drug Effort
DOC.TEXT: A bitter debate has erupted within President Virgilio Barco's government over a beefed-up U.S. naval force in the Caribbean, with Barco favoring the operation, a newspaper reported today. Two opposition parties today protested the increase in U.S. air and sea patrols in international waters in the Caribbean. The United States said the operation is an attempt to deter drug smugglers. On Sunday, Barco's foreign minister, Julio Londono Paredes, reportedly said Colombia rejects any attempt to search Colombian ships, even in international waters. Some news reports, based upon Londono's comments, interpreted that to mean that Barco himself was angry with the United States and that there was a rift between Washington and the Barco government. Apparently the rift is within the Colombian government itself, with the foreign minister and Barco at odds, a Bogota daily with access to Barco advisers said today. Barco accepts the U.S. action and is at odds with his foreign minister, La Prensa said. Londono has never been pro-American on international issues, it said. The falling out between Londono and Barco started with the U.S. invasion of Panama on Dec. 20, the newspaper said. The paper indicated that Barco supported the invasion and Londono was opposed. La Prensa is owned by Juan Carlos Pastrana, the son of former president Misael Pastrana. The daily has repeatedly shown that it has reliable sources within the Barco government. Another Bogota newspaper, El Tiempo, on Sunday printed what it said was a government statement saying Colombia would refuse to take part in the U.S. anti-drug program. A government spokesman today said no such statement existed. In Washington on Sunday, Bush administration officials acknowledged ``some difficulties'' with Colombian authorities over their plans to deploy warships in the Caribbean in a new campaign against drug traffickers. The national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft blamed the problems on ``some premature and ... probably inaccurate leaks'' about U.S. intentions. The Barco administration has since August been engaged in a bloody war with cocaine barons. The government's war with traffickers, while seen as courageous by other countries, has received little support within Colombia. The opposition Conservative Party and the leftist Patriotic Union Party today criticized the U.S. action. The U.S. Embassy in Bogota said Saturday the move to step up air and sea patrols would be carried out ``far from the Colombian coast.'' The embassy announcement came amid persistent radio reports in Colombia that a United States naval force was planning to enter the Latin American country's territorial waters to set up a blockade off its coast. The Bush administration has not said how many ships and aircraft will participate in the drug interdicition operation off the Colombian coast, though the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy will reportedly be involved. The administration has not given the date on which the operations are to begin. The JFK and an accompanying guided missile cruiser, the USS Virginia, left Norfolk, Va., on Thursday for what the Pentagon said were routine training exercises in the Atlantic. An aircraft carrier normally has eight or 12 smaller ships as part of its battle group, along with an aircraft wing composed of about 3,000 men and dozens of observation and tracking planes. It is estimated that drug cartels in Colombia are responsible for processing and smuggling 80 percent of the cocaine sold on U.S. streets. Soon after Barco intensified his government's struggle against drug traffickers on Aug. 18, the United States pledged $65 million in military aid to help in the fight. U.S. officials have said there are between 50 and 100 U.S. military personnel in the country to help train Colombian security forces to use the donated equipment. Months ago, the Barco administration ruled out the use of U.S. military forces to fight drug traffickers within Colombia's borders.

DOC.HEAD: Aunt Bee Leaves Estate To Pinehurst Hospital, Public TV
DOC.TEXT: The woman who portrayed the kindly Aunt Bee on television's ``The Andy Griffith Show'' left her house to the town hospital and its contents to a center for public television, an attorney said. ``Anybody who reads the will can see that she remembered those who remembered her at the last moments,'' attorney Sam Williams said about how Frances Bavier divided her $700,000 estate. The huge brick-and-stone house where Ms. Bavier died in her sleep was bequeathed to Moore Memorial Hospital in Pinehurst, where the actress was treated several times. Ms. Bavier was admitted to two or three times to the hospital, most recently around last August for an undisclosed ailment, Williams said. The contents of the house, where Ms. Bavier died at 86 on Dec. 6, were donated to the University of North Carolina Center for Public Television, he said. The garage contains her green 1966 Studebaker, which hasn't been driven since 1983. Ms. Bavier shared her home with 15 cats. Her friends placed all the animals in private homes, except for a black one that has been too quick to catch. Ms. Bavier has lived in the southern North Carolina home since 1972. It showcased her belongings, including her cherished Emmy Award, her collection of leather-bound books and photograph albums. The pictures include photographs of a young Ron Howard from his days as Aunt Bee's charge, Opie.

DOC.HEAD: Billy Carter Autobiography Says Grand Jury Probes Bankrupted Him
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigations of Billy Carter's activities destroyed him financially, the ``first brother'' of former President Jimmy Carter said in a book he wrote before his death in 1988. Grand juries investigated Billy Carter's role in the family peanut warehouse and whether the business helped bankroll Jimmy Carter's presidential campaign. The Senate held hearings into Billy Carter's involvement with a deal between the Libyan government and an American oil company. And the former president's younger brother also got into trouble with the Internal Revenue Service. Carter wrote that testifying and defending himself was a full-time job for two years, required four law firms and ``cost me a small fortune.'' The hearings ``wiped me out financially,'' Carter wrote in ``Billy,'' published by Edgehill Publications, a subsidiary of Edgehill Newport, a center for the treatment of alcoholism and drug abuse at Newport, R.I. The book is in limited national distribution in hard cover and paperback. Carter had nearly completed the book before he died of pancreatic cancer in September 1988. Writer Ken Estes and Sybil Carter, Billy's wife of 33 years and co-author of the book, completed the final chapter. In part, the book is an effort to ``set the record straight'' and a way for Carter to help others battling alcoholism, Mrs. Carter said in an interview with The Albany Herald. ``He never ceased to be amazed that people would come up or send letters that said: `I quit drinking because of you.' It really touched him.'' People identified with Billy because he said what he thought, Mrs. Carter said. Billy Carter wrote of his years of high jinks during his brother's presidency, but the book also covers his childhood, his battle with alcoholism and his last days fighting cancer. He also wrote of his closeness to his mother, ``Miss Lillian'' Carter, and how they both enjoyed a good argument. Carter also credited his mother, who died in 1983, for one of his best-known quotes. According to Carter, his mother first turned the phrase: ``I've got a son who thinks he can be president; a daughter (Ruth) who is a faith-healer; another daughter (Gloria) who rides around on motorcycles; and another son who drinks beer all the time. If I had known they would turn out the way they have, I would have remained a virgin.'' Her son's widely publicized version was: ``I've got a mother who joined the Peace Corps at 68; a brother who wants to be president; a sister who is a holy-roller preacher; and another sister who rides around on motorcycles. I'm the only sane one in the family.'' He wrote: ``This is my last chance to give Mama proper credit.''

DOC.HEAD: Texas Lawyers Asked to be Nicer
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers and judges concede their profession probably won't set any standards for social graces, but they're giving good manners a shot nevertheless. A new Lawyer's Creed _ the first such statewide code in the nation _ was recently approved by the Texas Supreme Court and the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals. It asks the state's 52,000 lawyers for kinder litigation. No more obnoxiousness. No more tit-for-tat unprofessional behavior. No more stalling tactics. And no ``allusions to personal peculiarities or idiosyncrasies of opposing counsel'' will be allowed, according to the creed. Lawyers and judges say the let's-be-civil creed is overdue. ``It's kind of like dieting,'' Texas Supreme Court Justice Eugene Cook said. ``It's a battle that we can win, but it's not going to be done overnight.'' Cook said the creed was initiated by Dallas and Houston legal associations to fight bad behavior and needlessly aggressive courtroom tactics. The offending behavior _ from rudeness to engaging in lengthy procedural delays to even resorting to fistfights _ has been clogging court schedules and hampering disposition of cases. Cook said some lawyers try to reschedule proceedings on dates most likely to bother an opponent. ``If they know of a time that will be inconvenient _ say the day your wife is having a baby or the week you've been planning all year for a vacation _ that's when they'll schedule it,'' he said. ``Some people think that it's the way to practice law, to be rude and abusive and try to intimidate the other side.'' He said the problems have become increasingly common in the last five years. U.S. District Judge A. Joe Fish said part of the problem may be the increase of lawyers in the state's largest cities. ``I think the Rambo tactics arise out of the feeling that `I'm never going to see the other lawyer again,''' he said. Dallas Bar Association president Al Ellis said financial woes also have increased courtroom problems. ``As the law firms have gotten bigger and the economy has gone down, there's been a lot of pressure on younger and middle-management lawyers to produce, and some have responded with this kind of behavior,'' he said. The 34-part Lawyer's Creed, developed by a committee with representatives from 18 legal associations, relies on voluntary compliance and includes no specific penalties. The creed includes requirements of civility toward peers and judges and a ban on ``antagonistic or obnoxious behavior.'' ``Some judges have copies of the creed pasted to their courthouse doors,'' Cook said. ``They tell the lawyers, go outside and read it and don't come back in until they learn how to act accordingly.''

DOC.HEAD: Hippo Kills Man Trying to Cross Border
DOC.TEXT: A man trying to cross illegally into Zimbabwe from Zambia at night was crushed to death by a rogue hippopotamus, and his son was seriously injured by the beast, police said Monday. The two-ton hippo chased Gibson Mtonga and his son, Chaipa, on Saturday night as they were trying to cross the border near Victoria Falls, said police spokesman Alfred Mulopa. Chaipa, 13, told police he was hurled several yards by the animal, which then killed his father. Mulopa said they were turned back by Zimbabwean immigration authorities earlier Saturday but apparently tried to cross the border after dark. The Victoria Falls border post closes at night _ the time hippos usually leave the water to forage on land.

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong Arrest in California Smuggling Case
DOC.TEXT: Police said Monday they have arrested a man in Hong Kong in connection with the seizure of 143 pounds of heroin concealed in cans of Chinese fruit imported to Los Angeles. The man was arrested Saturday after U.S. authorities discovered the high-grade heroin hidden in 192 cans of litchis in syrup found in Los Angeles last month, police said. The drugs would have sold for about $64 million in the United States, the statement said. Officers of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency and U.S. Customs also arrested two men _ a Chinese and a Vietnamese _ in Alhambra, Calif., on Saturday in connection with the drug bust, the statement said. The man in Hong Kong was arrested after police raided sites in the colony and uncovered a drug packaging center in an industrial building, police said. No names were released and investigations into the case were continuing.

DOC.HEAD: Citizens Seek Halt to Golf Course Construction
DOC.TEXT: A citizens' group has asked the government to stop building a golf course near Tokyo unless it can show that weed killers and other chemicals used on the course won't pollute their water, an official said Monday. It was the first time such a request had been made to the Environmental Disputes Coordination Commission, set up in 1972 to settle pollution issues by arbitration, said Takashi Tachi of the prime minister's office. Suzoko Ishizaki, one of the leaders of the group, said weed killers and other chemicals to be used on the Seibu Hanno Country Club course would contaminate water supplies in the city of Hanno. Country club official Tatsuya Hasunuma said the 345-acre course had been approved in June after public hearings and environmental assessment by the Saitama prefectural government, but the club is ready to take any remedial measures that the government suggests. Tachi said the coordination commission would try to settle the dispute through negotiations. The golf course, about 30 miles northwest of Tokyo, is to be completed by 1992 at an estimated $105 million, Hasunuma said. Hanno already has six golf courses, with a seventh under construction. As of February 1989, Japan had 1,640 golf courses, and more than 15 million of the nation's 120 million people play golf.

DOC.HEAD: Clouds Hold Off Shuttle Launch Until Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: NASA conducted a stop-and-go countdown and waited until the last possible minute Monday before it knuckled under to clouds and scrubbed the launch of the space shuttle Columbia for 24 hours. ``Nice try,'' said launch director Bob Sieck. The launch was rescheduled for 7:35 a.m. Tuesday. Air Force weather officers had bet 80-20 against weather permitting a launch Monday. But they said chances were 70-30 that conditions would be favorable Tuesday with a potential for low clouds and fog. Columbia, with a five-member crew, is scheduled to spend 10 days in space to launch a Navy communications satellite and to retrieve a bus-size scientific satellite that will crash to Earth in March if the rescue fails. Despite Monday's rotten odds, NASA officials decided to go through the complex launch routine on the slim chance of finding a hole in the clouds and also to exercise the refurbished facilities on launch pad 39A, which had not been used in four years. In fact, the count was interrupted once while six troubleshooters checked a potential pressure problem with a valve system that sprays the launch pad with 300,000 gallons of water just before liftoff. The water absorbs the sound from the engines, preventing it from bouncing back into the engines and causing damage. The technicians determined that a zero pressure reading was false and that the system was OK. NASA estimates that a launch abort on a weekday costs an extra $624,000 at the Kennedy Space Center alone, including $377,000 in lost fuel. There are additional costs at other NASA sites around the world. The cost of a single shuttle launch is estimated between $250 million and $300 million. Commander Dan Brandenstein and his crew had been strapped into their flight seats for nearly four hours while weather reports teetered between go and no-go. Finally, mission control in Houston radioed: ``We're not going to make it.'' Over the pad, the sky was fairly clear. But a 30-mile-wide bank of clouds approaching from the west at 6,000 feet would have made an emergency return difficult for Brandenstein, who would have to land the unpowered space ship on a concrete runway near the launch pad. It was the fourth postponement for this particular mission, but it was only the first time that astronauts were on board, suited up and ready to go into space. The mission is to be the first of 10 for 1990, the most for one year since the Challenger explosion four years ago. During their flight, the astronauts first are to deploy a Navy communications satellite. Then, they are to chase, capture and bring home a satellite called the Long Duration Exposure Facility or LDEF. The satellite, essentially a 12-sided frame, is packed with 57 experiments, many testing the ddurability of various materials exposed to space. The satellite has spent nearly six years in orbit and, if it isn't retrieved, trackers estimate atmospheric drag will make it fall out of orbit and burn up about March 9, its experiments lost forever.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Removes Bodies From South Lebanon Battlefield
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias stopped their war long enough Monday for the Red Cross to remove 17 bodies from the battlefield in the villages and apple orchards south of Sidon. The bodies, wrapped in blankets and plastic bags, were of fighters from Amal, a mainstream militia supported by Syria. Amal and and Hezbollah, a fundamentalist group loyal to Iran, have been fighting since Dec. 23 for supremacy among the 1.2 million Shiites in Lebanon, the nation's largest sect. A terrible stench filled the air as bodies were handed over by Red Cross teams to Amal militiamen who returned them to their families.
