Police say 94 people have been killed and 275 wounded in the 17 days of fighting in Iqlim al-Tuffah, the Apple Province. Amal and Hezbollah have battled intermittently sice May 1987 and hundreds of people have been killed. Palestinian guerrillas moved into a buffer zone between the two sides Monday and a seven-hour truce applied in most villages. Iranian envoy Mohammad Ali Besharati, who is trying to mediate a settlement, visited Syria and drove to Lebanon overnight for talks with Shiite leaders. A similar mission last week by Besharati, a deputy foreign minister, failed to stop the fighting. On Monday, the International Committee of the Red Cross sent eight ambulances and eight station wagons with medical teams to evacuate dead and wounded, a Red Cross statement said. Statements from the rival militias issued in Beirut spoke of dozens of bodies in the orchards of Iqlim al-Tuffah, and of wounded civilians and combatants in urgent need of medical care. Both factions withheld fire Monday in Kfar Hatta, Kfar Milki and Kfar Beit as the Red Cross teams rolled in, but artillery fire continued in Jarjou, Jbaa and Ein Bouswar, police said. No casualties were reported. About 700 Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas man a buffer line slightly more than a mile long that separates Kfar Hatta, Kfar Milki and Kfar Beit. It prevents the two sides from launching major ground assaults, but cannot stop artillery and rocket fire. The battleground is ner Ein el-Hilweh and Mieh Mieh, Palestinian refugee camps on the outskirts of Sidon, the ancient port 25 miles south of Beirut. Police say PLO chief Yasser Arafat apparently ordered the intervention to prevent either Shiite faction from gaining territory from to shell the camps, which form his main power base in Lebanon. Hezbollah's spiritual guide, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, said in an interview published Monday by Al-Anwar, a conservative Beirut daily: ``The Apple Province war is drawing to an end. The curtain will be lowered soon on that conflict.'' He gave no details. At his residence in Moslem west Beirut, President Elias Hrawi received representatives of about 40 nations Monday in a traditional audience marking the new year. ``I have taken over a state where man has been almost totally destroyed'' by 14 years of civil war, Hrawi told the diplomats. ``My people want deliverance.'' He said his government was determined to prevent Lebanon's ``disintegration on the eve of a new historic era of international relations based on openness,'' a reference to superpower detente. Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic said political reforms designed to bring peace between Christians and Moslems soon would be introduced despite oppositon by Gen. Michel Aoun, the rebellious Christian commander. The general opposes what he describes as Syria's dominant role in most of Lebanon. Aoun commands 20,000 soldiers in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave north and east of Beirut, where 1 million Christians live, and refuses to turn over the presidential palace in Baabda, a Christian suburb. Among those attending the meeting with Hrawi on Monday was Spanish Archbishop Pablo Puente, the papal nuncio in Lebanon. At the Vatican, spokesman Joaquin Navarro said Puente would work for a ``sincere and loyal dialogue among all parties, taking into account above all those in a weak position who fear for the future of themselves and the country.''

DOC.HEAD: Nebraska Gov Urges Expelling College Students Convicted of Drug Offenses
DOC.TEXT: Students at public colleges and universities should be kicked out of school for conviction of any drug offense, Gov. Kay Orr proposed today. The Orr anti-drug plan, proposed in her annual state of the state message, also would require students who enter public higher education to certify they will be drug free before they can enroll or receive state student aid. They would lose the aid and be expelled from school for any drug conviction, including misdemeanors, and could re-enter school only after completing a drug rehabilitation program. ``I want to make it crystal clear,'' said Mrs. Orr, a Republican who is running for re-election this year. ``Nebraska intends to rid inself of this evil which is corrupting our youth and spawning crime in our streets. ... Drug abuse is a plague threatening every single family.'' Other measures the governor will press in the Legislature include suspension of driver's licenses for those convicted of drug offenses; creation of a separate ``corruption of minors'' felony for those selling drugs to those under 18 or hiring them to work in a drug operation; and boosting the punichment for first-time possession of marijuana, which now carries just a $100 fine, to up to a $500 fine and three months in jail. Gary Rex, an aide to the governor, indicated the administration realized that some of the proposals, if enacted, might be challenged in court on constitutional grouns. Responding to questions, he also acknowledged that people convicted of other felonies, including murder, could still attend a public college, university or technical community college _ but someone convicted of a misdemeanor marijuana charge would be expelled.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Hurt in Student Clashes
DOC.TEXT: Students from two opposition parties battled each other with firebombs, guns and hockey sticks on three campuses, and at least 30 people were wounded, police said Monday. Students in Debendra College near Dhaka burned and damaged about a dozen dormitory rooms Sunday, injuring 19 residents, police said. Clashes also took place Sunday at Mohan Chand College and Government College in Sylhet, 120 miles northeast of Dhaka, police said. Sangbad, a Bengali-language newspaper, said 11 students were injured in Sylhet. All three schools were closed until further notice. The fights were between supporters of the Awami League and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, officials said. Both parties oppose the government of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, but their followers often clash with each other. Sangbad said the fighting began when the groups started simultaneous marches and wanted to hold meetings at the same site.

DOC.HEAD: World's Oldest Twins In Poor Health
DOC.TEXT: Any celebration marking the 106th birthday of the world's oldest living twins will be subdued Saturday because both are ill, one in critical condition at their nursing home. Allie Hill and Maggie Lambeth, born Jan. 13, 1884, are at Mountain Vista Health Park, which for three years has held rousing birthday parties for the women. Earlier parties attracted political bigwigs, friends and many of the 192 direct descendants of the identical twins. ``There'll not be a big celebration because of their medical condition,'' nursing home Administrator Kathy McDonald said last week. ``Let's face it, this is a miracle almost _ at 106 their condition has been better than you can expect.'' The sisters' longevity is documented in the 1990 Guinness Book of World Records, which says the chance of identical twins both reaching the age of 100 is said to be one in 50 million. One set of twins, Eli and John Phipps, born in 1803, both reached the age of 108, Guinness says. Mrs. Hill, who is in critical but stable condition, has been ill since Dec. 20, when she suffered what may have been a stroke, according to family members. Her sister is confined to her room a few doors down the hall. ``Things are not quite as well as they were last year. Since she's been sick, I think all of her grandchildren have been here to visit,'' said Mrs. Hill's daughter, Bertha Hoover of Gastonia. Mrs. Lambeth's daughter, Minnie Anderson of Asheboro, said her mother has not been well for most of the past year, and a nurse attributed her poor health mostly to her age. ``She's doing pretty good, as well as could be expected for her age,'' Mrs. Anderson said. ``They've lived longer than most people I know. I've enjoyed it.'' However, Mrs. Anderson, 76, said she does not wish to duplicate her mother's long life. ``I don't want to live that long. But I'll have to live as long as the good Lord lets me,'' she said. The twins have had more than three parties during three years of celebrity that has attracted worldwide attention. In March 1987, two months after the pair were feted on their 103rd birthday, a Japanese television crew footed the bill to stage a re-enactment of the occasion for airing on an Oriental version of ``That's Incredible.'' The sisters have received birthday greetings from Presidents Reagan and Bush. Last year, more than 500 birthday cards arrived. The twins were born to John and Jane Cody Grubb on a farm in Cid, about 10 miles from here. They grew up, married and raised families in the community of their birth. They lived no more than a couple of miles apart all their lives. At 20, Allie married James M. Hill, who died in 1955. They had 11 children, nine of whom are living. During the past year, Rosa Garner, 84, her oldest daughter, has become a fellow resident at Mountain Vista. Mrs. Hill has 30 grandchildren, 59 great-grandchildren and 21 great-great grandchildren. Maggie married David Elzie Lambeth when she was 21. He died in 1971. They had nine children, of whom six are living. There are 18 grandchildren, 31 great-grandchildren and 13 great-great grandchildren. The twins get plenty of company. ``Seven days a week they have visitors,'' Ms. Buie said. ``I doubt they've missed a day in a year.''

DOC.HEAD: Defendants Arraigned in Atlantic City Corruption Trial
DOC.TEXT: Eleven people, including three Atlantic City councilmen, pleaded innocent Monday to charges they sold or bought influence in the casino resort. Among those entering pleas in what prosecutors have called a ``city for sale'' scandal were Council President Walter E. Collette, 61, and Councilmen Gene Dorn, 47, and Arnold Orsatti Jr., 46. None of the defendants said anything during arraignment. Superior Court Judges Manuel Greenberg and Robert Neustadter told the defendants and their attorneys not to discuss the case publicly. Greenberg said all defense motions must be filed by April 1. Edwin J. Jacobs Jr., attorney for Collette, said defense attorneys need the time to examine the more than 300 tapes made of the defendants by Albert Black, a state informant. The city officials were arrested along with Mayor James L. Usry on July 27 in a sting operation that alleged widespread corruption in City Hall. Usry and three others were named Jan. 3 in separate indictments, and their arraignments are scheduled later this month, said Deputy Attorney General David Brody. Usry was charged with accepting $6,500 in bribes. Collette, Dorn, Orsatti and zoning board Chairman Kaleem Shabazz, 52, are named with five other people on charges of conspiring to use the City Council and zoning board to obtain money and benefits as part of a racketeering enterprise. The probe began in late 1988 when Black, who manages a local security agency, sought to refurbish a gas station and was allegedly told he would have to make payoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Bishops Gather for First Time in 40 Years
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Romania's Roman Catholic bishops gathered last week for the first time since 1948 to discuss ways of rebuilding the church after 40 years of Communist suppression, an Italian church official said Monday. Eleven bishops met Jan. 3-4 in Alba Julia to examine the new prospects for the church following the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu's hard-line regime, according to the director of the Italian Catholic relief agency Caritas. Monsignor Giuseppe Pasini, who just returned from Romania, said the meeting was attended by Archbishop Francesco Colasuonno, Pope John Paul II's special envoy for Eastern Europe. Colasuonno met with the pope Monday, the Vatican said without elaborating. Pasini said there are ``well-founded hopes'' the Vatican and Romania can re-establish diplomatic relations, which were broken in 1950 when the papal nuncio was expelled from Bucharest. He said the Romanian bishops agreed on the need to re-establish religious congregations, form a national bishops' conference and obtain full freedom to exercise their pastoral duties. Pasini said there are an estimated 2.3 million Catholics in Romania _ about 10 percent of the population. They include 1.45 million Latin rite Catholics, of whom 1 million are from the Hungarian minority and 150,000 are German-speaking. But Pasini said those most urgently in need of help are the pastors and followers of the Eastern or Byzantine rite Catholic church, which was suppressed in 1948 and forcibly incorporated into the Orthodox church. Their 1,800 churches were confiscated and bishops and priests who refused to accept the merger were jailed, Pasini said. The number of Eastern rite Catholics totaled 1.8 million in 1948, but today's figure is not known because the faithful have been living an underground existence, he said. Five Eastern rite bishops attended last week's meeting. ``The most shocking thing that came out of the meeting is the state of poverty and abandon in which the Eastern rite Catholics live,'' Pasini said. Last week, the new Romanian leadership abolished two 40-year-old decrees that suppressed the Byzantine rite church. Pasini said the Latin Rite church also suffered under Ceausescu's regime, with religious freedom severely restricted, dioceses reduced from six to two, ordination of priests limited to six a year and homes of clergy bugged by the secret police.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Wood Chipper Trial, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0485,0466
DOC.HEAD: Man in Wood Chipper Case Gets 50 Years for Killing Wife
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with sentencing, sister's comments, new trial request denied. ADDS byline. EDITS to trim. Note contents of 13th graf, `Police found...'.
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of killing his wife and disposing of her body by using a wood chipper was sentenced today to 50 years in prison. Richard Crafts, a former airline pilot, was sentenced after Superior Court Judge Martin L. Nigro rejected a defense motion for a new trial. Crafts told the judge that he had been wrongly portrayed as a cold-blooded killer, but didn't address the issue of whether he had killed his wife. ``A great deal has been said about my apparent lack of emotion _ `He has ice water in his veins,''' Crafts said during brief remarks before he was sentenced. ``I have feelings like everyone else.'' Crafts, 52, was convicted of killing 39-year-old Helle Crafts, a Danish-born flight attendant, on Nov. 18 or 19, 1986, at their Newtown home. Prosecutors said he cut the body with a chain saw and fed parts through a wood chipper on a bridge between Newtown and Southbury. He could have been sentenced to 25 years to life in prison for his murder conviction. Craft's sister, Karen Rodgers, who has custody of the couple's three young children, urged Nigro to impose the maximum sentence. ``I am concerned that Mr. Crafts has not publicly nor privately demonstrated any remorse for the murder of his wife,'' Rodgers said. ``I believe he has paid lip service only to the concerns of his children.'' The judge rejected a defense motion to set aside the conviction and order a new trial, saying there was no evidence that the case had been tainted by tape recording by state police. The Hartford Courant reported in November that Connecticut State Police routinely tape-recorded telephone conversations at state police barracks, including calls between suspects and lawyers. The newspaper based its report on disclosures made during an unrelated trial. Recording calls between lawyers and clients is forbidden under federal law. Farver said he had no direct evidence that state police illegally taped any telephone conversations with Crafts, and acknowledged such an argument traditionally would be raised after sentencing. But he said he wanted to formally raise the issue before sentencing, and would reintroduce the argument on appeal. Police found body parts, including a fingernail and human tissue, on the banks of the Housatonic River. The prosecution's case also hinged on the testimony of witnesses who said they saw a man with a wood chipper on the bridge Nov. 20. Crafts has been held at the Bridgeport Community Correctional Center.

DOC.HEAD: Internal Government Debate Over U.S. Naval Presence
DOC.TEXT: An argument apparently has begun in the government over increased U.S. naval activity in the Caribbean against drug traffickers, which President Virgilio Barco is said to favor. The United States has said it is increasing air and sea patrols in international waters, and protests came Monday from the opposition Conservatives and leftist Patriotic Union Party in Colombia. Protests were expected because Barco's 5-month-old confrontation with the Colombian cocaine barons, seen as courageous in other countries, has received relatively little support at home. Confusion over Colombia's position on the U.S. action resulted from a statement Sunday by Foreign Minister Julio Londono Paredes that the government rejects any attempt to search Colombian ships. Some international news reports, based on Londono's comments, interpreted that to mean Barco was angry with the United States. La Prensa, a Bogota daily with access to presidential advisers, said Monday the problem appears to be within the Colombian government and stems from a dispute between Barco and his foreign minister. Barco has said nothing so far and his office has issued no statements. A diplomat with the U.S. Embassy told The Associated Press on Monday that Barco had not sent a protest note or objected in any other way, officially or unofficially, to the increase of Caribbean patrols. The official asked to remain anonymous so he would not become a target of the cocaine gangs. According to La Prensa, the president accepts the U.S. action and Londono never has been pro-American on an international issue. The falling out began with the U.S. invasion of Panama, La Prensa said. It suggested Barco supported the invasion and his foreign minister was opposed. Juan Carlos Pastrana, son of former President Misael Pastrana, owns La Prensa. The paper has been aggressive in reporting attempts by lawyers for the drug lords to negotiate a truce in the war on traffickers that began in August. Londono arrived home from a vacation Sunday, and said in response to reporters' questions at the airport: ``The Colombian government does not accept, nor will it ever accept, any type of interference with ships carrying the Colombian flag on the high seas. ``Any type of interference on the high seas would need the authorization of the Colombian government, especially of the Ministry of Defense.'' When Barco's office was asked if that was the official Colombian position and whether Barco was upset about not being told in advance that a U.S. task force would sail into the Caribbean, spokesman Julio Carlos Gonzalez said Barco had no official comment. Londono said: ``It just isn't possible to suppose that a country like the United States, which has the most sophisticated methods available for intercepting and controlling ships and planes entering its own territory, should have to go into international waters to carry out what it should be doing in its own territory.'' U.S. efforts to intercept drugs in its own territory obviously have failed, he said. Adding to the confusion about Colombia's official positiion was a report Sunday by the Bogota daily El Tiempo that Barco's office issued a statement saying Colombia would not contribute warships to the U.S. effort in the Caribbean. Gonzalez, the Barco spokesman, said the El Tiempo story was not based on any Barco statement because none had been issued. A U.S. Embassy statement last week said the Navy patrols were merely an exercise in increased vigilance, not a new policy, and would take place in international waters. If Colombia does not join the patrols, one reason might be lack of equipment and manpower. Its navy has three corvettes, which are smaller than destroyers; a submarine that is under repair, and a variety of patrol boats. The Colombian navy's main tasks are fighting drug traffickers and five leftist guerrilla groups, which means patrolling thousands of miles of Pacific and Caribbean coastline. It has intercepted several boats that were smuggling guns to guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: Justices Will Consider Governors' Powers over National Guard Units
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court, reviving a controversy from the 1988 presidential campaign, said Monday it will referee a dispute over a governor's power to withhold National Guard troops from peacetime training in Central America. The justices agreed to hear an appeal by Minnesota officials contesting the federal government's authority to override a governor's objection and send members of a state's National Guard on foreign training missions. The court, which last April rejected a similar appeal by Massachusetts officials, is expected to announce a ruling in the Minnesota case by July. The matter became an issue in the 1988 presidential campaign when Democratic candidate Michael Dukakis, the Massachusetts governor, denounced the Reagan administration for what he called a ``failed and illegal'' policy of supporting the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. He said sending National Guard troops to the region was an attempt to intimidate Nicaragua. The Justice Department described Dukakis' position as ``a dagger aimed at the heart of national defense.'' By contrast, Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota has said he considers the issue one of states' rights and has not been critical of Reagan or Bush administration foreign policy. Perpich joined other Minnesota officials in appealing to the Supreme Court in Monday's case. Twelve members of a Minnesota National Guard public relations unit were in Panama on a training mission last month when U.S. forces invaded there. The Minnesota residents returned to the United States a day after the invasion began Dec. 20. Perpich did not try to prevent the troops from training in Panama. ``Now that the Supreme Court has decided to hear it, ... we've got a good legal footing for that appeal,'' he said Monday. The focus of the controversy is a 1986 federal law known as the Montgomery Amendment, which limits the power of governors to withhold their consent to federal deployment of National Guard units. The amendment was enacted after several governors said they opposed the Reagan administration's Central American policy and did not want National Guard troops from their states assigned to training missions in that region. The amendment prohibits any governor from withholding consent to a National Guard unit's active duty outside the country because of an objection to the location, purpose or schedule of the duty. There has been dual control over the National Guard since Congress made it a component of the Army in 1933. Anyone joining the National Guard enrolls simultaneously in a state militia organization and a reserve component of the national armed forces. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in June that the Montgomery Amendment is constitutional and rejected arguments by Minnesota officials. The appeals court said the federal government's authority to provide for national defense is primary, and the states' power to organize militias ``cannot constrain Congress' authority to train the guard as it sees fit.'' The Bush administration said Minnesota's position is contradictory. Justice Department lawyers said that under the state's view Congress could require National Guard troops ``to fight a war abroad ... but would lack the authority to prepare and train them abroad for such an eventuality.'' According to figures quoted by the 8th Circuit court, the Army National Guard provides 46 percent of the Army's combat units and 28 percent of its support forces. The Air National Guard provides a substantial portion of the nation's air defenses, including 73 percent of interceptor forces, 25 percent of tactical fighters and 24 percent of tactical air support.

DOC.HEAD: Students Burn Effigies of U.S. Ambassador, Roh
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of radical students burned effigies of the U.S. ambassador and President Roh Tae-woo on Monday in the southern city of Kwangju to protest the envoy's visit, reports said. A separate group of 100 protesters threw human excrement and tear gas powder near a police station several hundred yards from the U.S. Cultural Center residence that U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg visited, the news reports said. Gregg, who apparently did not see the protests, was the first U.S. ambassador to visit the city since a 1980 civil uprising in which 200 civilians died and 1,500 were wounded. Many Kwangju citizens believe Washington condoned the mobilization of the Korean military to put down unrest and silence government dissent. Washington has denied the allegations. About 500 radical students yelling anti-American slogans battled 900 riot police with firebombs and rocks at Kwangju's Chosun University, said Yonhap, the South Korean news agency. Fierce fighting continued for an hour inside the campus after riot troopers moved in to break up a rally, Yonhap and newspapers reported. The troopers were supported by two armored fans firing tear gas, the reports said. No injuries or arrests were reported. ``Gregg came here under a scheme with Roh Tae-woo trying to unilaterally shelve the Kwangju issue,'' Yonhap quoted a student leader at the rally as saying. Police have been on alert since the ambassador arrived Sunday for a three-day visit. Korean news reports said he was protected by plainclothes officers. The Hankook Ilbo, a Seoul daily, said police advised against Gregg's visit, but U.S. officials said an explanation of Washington's role in Kwangju should be resolved through dialogue. ``I came here not to make an apology but to express regret and condolences to Kwangju citizens,'' Gregg said Monday, according to news reports. He also denied any U.S. involvment in putting down the uprising. Gregg said the United States urged the South Korean government in 1980 to settle the protests in Kwangju peacefully, ``but our influence was not enough over the South Korean government,'' Yonhap said. Anti-American sentiment is strong, and the U.S. Cultural Center in Kwangju was attacked 28 times before it was closed last year to protect the staff. Gregg has said he hopes it will reopen soon. Three dissident groups issued statements opposing his visit. The ambassador invited dissidents and leading citizens to a dinner to explain the U.S. position on Kwangju, but Yonhap said many stayed away in protest. ``We rejected his invitation because the truth about Kwangju and the possible U.S. role have not been clarified,'' said Chun Kye-ryang, a leading dissident and relative of a victim of the uprising. Last week, the U.S. Embassy issued a statement rejecting former President Chun Doo-hwan's reference to an alleged U.S. role in the Kwangju incident. Chun said in parliamentary testimony Dec. 31 that he, then an army general, decided on the military suppression of the uprising after receiving information from the United States that the military threat from Communist North Korea was increasing. The U.S. Embassy said the United States did not see any evidence of heightened threats from North Korea at the time. Gregg, a former CIA station chief in Seoul, has been the target of protests since he was appointed ambassador last year. On Oct. 13, six radical students broke into his residence and hurled homemade bombs at police before being overpowered. Gregg and his wife, Meg, were unhurt.

DOC.HEAD: As Relatives Cheer, Soldiers Get Back to Fort Bragg From Panama
With PM-After Noriega, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with welcoming speech, other detail; CORRECTS number of transport plans to four sted five. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Post officials...'.
DOC.TEXT: A contingent of 82nd Airborne Division troops arrived home today to shouts of joy and hugs of relatives, but the bulk of paratroopers from here remained in Panama. Four transport planes that carried the 700 men home began arriving before noon at Pope Air Force Base, which is adjacent to the sprawling Fort Bragg post. After the last one landed, troops formed as a battalion on the tarmac before being dismissed to greet the approximately 1,000 relatives and friends on hand. ``There are hundreds of thousands of Panamanians that will be forever grateful to you for bringing them freedom _ for the rest of their lives _ for bringing them peace and bringing them prosperity,'' Gen. Edwin H. Burba Jr. of Command Forces in Atlanta told the soldiers. One soldier was coming home to the son he's never seen. Kristi Harris waited for her husband, Spec. 4 Carlie Harris, carrying 4-day-old Carlie Jr. Their 7-year-old son, Patrick, also was there. She said no special celebration was planned for the missed Christmas holiday because her husband's homecoming ``is probably Christmas enough.'' The 3rd Battalion soldiers were among about 4,000 from Fort Bragg sent to Panama as part of the Dec. 20 invasion that toppled ruling Gen. Manuel Noriega. About 26,000 U.S. soldiers participated, and some already returned to other U.S. bases. ``I'm glad they finally took care of the situation'' in Panama, said another woman awaiting her soldier husband, Marie Ballou. ``It's been a long time coming.'' The unit that returned today was the 3rd Battalion of the 504th Parachute Infantry Regiment. Post officials said they did not know when other Fort Bragg troops would return. The 3rd battalion was involved in seizing Madden Dam, a major source of electrical power for U.S. installations in the area, and Cerro Tigre, which was believed to be the main supply depot for Noriega's troops, Army officials said. No soldiers from the battalion were killed, but 23 were wounded, officials said. On Sunday, about more than 600 Army Rangers of the 3rd Battalion, 75th Ranger Regiment returned from Panama to Fort Benning in Columbus, Ga. ``It's great to be home,'' Pfc. Daniel Becker said, after being reunited with his girlfriend.

DOC.HEAD: Urban Leaders Say Drug Problem Worsening
With AM-Noriega-Impact, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Drug problems worsened last year in more than half the nation's cities, making the issue the top worry of urban leaders, a survey of elected officials said Monday. Fewer than one city in 10 reported making any headway locally in the war on drugs, according to the survey by the National League of Cities. ``There's been a lot of talk about drugs coming out of Washington, and our city leaders are now sending back a message _ a message that it's time for Washington to get a front-line report on what's happening and what's needed,'' said Alan Beals, executive director of the league. ``The drug issue must be a national priority, local officials are saying, because they cannot beat it on their own,'' he said. The league surveyed elected municipal officials _ mayors and council members _ from 314 cities selected randomly from the 2,461 cities with a population of 10,000 or more. Officials in 58 percent of cities surveyed said drug problems had worsened in their communities over the past year. Another 31 percent said the magnitude of the drug problem remained the same, and 9 percent reported progress. Drugs led the list of top concerns of city officials. One in five said that if they could meet with President Bush on any topic, they would focus on drugs. ``Clearly our local leaders believe there is a need for national leadership and a stronger commitment of national resources to help eradicate the poisonous and violent drug culture that has invaded our cities,'' Beals said. On other topics, 39 percent said their cities would have to raise local taxes this year. Nearly half said they would increase various user fees, and almost two-thirds said their city's spending will increase. Beals, at a news conference releasing the study, said cities leaders are ``making the tough choices on their own,'' by raising taxes _ without waiting for the federal government to provide more help. He decried a ``fend for yourself national approach'' of the last decade, with the federal government withdrawing aid to cities. The league survey was conducted by telephone in November and early December by the Center for Urban Studies at Wayne State University in Detroit. Beals said it was a scientific sample, and it carried a stated margin of error of plus or minus 5.5 percentage points. Beals said there was discontent among urban leaders with the federal government's allocation of money to fight drugs. The $2.2 billion in federal drug assistance goes to the states, he said, ``but it's needed in our cities where the war against drugs is being fought.'' He said the survey found nearly half, 47 percent, described relations with their state government as ``fair'' at best, 22 percent said they were ``poor,'' and 28 percent said ``good.'' Other top concerns cited by the city officials as needing presidential attention were financial constraints and the lack of federal aid to go with federally required local programs, solid waste and other environmental problems, education and affordable housing. Besides drugs, city leaders reported worsening conditions involving the cost of living, affordability of housing, energy costs, crime and solid waste.

DOC.HEAD: American to Choreograph Chinese Ballet
DOC.TEXT: An American is choreographing a Chinese ballet in one of the first such cultural exchanges since China's military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement last June. Norman Walker, who teaches dance at Adelphi University in New York and has choreographed more than 150 dances, said the romantic score he had composed for the Central Ballet of China depicts a ``natural growth in human affairs.'' Walker said the ballet, based on Chinese composer Liu Dunnan's piano concerto ``The Mountain Forest,'' attempts movements different from the rest of the Central Ballet's repertoire ``so as to expand their potential.'' The dance, he said, ``is classically based but uses the attack and thrust as well as the movement ideas of contemporary dance.'' Mary Yung Kantor, a sponsor of the project, said the ballet would be ``the first cultural exchange like this'' since China's suppression of the democracy movement soured relations with the United States. ``Art is art. I'm not here for propaganda,'' said Mrs. Kantor, president of the Simarka Trading Co., which has offices in New York, Hong Kong and Taiwan. The Chinese, she said, ``know I have no ulterior motives.'' Academic and sports exchanges have been revived slowly in recent months, and at least one American opera troupe performed in China last summer. The ballet, based on an exchange planned before June, will open Jan. 18 in Beijing and will feature 11 couples from the national troupe. The Central Ballet was founded in 1959, but during the ultra-leftist Cultural Revolution of 1966-76 it was allowed to perform only revolutionary works. It recent years it has gained an international reputation for staging Western ballet classics and has toured the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union. Walker, who has choreographed dances for the Joffrey Ballet, Boston Ballet, Washington Ballet and Ballet Philippines, joins well-known ballet figures such as Beryl Grey, Maria Fay and Rudolf Nureyev who have worked with the company.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Plan Giant Independence Rally For Gorbachev Visit
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian activists say they are planning a big welcome for Mikhail S. Gorbachev when he arrives in their restive republic this week: a pro-independence rally they expect will draw hundreds of thousands. Sajudis, the Lithuanian grassroots political movement, is putting out the call on radio and TV for a giant demonstration upon the Soviet president's arrival Wednesday in the republic's capital of Vilnius, according to Longinas Vasiliauskas, a Sajudis spokesman. ``This demonstration is needed to show Gorbachev and the world that the Lithuanian people has already made its choice for a free and independent state,'' he said Sunday by telephone from Vilnius. Gorbachev reportedly is scheduled to spend three days in Lithuania this week trying to heal the rift between the republic's breakaway Communist Party and Moscow. On Dec. 20, a majority of Lithuanian Communists voted to break ties with the national party, a possible precursor to secession by the Baltic republic of 3.7 million people. Gorbachev criticized the move, saying the Communists were giving in to ``separatists,'' but leaders of the breakaway party who met with Gorbachev in Moscow last week said he also promised not to interfere if they stuck with their decision. Vasiliauskas said Gorbachev's remarks about separatists prompted Sajudis call for the rally. ``Sajudis intends for Gorbachev to see for himself that there is no alternative for Lithuania besides independence,'' he said. Nationalist rallies in the more politically active of the Soviet Union's 15 republics repeatedly have drawn hundreds of thousands. An estimated 1 million residents of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia joined hands last summer to protest the 1939 Soviet-Nazi pact that allotted the Baltic states to the Soviet sphere. The Sajudis announcement calls for Wednesday's demonstration to be ``peaceful, dignified and disciplined,'' Vasiliauskas said. ``There will be a few hundred thousand there, that's for sure.'' Gorbachev met Saturday in Moscow with loyal Communists from Lithuania who oppose their party's bold break with the national party, and an estimated 3,000 people back home rallied to support them. The protesters at the central sports palace in Vilnius adopted an appeal to Gorbachev asking him to condemn ``nationalistic and chauvinistic overtones'' in their republic and to restore the unity of the Communist Party. There has been little word of what Gorbachev discussed with the loyalists. The official news agency Tass said only that Gorbachev's talks with them and earlier meeting with the pro-independence faction featured ``an exchange of opinions on a way out of the situation.'' Lithuanian Communist Party leader Algirdas Brazauskas said the meetings have ``helped the two sides understand each other better,'' Radio Moscow reported Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Projectiles Fired at Home of Emperor's Brother; No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A homemade projectile fired from a car hit near the home of Emperor Akihito's younger brother Monday and another missile was found near the imperial garden in Kyoto, police said. No injuries or damage were reported. Police suspected leftist radicals opposed to the monarchy for the attacks, which took place at about the same time in Tokyo and Kyoto. The attacks came the same day a commission was formed to plan Akihito's formal coronation, and a day after the end of a one-year mourning period for his father, Emperor Hirohito. Police officials in Tokyo said missiles were fired from a car parked 650 feet from the western Tokyo residence of Prince Hitachi, Akihito's younger brother. One projectile was found in a road and a fragment, possibly from a second missile, was discovered in the yard of a private home near Hitachi's home, said the officials on condition of anonymity. The projectile contained no explosives, they said. Police said there were five launchers in the parked car's trunk. Kyodo News Service said one exploded in the car, which went up in flames. Police said they did not know if Hitachi, 54, third in line to the throne after Akihito's two sons, was home at the time. Police said they were investigating who owned the car and whether it had been stolen. Kyodo said the car had been stolen last month. Kyodo quoted an unidentified woman living nearby as saying she heard ``five or six booming sounds like fireworks going off. I felt as though fragments of something were going to come flying toward our house and was really scared.'' In the western city of Kyoto, one homemade projectile was found near the gate of the imperial garden, police said. Witnesses reported hearing three explosions. On Sunday, vandals burned the door of a building at the tomb of the legendary Emperor Kaika in the western town of Nara, police said. A note nearby said, ``Nara Red Army. Anti-imperial and anti-emperor,'' according to police. The radical groups oppose Japan's monarchy, despite public opinion polls showing strong support for it. On Monday, the government inaugurated the Imperial Enthronement Committee, led by Prime Minister Toshiku Kaifu, to plan the November coronation. Although Akihito, 56, became emperor immediately after his father died on Jan. 7, 1989, coronation plans were delayed by the one-year mourning period. Hirohito died at age 87 after a 62-year reign, longest in Japanese history. Some Japanese are opposed to government plans to spend $58 million on his son's coronation. In 1986, Japanese radicals fired homemade missiles at the state guest house, the U.S. Embassy, the Imperial Palace, Akihito's home and a police headquarters in Osaka before a summit meeting in Tokyo of seven major industrialized democracies. One person was injured. A car was set afire by a time bomb, reportedly by leftist radicals, in a parking lot of an Imperial Household Agency dormitory on April 29, Hirohito's birthday.

DOC.HEAD: China Buys 300,000 Metric Tons of U.S. Wheat
DOC.TEXT: China has bought an additional 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat under a price subsidy program, the Agriculture Department said Monday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said five private exporting companies made the deals under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Delivery of the wheat is schedfuled for May, he said. The sales were part of 1 million tons authorized for China under EEP on Dec. 5. A previous allocation of 2 million tons made last Feb. 27 had been exhausted, except for 10,000 tons. With the latest EEP approvals, China has 300,000 tons remaining to be used under the current authorization. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The latest sales would be about 11 million bushels. At current prices, estimated by USDA at $3.83 per bushel, the wheat would have a farm value of around $42 million. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest subsidies averaged $15.45 per ton, or about 42 cents per bushel. The subsidized sales were handled by Bunge Corp., 85,000 tons; Peavey Co., 80,000; Cargill Inc., 50,000; J. Aron & Co., 45,000, and Tradigrain Inc., 40,000. With the latest sales, China has bought about 5.4 million tons of U.S. wheat for delivery in the 1989-90 marketing year, which began June 1, most of it without subsidies. In 1988-89, China bought more than 8 million tons of U.S. wheat, all of it under the EEP program.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0612 to CORRECT category code.
Bush Declares `Time Is Past' for Congress to Cut Capital Gains Tax
DOC.TEXT: President Bush struck a combative stance for the 1990 congressional session Monday, complaining ``it is past time'' for lawmakers to approve a capital gains tax cut and other White House proposals left hanging last year. Saying a capital gains bill would be a top priority, Bush declared, ``I am sick and tired of the demagogues who call this a tax cut for the rich. It means jobs, it means savings and it is good for all Americans.'' Many Democrats in Congress have opposed a reduction on grounds the chief beneficiaries would be the wealthy. Bush spelled out his legislative hopes in a speech to 8,000 delegates to the annual convention of the American Farm Bureau, the nation's largest farm organization with 3.8 million member families. He also called for action on anti-crime and clean-air legislation, but the tax cut talk won the loudest applause from farmers. Bush reminded his audience that lower tax rates would apply to the sale of farmland. On a separate issue, Bush also won cheers by saying, ``I am mighty proud'' of the American forces who were sent to Panama to depose Manuel Antonio Noriega. Noriega is being held in Miami on drug-trafficking charges, and Bush said, ``The joy shown by the people of Panama says it all.'' The capital gains legislation concerns taxes on profits derived from the sale of stocks, real estate and other assets. Bush has proposed lowering the top tax rate to 15 percent from the current tops of 28 percent and 33 percent. A Bush-backed plan was defeated last year when Senate Republicans could not muster the 60 votes necessary to break a Democratic filibuster against it. But lawmakers on both sides of the issue have expressed doubt that procedural devices could kill the proposal this year. An aide to Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, who led the opposition last year, said Monday the Maine Democrat ``supported a capital gains (tax) reduction in 1986, and has said he will continue to support one if it meets three criteria _ if it doesn't adversely effect the budget deficit, if it is targeted, and if it is part of a fair and progressive tax structure.'' One of every four Democrats sided with Republicans when the House voted for a capital gains cut last September. But even some Democrats who are longtime supporters of lower capital-gains taxes were unhappy with the bill because it would have provided a lower tax rate for only 2\ years and then would have substituted a system under which gains caused by inflation would be excluded from taxation. Bush has not disclosed details of the cut he will propose in his Jan. 29 budget message. However, congressional Republicans say they expect him to call for a plan that would provide a greater tax incentive the longer an asset is held. Thus, profits from the sale of property owned for five years would be taxed less than would gains from something owned two years. Present law taxes capital gains at the same rates as other income. ``The fight isn't over yet,'' Bush said, contending that a capital gains tax cut would ``help keep American agriculture dynamic and prosperous.'' More generally, Bush recalled that ``I put out my hand to the Congress, to the Democratic majority'' in his inaugural address a year ago and offered lawmakers proposals on crime, clean air and the capital gains tax cut. ``Now a year has past. The new year is upon us and it's time, it is past time for Congress to tend to some of the unfinished business,'' Bush said. With Congress due back in session Jan. 23, Bush said, ``The hand of cooperation is once again extended. And I would only add: America wants it done right; America wants it done responsibly, and America wants it done now.'' After his speech, Bush toured futuristic exhibits of high-technology agriculture at Walt Disney's EPCOT Center. He also visited the ``living seas'' building and came face to face with porpoises and scuba divers in a tank. The trip came at the start of a year in which Congress must update the 1985 farm legislation that reduced basic crop price supports, saving billions of dollars for taxpayers. Crop subsidies this year are expected to total about $11 billion, far below the record $26 billion in 1986. Providing only a hint about the farm bill he will propose, Bush said, ``We must have market-oriented farm policies that allow producers more flexibility to decide what crops to grow. ... ``At the same time, we've got to maintain a safety net to protect farmers from conditions beyond their control,'' the president said. Moreover, Bush said, ``We've got to expand markets and enhance productivity. We've got to assure the public that America's food is the safest in the world, and we've got to protect our precious environment.'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter has said he does not expect massive changes in the 1985 law, but has acknowledged that the 1990 rewrite must tackle the issues of environmental and food safety. Bush said international markets for farmers are improving, with U.S. agricultural exports increasing last year for the third year in a row. ``We also support expanding our ties with Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to open even more markets,'' Bush said, noting that Yeutter led a delegation to Poland to suggest ways it could shift to a market economy. ``We're forging new partnerships between our agriculture industries and Eastern Europe's emerging economies.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Agents Arrest Cult Leader, Seize Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The Lundgrens...', to UPDATE with official saying they did not plan to waive extradition, arraignment now set for Tuesday sted extradition hearing today.
DOC.TEXT: A cult leader wanted in the slayings of an Ohio family of five was arrested near the Mexican border by authorities who say weapons and survivalist gear were found in his motel room and a storage locker. Jeffrey Lundgren, 39, a former Sunday-school teacher and tour guide in the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in Ohio, was arrested outside the motel Sunday by federal agents and county sheriffs. Lundgren's 38-year-old wife, Alice, and the couple's 19-year-old son, Damon, also were arrested there. Three other Lundgren children _ Kristen, 10, Caleb, 9, and Jason, 15 _ were taken into protective custody, said Andrew Vita, the special agent in charge of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms office in Los Angeles. ``This will relieve a lot of apprehension,'' Kirtland, Ohio, police officer Ronald K. Andolsek said late Sunday on the Lundgrens' arrests. In recent days, Kirtland police had been keeping close watch of the homes of residents who were once threatened by Lundgren. John Hewicker, a San Diego County deputy district attorney who handles extraditions, said today that the Lundgrens told investigators they would refuse to waive extradition to Ohio, where they face charges that include aggravated murder and kidnapping. The Lundgrens will be in state court on Tuesday for arraignment on fugitive charges, Hewicker said. The extradition hearing would come later, he said. Lundgren broke away from the Reorganized Church and persuaded other members to follow him, officials said. The group once lived on a 15-acre farm near the Cleveland-area town, where investigators last week unearthed five bodies. Authorities believe the five are Dennis Avery, his wife, Cheryl, and their three young daughters. Investigators believe the Averys were killed in mid-April and buried in a common grave under the barn. Searches of the Southern California motel room and a nearby storage area rented by Jeffrey Lundgren uncovered numerous weapons, including an AR-15 assault rifle, as well as ammunition, knives and gas masks, Vita said. ``They had camping gear, web gear that the military would wear _ things that can sustain you up in the mountains,'' he said. ``We're not sure where they were going,'' ATF agent James Stathes said. Authorities had been watching the motel since Saturday night, said George Rodriguez, a special agent for the ATF in Kansas City, Mo. Lundgren and 12 of his followers were indicted by a Lake County, Ohio, grand jury in the killings. Two followers _ Kathryn Renee Johnson, 36, of Holden, Mo., and Daniel David Craft, 25, of Nauvoo, Ill. _ remain at large. Authorities were led to the motel in National City, about five miles south of San Diego, by telephone calls made from a pay phone to another location under surveillance, said Steven C. LaTourette, a Lake County prosecutor who held a news conference in Painesville, Ohio. ``This case continues to develop. As a prosecutor, I've got to tell you, it's a great case,'' LaTourette said. The prosecutor has said the Averys apparently were killed in a cult sacrifice necessary under a prophecy of Lundgren's before the cult could relocate. However, the president of the northeast Ohio chapter of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, Dale Luffman, said he thought the slayings resulted from a dispute over money, sex or fear the family would leave the cult. The church stripped Lundgren of his lay minister credentials in 1987 after he began preaching radical doctrines. Though the church has roots and some beliefs in common with the Mormon Church, the two churches are separate.

DOC.HEAD: Puerto Rico Native Will Run For Seat Of Convicted Congressman
DOC.TEXT: A state legislator who is a native of Puerto Rico said Monday that he will run for the congressional seat vacated last week by the resignation of convicted Rep. Robert Garcia. Garcia was convicted on extortion and conspiracy charges in the Wedtech military contracting scandal. State Assemblyman Jose Serrano said he'll officially declare his candidacy ``as soon as the governor calls the (special) election.'' Gov. Mario Cuomo's press secretary, Gary Fryer, said the governor would soon announce a special election, probably to be held in late February, for the Garcia seat in the New York City borough of the Bronx, one of the nation's poorest congressional districts. Under the special election process, county leaders determine the party candidates without primaries. Serrano is expected to have the backing of George Friedman, the Bronx County Democratic chairman and an Assembly colleague of Serrano's, and thus should get the Democratic ballot spot. In that congressional district, as in many areas of heavily Democratic New York City, gaining the party nomination is tantamount to election. If elected, Serrano, 46, would be the only voting member of Congress to be a native of Puerto Rico. He moved with his family to the Bronx when he was 7.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Opens in $8.7 Million Suit over Navy Jet Training Flights
DOC.TEXT: A former cattle rancher testified Monday that Navy jets screaming as low as 100 feet above his central Nevada land terrified his livestock, interfered in their breeding and eventually put him out of business. Don Nonella testified at the opening of a federal court trial in his $8.7 million lawsuit against the Navy, which operates the Fallon Naval Air Station 60 miles west of the Nonellas' former ranch. The government claims poor business practices and not noisy fighters ruined Nonella's chances of success. Nonella testified that in May 1985 only 466 cows were successfully bred instead of the 800 he had anticipated. He said the animals' health and their feed were all acceptable. He said he was baffled until one day when he was moving some cattle and a Navy jet roared over. ``I could see the pilot had glasses on, I was that close to him,'' Nonella said. ``It occurred to me at that time it might be the jet overflights.'' Nonella, 58, and his wife, Barbara, 52, filed suit last year over the daily training flights out of the naval air station, about 60 miles east of Reno. ``We put our life savings into the place and they put us out of business,'' said Nonella, who nows lives in Elko and drives trucks. ``We couldn't operate out there because of the noise.'' They are among dozens of residents who lived in the valleys under the Navy's designated air space for flight training and who have long complained that low-level jet flights shattered their nerves and sometimes property. Congress appropriated $10.9 million to buy about 100 parcels in Dixie Valley, 70 miles east of Fallon, where some 35 families lived. The Nonellas owned their 1,000-head ranch from 1979 through 1988, then abandoned it after they were unable to sell it. ``No one would buy the place and we couldn't make our payments so we just deeded it back to the federal land bank,'' Don Nonella said. ``We just left.'' The non-jury trial is expected to last more than one week.

DOC.HEAD: Redoubt Volcano Erupts Again; Sends Out Ash Cloud
DOC.TEXT: Redoubt Volcano rumbled alive today, spitting ash and steam at least five miles into the air, scientists said. Redoubt produced a ``vigorous'' eruption at 10:20 a.m., said Steve Brantley of the Alaska Volcano Observatory. Pilots reported ash up to at least 26,000 feet, he said. Winds from the southwest were expected to carry the ash north and northeast. The volcano 115 miles southwest of Anchorage rumbled awake Dec. 13 after a 25-year rest. Periodic eruptions since then have disrupted air traffic off and on, including Saturday. But today's eruption did not immediately result in new flight restrictions, the Federal Aviation Administration said. Saturday's activity was ``clearly a minor event'' compared to eruptions last month and even earlier last week, the observatory said. Scientists said that during the day the volcano continued to generate ``a vigorous plume'' of steam and volcanic gas to altitudes of 12,000 to 15,000 feet. Volcanic ash is of concern to pilots because it can shut down jet engines. A Boeing 747 operated by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines lost power to all four engines after flying through Redoubt ash last month. The engines were restarted and the plane made a safe emergency landing in Anchorage.

DOC.HEAD: Families of Kidnapped Swiss Workers Appeal for Their Release
DOC.TEXT: Family members of two young Swiss relief workers visited Beirut on Monday and urged the kidnappers to set their loved ones free. Elio Erriquez and Emmanuel Christen were orthopedic technicians at an International Red Cross clinic in Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut, when they were kidnapped Oct. 6. ``I appeal to you to unlock the door and allow them to come freely from Sidon to Beirut,'' Marianne Christen said. ``I would like to tell my son how much we miss him and are looking forward to seeing him back among us.'' Erriquez's mother, Graziella, said: ``I appeal to their captors to release them immediately because their seizure is harming thousands of people in need of their assistance.'' The Sidon orthopedic center was closed after the abductions. Mrs. Christen said the families visited Beirut ``to see the place Elio and Emmanuel loved and lived in for the last two years and to meet the people who are doing their best to ensure their safe release.'' Marie Erriquez, Elio's twin, said: ``If Elio and Emmanuel can hear us, I want them to be courageous because they have lots of friends here and in Switzerland who have shown their support against this injustice.'' Accompanying the families were Christophe Marnish and Angelo Gnaedeinger of the International Red Cross in Geneva. During a news conference at the seaside Summerland Hotel in Moslem west Beirut, the group displayed a petition for the men's release that bore 70,000 signatures collected by Swiss newspapers and a support committee for the hostages. Michel Dufour, head of the all-Swiss International Red Cross office in Lebanon, said it had received more than 50,000 letters of sympathy. Dufour said the families would take the letters home to ``show Lebanese concern and consciousness toward our colleagues.'' No group has claimed responsibility for kidnapping Christen, 32, and Erriquez, 23. Sidon police and the Palestine Liberation Organization say they are held by the Fatah Revolutionary Council terrorist group led by Abu Nidal, but it denies responsibility. Christen and Erriquez are among 18 Westerners held hostage in Lebanon, who include eight Americans. Held longest is Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, abducted March 16, 1985. Most Western hostages are believed held by Shiite Moslem kidnappers loyal to Iran. In an interview published Sunday in Tehran, Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, the former Iranian foreign minister, said Iran does not want relations with the United States, and the Lebanese have a right to hold foreign hostages. The English-language Tehran Times quoted him as saying Iran seeks diplomatic relations with all countries except the United States, Israel and South Africa. ``Lebanese Sunnis, Shiites, Druse and Christians are the hostages of the U.S., Israel and other Western powers, so it's their natural right to take hostages to inflict heavy blows on their enemies,'' Mohtashemi said. ``No negotiations, but force, is the answer to what the enemies of the Lebanese have done against that deprived nation.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Bob Dylan will open an international tour with a warmup concert Friday at Toad's Place, a New Haven nightclub that in August featured the Rolling Stones. To get Dylan to appear at the club, which can hold only 700 people, Toad's offered to let him keep all proceeds from ticket sales, said Mike Spoerndle, president of Toad's. Tickets are to cost $18.50. ``We were not looking to make money. We were interested in having another legend,'' Spoerndle said. After Toad's landed the Stones to close out the 1980s, Dylan's appearance ``is a great way to start the 1990s,'' said Katherine Cormack, Toad's director of booking and promotion. Dylan's latest album is titled ``Oh Mercy.''

Jerry Van Dyke, who turned down a role in ``Gilligan's Island'' in favor of ``My Mother, the Car,'' refuses to be optimistic about the chances of his latest effort, ABC's ``Coach.'' ``I've had terrible luck, just awful luck,'' said Van Dyke, who got his start in television on his older brother's long-running ``The Dick Van Dyke Show.'' ``I was offered `Gilligan's Island.' I said `This is the worst thing I ever saw and I won't do it.' Look at it ... becomes a hit ... lasted three seasons,'' Van Dyke said in the Jan. 13 edition of TV Guide Magazine. ``My Mother, the Car'' quickly stalled. The magazine didn't say what role Van Dyke was offered in ``Gilligan's Island.'' The younger Van Dyke's pessimism toward his new role as assistant football Coach Luther Van Dam in the TV series, which features Craig T. Nelson in the title role, is founded on more than just one failure. After ``Car'' failed, ``Sheldon Leonard, who was the top producer in TV (in the late 1960s) had one bomb in his life and it was my show, `Accidental Family,''' Van Dyke said. Next came ``Headmaster,'' starring Andy Griffith in the title role, which also bombed.

A con man who says he's borrowing jewelry for Joan Rivers has made off with thousands of dollars worth of merchandise from at least two Manhattan stores, the syndicated talk-show host said Monday. ``This is terribly sad,'' Rivers said in a news release. ``The store owners are nice, honest people and this shouldn't have happened to them.'' The well-dressed man in his 30's said he was borrowing the jewelry for Rivers to wear during a televised interview with arms dealer Adnan Khashoggi, according to Jennifer Geertz, a spokeswoman for Rivers. The con man left two phone numbers with the stores, one at CBS and another that reaches a recorded message at offices of ``The Joan Rivers Show.'' ``He was a real pro,'' Irene Kojen of the Peipers & Kojen store told New York magazine. ``He was so smooth that when he asked for one ring, I lent him two, so Joan would have a choice.''

Michelle Pfeiffer has been chosen best actress and Beau Bridges best supporting actor by the National Society of Film Critics for their work in ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' ``Baker Boys,'' the story of two pianist-brothers who add a woman singer to their nightclub act, also won the best cinematography award Sunday for the work of Michael Ballhaus. ``Drugstore Cowboy,'' an independent film about a small group of drug addicts who steal from pharmacies, was voted best film of 1989 by the society, which comprises 39 critics of major national publications. Its director, Gus Van Sant Jr., was voted best director. Its screenplay was also cited. Daniel Day-Lewis was chosen best actor for his portrayal in ``My Left Foot'' of Christy Brown, who overcame cerebral palsy and poverty to become a noted Irish artist and writer. Anjelica Huston was picked best supporting actress for her role in ``Enemies, A Love Story,'' based on a novel by Isaac Bashevis Singer. ``Roger and Me,'' Michael Moore's description of how mass layoffs by General Motors changed Flint, Mich., received the best documentary award.

DOC.HEAD: Ben the Bear, of `Grizzly Adams' Fame, Is Dead
DOC.TEXT: Ben, one of the Kodiak bears who starred in the ``Grizzly Adams'' television series in the late 1970s, has died during hibernation of chronic heart disease, zoo officials said Monday. The best-known resident of the Folsom Children's Zoo apparently died last week in his hibernation den. Zoo Director John Chapo said Monday that Ben apparently had been dead for several days when he was found by a zookeeper. Ben, believed to be about 15 years old, lived at the zoo for 10 years. The Kodiak bear, a subspecies of the brown bear, has a life span of about 35 years. The bear's grumpy personality eventually made him unsuitable for movies and television work and his owners found a home for him in Lincoln. Kodiak bears are among the largest carnivores in North America. Ben was about 8 feet tall and weighed 800 to 1,000 pounds at death. He was somewhat smaller than the largest kodiaks, which can stand 11 to 12 feet tall and weigh 1,600 pounds. Ben usually would arouse from his hibernation on pleasant days and eat, Chapo said, but Saturday the zookeeper could not rouse him. Tests showed he died of chronic heart disease, Chapo said. The condition could have been present from birth or might have developed later. It had gone undetected because physical exams of such large animals are difficult and infrequent. ``He'd always been healthy, acted fine,'' Chapo said. ``There was no reason'' to put him under anesthesia to examine him, which could be dangerous to such a big animal.

DOC.HEAD: Nelson Mandela Likely to be Freed Shortly, Wife Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs at end with British group organizing for Mandela release.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CPN2
DOC.TEXT: An upbeat Winnie Mandela met her jailed husband, Nelson Mandela, on Monday for talks about his widely expected release, which she believes will be within weeks. Mrs. Mandela, who visited her husband for three hours, has never emerged from a visit so optimistic about prospects of freedom for Mandela, who has been jailed almost 28 years. ``This is the first time I have accepted as a reality that he will be released this year,'' Mrs. Mandela said. ``This is the real thing.'' As recently as two weeks ago, Mrs. Mandela was playing down speculation that her husband would be freed early in 1990. She said Monday that no release date had been given to her or her husband. Asked whether it would be weeks or months from now, however, she replied: ``I don't think we are talking about months.'' Since taking office in August, President F.W. de Klerk has freed several of Mandela's colleagues from the outlawed African National Congress guerrilla movement and has indicated Mandela's release will follow. A broad range of black leaders have said they cannot accept de Klerk's invitation to negotiate a new constitution until Mandela is freed. There is strong speculation de Klerk will make a statement about Mandela's status when he opens Parliament on Feb. 1. The ANC, in a statement from its exile headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia, acknowledged the de Klerk government was moving to dismantle apartheid but said it was premature to begin negotiations. ``We are committed to seize any real opportunity that might emerge genuinely to seek a political agreement for the speedy end of the apartheid system,'' Alfred Nzo, the ANC's secretary-general said in a statement marking the group's 78th anniversary. However, he added: ``The armed struggle continues to be a critical and decisive component part of our strategy.'' Mrs. Mandela met with her husband in a former staff residence at Victor Verster Prison Farm in the wine-growing town of Paarl, near Cape Town. She emerged in the company of lawyer Omar Dullah, who said: ``Mrs. Mandela was requested by Mr. Mandela to make the visit because he wanted to discuss with her some preliminary arrangements relating to his release, in view of the general expectation that his release will be sooner rather than later.'' Mrs. Mandela declined to elaborate on the meeting. ``Suffice it to say it is the first time we have discussed the preliminary arrangements of what will happen after release,'' she said. Asked how she felt, she replied with a broad smile: ``I think it is clear from my expression.'' Mandela, 71, is South Africa's best-known black leader. There is widespread belief he could be elected president if the black majority had full voting rights. He has been jailed since 1962 and is serving a life sentence for plotting a sabotage campaign to undermine the white-run government. Mandela has received a steady stream of visitors in recent weeks, ranging from Cabinet ministers to prominent anti-apartheid leaders. He met Dec. 13 with de Klerk at the presidential office. The country remains under a 43-month-old state of emergency and the ANC is officially banned. De Klerk has hinted, however, that he may lift some emergency restrictions, and the recently released ANC leaders leaders have campaigned openly on behalf of their organization. They also have been granted passports and are expected to travel next week to ANC headquarters in Zambia. In London, Anglican Archbishop Trevor Huddleston, a veteran anti-apartheid campaigner, on Monday launched the ``Nelson Mandela International Reception Committee'' aimed at organizing celebrations when the black leader is released. A statement by the committee urged towns and universities around the world that have honored Mandela to arrange events.

DOC.HEAD: When Must Someone Come Forward With Information?
With AM-Stuart Shooting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of Charles Stuart who might have suspected he was involved in his wife's killing had no legal obligation under state law to report that to police, legal experts say. In Massachusetts, ``persons are criminally culpable for what they do, for their acts, not for what they know,'' said Frank Chubert, a professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University in Boston. The issue was raised last week when Stuart's youngest brother, Matthew, implicated him in his pregnant wife's shooting death Oct. 23. Matthew Stuart told police he disposed of a gun and her purse at his brother's request. Charles Stuart, apparently aware he had become a suspect, committed suicide Thursday as police sought to arrest him. He had told police that a mugger shot him and his wife during a robbery after they left a hospital childbirth class. Matthew Stuart reportedly told others of his suspicions. Legal experts say that although some people might have known the truth all along, they cannot be held criminally liable under Massachusetts law for withholding information. ``There is no obligation,'' said John Dawley, who was Charles Stuart's attorney. ``But morally and ethically, there are different standards.'' About a dozen states, but not Massachusetts, have ``good Samaritan'' laws that require people to tell authorities if they know a crime has been committed, said Charles Ogletree, a professor at Harvard Law School. But he said the law is rarely enforced. ``It's hard to persuade a jury to convict someone who said, `I saw a crime and I was scared to report it,''' Ogletree said in an interview Friday. Also, if such laws were strictly enforced, they could have painful implications, Chubert said. ``Just think of where that goes,'' he said. ``Does that mean mom and dad get prosecuted for failure to report? You could use the power to lock up a person's family.'' Massachusetts also grants immunity for close relatives who become an accessory to a crime after the criminal act has been committed, Ogletree said. Typically, he said, immunity would be granted to a relative who hides a fugitive. But in the case of Matthew Stuart, the issue of legal protection might be more complicated, experts said. His attorney said Matthew Stuart, at his brother's instruction, met him the night of the shooting and took a bag containing a gun and Mrs. Stuart's purse. An important part of his story is that he wasn't aware Mrs. Stuart was shot when he retrieved the items. If in fact he knew that the crime was being committed, then he might be crossing the line into aiding the crime, in which he would not have the immunity, Ogletree said. ``He's on thin ice,'' said Joseph Balliro, a criminal lawyer in Boston. ``That's going to be up to a grand jury to decide if they believe him or not believe him.'' Furthermore, experts said, the disposal of a gun can be considered a separate crime, such as obstruction of justice. ``If he goes out and hides the evidence of a crime, then that's a no-no,'' Balliro said Friday. John Julian, a spokesman for the Suffolk County district attorney's office, said Friday he could not comment on whether Stuart might be charged or receive immunity. ``There is an ongoing grand jury investigation,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Vegetable Prices Push Menu Prices Up
DOC.TEXT: Higher prices are cropping up in Florida restaurants, especially those offering vegetarian fare, in the wake of the Christmas freeze that wiped out much of the state's winter farms. A few restaurant owners say they've had to raise prices just to break even. ``I'm a vegetarian restaurant, so I'm feeling more than a pinch,'' said James McKenna, owner of the Ciao Sidewalk Cafe in Delray Beach, 20 miles north. McKenna said a few weeks ago he was buying tomatoes for $8.50 a case, but now he is paying $23. As a result, he raised the price of the meal-sized salads at his cafe by 25 cents Thursday. The Taurus Steak House in Miami's Coconut Grove section has been adding a $1.75 surcharge for their salad bar since the day after Christmas because fo the higher vegetable prices, said Dave Hill Jr., the restaurant's manager. At Ruby Tuesday chain restaurants, the prices have not changed, but some days they've left cherry tomatoes and green peppers off salads. ``We have not increased our prices, but we've had to delete a few items,'' said Craig Marcy, a senior assistant at Ruby Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale's Broward Mall. Most big restaurant chains are bearing the cost without changes. ``We're just absorbing the extra cost,'' said Cheri Grey of the Steak & Ale regional headquarters in Tampa. ``This is just short term.'' Prices fluctuate in any market and effect the restaurant industry, said Frank Pike, chairman of the board of the Palm Beach County Chapter of the Florida Restaurant Association. ``This happens in a multitude of categories _ beef, stone crabs,'' Pike said. ``They can't change their prices every time the market fluctuates.'' Pike said it is too early to assess the impact of increased vegetable costs on the restaurant industry as a whole.

DOC.HEAD: British Moslems Begin Vigil at Rushdie's Publishers
DOC.TEXT: Moslems picketed Monday outside the publishers of the novel ``The Satanic Verses,'' but organizers of the protest tried to distance themselves from the death threat against author Salman Rushdie. At a news conference to announce the five-day vigil, Mugharam Al-Ghamdi, chairman of the U.K. Action Committee on Islamic Affairs, said the demonstration is a reminder that the Moslem outrage over the novel, which started with its publication in September 1988, would not subside. Picketers outside Viking Penguin Books handed out leaflets and carried signs proclaiming ``No Rushdie Porn,'' ``Hypocrisy in High Places,'' and ``Put Honor Back on the Agenda.'' Moslems say ``The Satanic Verses'' blasphemes Islam by associating the prophet Mohammed with prostitutes and suggesting the Koran, Islam's holy book, was not the work of God. On Feb. 14, Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issued a religious edict calling on Moslems to kill Rushdie. Khomeini's action drove Rushdie into hiding, and two Iranian clerics offered a bounty of $5.2 million for Indian-born writer's death. Iranian leaders have not rescinded the threat after Khomeini's death June 3. ``Since the sensationalism has receded, what remains is a genuine and permanent bitterness in the hearts and minds of ordinary Moslems,'' Al-Ghamdi said. Although he warned that the bitterness would increase if the book were not withdrawn, he and the U.K. Action Committee did not support the death threat. ``We appeal all the time to Moslems in Britain to keep within the limits of the law,'' said Iqbal Saraceni, a committee leader. ``We will not condone any overstepping of the law.'' The committee, however, refused to condemn the death threat. Threats also have been made to Penguin. A police officer is on 24-hour duty outside and three security guards now watch over the entrance hall, which is equipped with a metal detector. Viking Penguin spokesman Bob Gregory said there was no connection between the vigil and publication of a paperback edition of ``The Satanic Verses.'' ``There is no date set for publication of the paperback,'' Gregory said. ``From that you cannot assume that a paperback version will be published or will not be published.'' Al-Ghamdi said Britain's 1.5 million Moslems want ``The Satanic Verses'' withdrawn from publication and Britain's blasphemy laws changed to incorporate other religions besides Christianity. Moslem communities from across Britain are taking turns picketing the west London offices during the protest. On Monday, Moslems from Bradford, 180 miles northwest of London, were on duty. ``We've seen a mixture of some people who are sympathetic and some people who disagree,'' said Liaqat Hussain, the general secretary of the Bradford Council for Moslems. The protesters handed out leaflets demanding withdrawal of the book, a change in the blasphemy laws and for ``the moral support and goodwill of all our fellow citizens to further our just demands.''

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Drug for Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved the drug clomipramine for the treatment of patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder. The FDA determined that clomipramine is a new kind of drug that represents an advance in the treatment of the condition. Although the drug is only now being approved for routine use, it has been available for use in severe cases of obsessive-compulsive disorder, or OCD. It is made by Ciba-Geigy Corp., and will be marketed under the trade name Anafranil. ``Anafranil has proved to be effective in controlling OCD symptoms in many patients,'' said Dr. Michael Jenike of Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. The symptoms of the disorder include obsessive preoccupation with dirt or contamination, and the fear among its sufferers that they will act on violent thoughts. They develop such compulsions as excessive cleaning, handwashing, counting, and checking. Another approved drug called fluoxetine, or Prozac, also appears to be effective against obsessive-compulsive disorder, researchers said.

DOC.HEAD: Clues Show Possible Flaws in Murder Plot
DOC.TEXT: A gun was stolen from the fur store where Charles Stuart once worked, adding another twist to the grisly murder hoax that police now say was not so cunning after all. The latest clue came Monday with confirmation that a .38-caliber revolver was stolen from the Edward F. Kakas & Sons fur store where Stuart worked as a manager, and the gun might have been the weapon used to kill his pregnant wife and wound him. ``I believe what happened with Chuckie, this was the doing of a sick mind,'' Pat Reardon, a cousin, said Monday. Stuart, 29, committed suicide last week after his brother Matthew implicated him in the crime. Charles Stuart originally told police that he and his wife were the victims of a mugger who forced his way into their car Oct. 23 as they left a birthing class. Stuart's wife, Carol, died hours after the shooting, and their premature baby, Christopher, died 17 days later.
