Matthew Stuart, 23, told authorities last week that he took Mrs. Stuart's handbag, which contained the gun, from the scene and threw the items separately into the Pines River in Revere. Divers have recovered the handbag but not the gun. Jay Kakas, co-owner of the fur store, told police that a revolver was stolen from the safe at the store, a representative of the store, who asked not to be identified, confirmed Monday. Stuart also had access to the safe, the representative said, and the Kakases thought to check the safe last week after police named Stuart as the prime suspect. Investigators have refused to comment on the disappearance of the gun. Other flaws also have emerged in what some officials said at first looked like a near-perfect crime. Most notably, Matthew Stuart was apparently not the only person to know of his brother's involvement. He told his attorney that he told family members and friends about the scheme. Matthew Stuart declined to comment on the case as he left the family home Monday, telling reporters, ``I can't talk to you.'' Another brother, Michael Stuart, was questioned Monday at the Suffolk County district attorney's office. His lawyer, Richard Clayman, said his client ``broke no laws.'' Legal experts say the family members had no legal duty to contact police about their suspicions. ``There is no obligation,'' John Dawley, who was Charles Stuart's attorney, said last week. ``But morally and ethically, there are different standards.'' Police are investigating whether insurance was a motive behind the crime. Stuart collected $82,000 on an insurance policy due his wife for her work as an attorney, and a search of the couple's Reading home has turned up another $100,000 policy on her, according to various sources. Police reportedly also are investigating whether a romantic relationship between Stuart and another woman might have been a factor. News reports indicate a 22-year-old woman who worked for two summers at the fur store repeatedly used Stuart's telephone calling card number to call him while he was hospitalized after the October shooting. Prosecutors have declined to say whether more charges might be coming, saying a grand jury investigation is continuing, and that they are still assembling information obtained from scores of interviews since Stuart's death. The younger Stuart told authorities that he was not aware Mrs. Stuart had been shot when he met his brother at the crime scene. Members of the black community, who have denounced what they say was a racist investigation into the Stuart case, met informally Monday to discuss a proposed civilian panel to evaluate police misconduct. In his story to police, Stuart said the mugger was black, and during the investigation scores of black residents were searched and at least two black suspects were named. ``We have to ease the tensions and avert similar problems in the future by establishing a civilian review board so black residents feel they can take their complaints to a fair and impartial body of citizens,'' said City Councilor Charles Yancey. Members of the Statehouse's black caucus have also said they plan to send a letter to U.S. Attorney Wayne Budd requesting a review of how the Stuart investigation was handled.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Invasion Troops Return to Fort Bragg
With AM-Noriega-Drug Impact, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Carlie is cq in 13 graf
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CBS1, PAN3
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of paratroopers who took part in the invasion of Panama returned home Monday to accolades from a general who described their work as ``absolutely brilliant.'' ``There are hundreds of thousands of Panamanians that will be forever grateful to you for bringing them freedom _ for the rest of their lives _ for bringing them peace and bringing them prosperity,'' said Gen. Edwin H. Burba Jr., of the Army's Forces Command in Atlanta. When the general welcomed the troops of the 82nd Airborne Division home with the greeting ``airborne all the way,'' a woman apparently eager to greet one of the soldiers shouted, ``Over here, all the way.'' Some 700 to 750 soldiers from the 3rd Battalion, 504th Parachute Infantry Regiment, arrived on four C-141 transport planes. They had been sent to Panama Dec. 10 for jungle warfare training. They were among about 4,000 soldiers from Fort Bragg that took part in the Dec. 20 invasion that toppled the ruling Gen. Manuel Noriega. The battalion was involved in seizing Madden Dam, a major source of electrical power for U.S. installations in the area, and Cerro Tigre, which was believed to be the main supply depot for Noriega's troops, Army officials said. The battalion also seized the village of Gamboa, home to more than 50 American families, and El Renacer Prison, where political prisoners from the failed October coup attempt against Noriega were held, officials said. No soldiers from the battalion were killed, but 23 suffered wounds or injuries, officials said. Of the 23 U.S. soliders killed in Panama, four were based at Fort Bragg, near Fayetteville, 60 miles southwest of Raleigh. Uninjured troops began returning to U.S. bases last week. ``The strategy and the tactics were good,'' Burba told soldiers standing in formation in a misty rain. ``You were well trained ... you had great leadership. We're really proud of you.'' The general praised the soldiers' work as ``absolutely brilliant. ... You ushered in a new era of combat.'' Spec. Jerry Wollam, a radio operator, said soldiers were told when they went to Panama that ``we were going down for jungle training but we might be some extra help.'' He was reunited with his wife, Kara, and twin boys Jeremy and Justin, born July 24. Kristi Harris, waited for husband Spec. 4 Carlie Harris with her 7-year-old son, Patrick, and son Carlie Jr., who was born four days ago. She said her husband had called her Christmas Eve, the first word she'd had from him since his unit left, to say he was all right. Mrs. Harris said no special celebration was planned for the missed Christmas holiday because her husband's homecoming ``is probably Christmas enough.'' Family members, some waving small United States flags and others holding umbrellas to ward off the light mist, waited under a banner that said, ``Team Bragg is proud of `Just Cause' Soldiers.'' The military operation was code named ``Just Cause.'' In the crowd was Marie Ballou, who was six months pregnant when her husband, Staff Sgt. Todd Ballou, was sent to Panama. Mrs. Ballou had false labor on Christmas Day, which her doctors told her was caused by the stress of worrying about her husband. ``I'm glad they finally took care of the situation'' in Panama, she said. ``It's been a long time coming.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Guerrilla Leader Proposes Angolan Peace Plan
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a long-dormant Angolan resistance group proposed a peace plan Monday involving a ``round-table'' of Angola's leaders, a U.N. peacekeeping force and free elections after an 18-month transition period. Holden Roberto, head of the National Front for the Liberation of Angola, which was a powerful force with U.S. backing in the mid-70s, told a news conference in Paris that Angola should take inspiration from the ``wind of change'' sweeping eastern Europe. Eduardo Dos Santos, president of Angola's Marxist government, would remain in charge for the 18-month transition period, Roberto said, and the U.N. force would be modeled after the one assuring transition to independence in neighboring Namibia. He said U.N. troops would be responsible for making sure no foreign military aid reached either Dos Santos' Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) or its chief rival, the National Union for the Total Liberation of Angola of Jonas Savimbi. All political or military prisoners held by both sides should be released under the plan, Roberto said. Roberto's and Savimbi's groups, along with MPLA, were signatories of the 1975 agreement that was supposed to lead to peaceful independence of Angola, then a Portuguese colony. But the pact fell apart, and the National Front for the Liberation of Angola was nearly annihilated in the late 1970s, while Savimbi's UNITA has continued to battle the MPLA government. After the Reagan aministration began aiding Savimbi in 1986, Roberto also sought American help to re-establish his guerrillas, apparently without success.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarians Shocked at Drastic Price Increases
DOC.TEXT: Shoppers were shocked and angered Monday by steep price increases for food and other consumer goods despite a government campaign to prepare them for the belt-tightening measures. The increases were part of an austerity package approved by parliament that will qualify Hungary for new credits from the International Monetary Fund. The trade unions maintain the increases will push as many as 3 million of the country's 10.6 million inhabitants below the official poverty line, which was set on Dec. 31 at just over $80 a month. ``I simply do not know how I am going to make ends meet,'' said Eva Kekes, a single publishing house editor, expressing the sentiment of many Hungarians. The price increases will boost the consumer price level by 19.5 percent, almost equaling the government's forecast of 20 percent inflation for all of 1990, the MTI news agency reported. Except for one specific brand of milk and bread, producers will be free to set all food prices, a fact that already has led to retail prices of meat and meat products going up an average 32 percent, dairy products by almost 43 percent and bread by 20 percent. Cigarettes, beer and spirits were 20 percent to 22 percent higher. As word spread about the extent of the price increases, store shelves began to empty and lines grew longer at stores and gas stations as people were hoarding on a large scale. Rice, flour, sugar, vegetable oil, canned meats, frozen vegtables were sold out. Some customers were overheard saying ``Just like Poland,'' where austerity measures took effect Jan. 1. Last week, butchers were under siege and shelves soon emptied even of lard. On Saturday, milk was impossible to find. People were also buying detergents and similar products, although these prices were not going up. On Friday and Saturday, the waiting time at gas stations was about three hours, with people filling cans in anticipation of a 15 percent to 17 percent increase. On Monday, many food stores were closed because the staff was pricing items and restocking shelves. Ms. Kekes, 36, said singles especially were hard hit ``because we have only one income, yet pay high rents, high utilities and high retail prices.'' ``At the same time, singles are discriminated against when seeking credit and when applying for housing,'' she said. Peter Huzella, a folk singer in an above-average income bracket, said that ``past price hikes did not make that much of a difference, but this one hit us hard.'' ``Our regular skiing trips are off and we have to rethink the special classes _ languages and sports _ the kids are taking,'' said Huzella, who has has a wife who is working, and three children aged 6, 10, and 14. ``I am sure we'll have enough to eat, but I am really worried about the people I see around me, especially those of my parents' generation,'' said Huzella, 40. His wife, Hajnal, said that with their jobs and the children, ``there is simply no time to go bargain-hunting. We'll just have to save where we can.'' Cars imported from Warsaw Pact countries became 25 percent more expensive, and sewage and water rates had already been raised by 336 percent, MTI said. Apartment rents are to increase by an average 35 percent from Feb. 1, while postal charges went up by an average 22 percent Monday. Also from next month, local transport fares will go up by 55 percent in Budapest and by 45 percent in other cities, while rail and inter-city bus fares will increase by an average 20 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors to be Sequestered For Reputed Mob Head's Trial
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began Monday for the assault and conspiracy trial of reputed mob boss John Gotti, and the judge said he will sequester the jurors because he is responsible for their ``well-being and comfort.'' Gotti, 48, alleged to be the head of the Gambino crime family, and Anthony Guerrieri, 60, are charged in the May 1986 shooting of John F. O'Connor of Brewster, vice president and business manager of the Carpenters Union Local 608. A third defendant died in December. State Supreme Court Justice Edward McLaughlin said the trial will last about three weeks, with the jurors locked away in hotels when trial is not in session. About three-fourths of the initial pool of 300 prospective jurors said they were unable to sit on a sequestered jury for three weeks and were excused. The remaining 77 were given 11-page questionnaires about their personal histories and opinions. Earlier, McLaughlin rejected a prosecution request for an anonymous jury, saying the defense would be given the jurors' names but not their home addresses or places of business. ``The defendants in this case will stop at nothing to prevent their conviction on the charges currently pending against them,'' Assistant District Attorney Jeffrey Schlanger said in court papers. Schlanger said that it took three trials to reach a verdict in 1988 in a federal racketeering and narcotics case involving Gotti's brother, Gene, and several associates, because jurors were accosted and intimidated. Prosecutors say Gotti commissioned members of a gang called the Westies to shoot O'Connor after O'Connor had a restaurant vandalized for using non-union carpenters. O'Connor, shot in the buttocks, apparently did not know the restaurant was managed by reputed Gambino family associate Phillip Modica, prosecutors say.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Says Cristiani Statements on Massacre Didn't Go Far Enoough
DOC.TEXT: President Alfredo Cristiani's acknowledgment that the military was responsible for killing six priests at the Central American University did not go far enough, its new rector said Monday. ``He only confirmed what we have said from the beginning. We need something more complete,'' said the Rev. Francisco Estrada of Cristiani's announcement Sunday night. Military and government officials declined to return telephone calls seeking elaboration of the president's admission that soldiers were responsible for the Nov. 16 slayings of six priests and educators and two women who lived on the Jesuit-run campus. Cristiani, in a five-minute nationwide address, did not say who has been implicated in the crime, or give any idea of their number or rank. The chief of the joint chiefs of staff said Sunday night that 47 members of an elite battalion, including two officers, were being questioned in connection with the slayings. But it was still unclear Monday if those soldiers and officers were the ones referred to by Cristiani. The United States on Monday praised Cristiani's announcement, but to Estrada, the speech ``was not relevant.'' ``It is not enough that they (the armed forces) put forward a sergeant. The question is, who ordered that sergeant to do it,'' said Estrada, who replaced the Rev. Ignacio Ellacuria, one of those murdered, as rector. Cristiani said a commission has been created ``to determine the exact circumstances (of the slayings) and clarify the truth in its complete magnitude.'' He said investigators would ``deduce responsibilities and make sure justice is done.'' Punishment will be meted out ``down to the last person implicated,'' he said. The slayings of the six priests and educators was one of the most heinous political slayings in the decade-long war against the leftist rebels. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater praised the Salvadoran investigation and hailed the ``great courage'' of Cristiani. ``We asked the investigation be thorough and the prosecution move ahead and it looks like that's the course he is on,'' said Fitzwater, who was traveling with President Bush aboard Air Force One to Florida. At the U.S. State Department, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the Salvadorans have made ``this important breakthrough'' in identifying alleged perpetrators, but she said prosecution must follow. U.S. authorities have indicated continued support for the government against the rebels depended to a great extent on punishing those responsible. No military officer has been convicted of a politically motivated slaying since civil war broke out in late 1979, although the army was implicated in rightist death squads blamed for the murders of thousands of suspected leftists in the early 1980s. Agents from the United States and Spain have aided in the investigation. Scotland Yard detectives arrived this weekend and began work Monday. Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, head of the joint chiefs of staff, said earlier by telephone that 47 soldiers from the elite Atlacatl battalion have been restricted to base but are not under arrest. Ponce said the 47 men being interrogated are members of the unit that conducted a search of the Jesuits' campus residence two days before the priests were slain. Asked if the men restricted to bases were implicated by evidence other than the fact that they conducted the search, Ponce declined to comment. A university employee has said she saw men in military uniforms outside the residence shortly before the shots that killed the priests were heard. The woman, Lucia Barrera, has been taken for her own safety to the United States, where she is under the protection of the Jesuits. The priests and educators _ Ellacuria, Ignacio Martin-Baro, Segundo Montes, Amado Lopez, Juan Ramon Moreno and Joaquin Lopez Lopez _ were taken from their beds in their on campus residence before dawn and killed. Their housekeeper, Julia Ramos, and her 15-year-old daughter Celina, also were slain. The slayings took place five days after leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, launched their biggest offensive of their 10-year-old revolution. The guerrillas have battled a succession of U.S.-backed governments they say serve as civilian facades for repressive military rule. The far right, which is blamed for the death-squad murders of several thousand suspected leftists in the early 1980s, had consistently denounced the Jesuits as subversive ideologues.

DOC.HEAD: ^ecurity Forces Go on Trial; Romania Lifts Travel Restrictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to include first conviction; picks up 5th pvs, `A group'
DOC.TEXT: Captured members of Nicolae Ceausescu's feared security force went on trial before military courts Monday, charged with trying to crush the uprising that ended his 24-year reign last month. The first such ``terrorist'' convicted was found guilty of attempted murder and sentenced to nine years in prison, state radio reported. It said the defendant tried to kill an army officer, but gave no names or details. Restrictions on travel abroad were lifted Monday, and the Roman Catholic Church said Romanian bishops had met for the first time in 41 years to discuss how the church could be rebuilt after decades of Communist suppression. Sibiu, a city in southern Transylvania that was ruled by Ceausescu's son, Nicu, was the site of the first trials of members of the Securitate. Members of the Securitate were fiercely loyal to Ceausescu. They continued to terrorize citizens and battle the army after his fall Dec. 22 and execution three days later. ``A group of terrorists who fought against the people in the army'' faced a military court, said a spokesman for the National Salvation Front, the provisional government ruling since Ceausescu's ouster. Aurel Dragos Munteanu, the spokesman and director of television, told a news conference he was unsure how many security men would face trial, and gave no details of the exact charges in Sibiu or other centers of heavy fighting such as Bucharest and Timisoara. The accused have no right of appeal, but media _ foreign and domestic _ will have access to the tribunals, he said. The National Salvation Front organized the secret military tribunal that ordered the president and his wife, Elena, executed on Dec. 25. Since then, it has abolished the death penalty, meaning that the captured men of crack security units who battled the army after Ceausescu was ousted face a maximum sentence of life in prison. Munteanu said those still under investigation include Nicu Ceausescu and Gen. Iulian Vlad, the former head of the Securitate, which has been ordered disbanded by the new leadership. Interim President Ion Iliescu signed a decree Monday providing for the ``right to free travel'' abroad, the state Rompress news agency reported. The decree also abolished the exit-entry visas and stipulated that passport seekers are entitled to a passport within 20 days after applying, and in ``justified emergency cases within three days at the most.'' ``In view of securing the fundamental rights and freedoms of the Romanian citizens ... all Romanian citizens older than 14, irrespective or race, nationality, sex, mother tongue, religion, political beliefs and occupation have the right to travel freely abroad,'' Rompress said. Under Ceausescu, Romanians had to wait at least three months to get a passport, which in many cases was not approved. Elderly people were as a rule allowed to travel to the West, but younger people or couples were denied. The decree, however, stipulated that passports can be refused if applicants are under prosecution or sentenced to prison, or if they ``are known through confirmed facts of being engaged in activities that upset public order or commit immoral offense.'' Romania became the latest former hard-line Soviet bloc country to lift restrictions on its citizens' travel to the West. East Germany and Czechoslovakia earlier allowed freer travel. Also on Monday, an Italian Roman Catholic church official said that Romania's Catholic bishops met last week for the first time since 1948 to discuss ways of rebuilding their church. Eleven bishops met Jan. 3-4 in Alba Iulia, central Romania, to review new prospects for the church, following the fall of Ceausescu's regime, according to the director of the Italian Catholic relief agency Caritas. Monsignor Giuseppe Pasini, who just returned from Romania, told a news conference in Rome that the meeting was attended by Archbishop Francesco Colasuonno, Pope John Paul II's special envoy for Eastern Europe. Pasini said there are ``well-founded hopes'' that the Vatican and Romania can re-establish diplomatic relations, which were broken in 1950 when the papal nuncio was expelled from Bucharest. The Romanian bishops agreed on the need to re-establish religious congregations, form a national bishops' conference and obtain full freedom to exercise their pastoral duties, he said. There are about 2.3 million Catholics in Romania, Pasini said, or about 10 percent of the population. They include 1.45 million Latin rite Catholics, of whom 1 million belong to the Hungarian minority and 150,000 are German-speaking.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Contras Give Up Fight and Return Home for Elections
DOC.TEXT: A top official and 8 others from the U.S.-backed Contra guerrillas on Monday ended their armed fight against the leftist Sandinista government to return home and take part in the electoral process. It was the first Contra group to return to Nicaragua under the auspices of a United Nations-Organization of American States committee charged with supervising demobilization of the rebel force. Luis Fley, a long-time official at the rebels' Honduras office, said the group decided to return as an expression of support for the Central American peace process and to ``contribute to the process of national reconciliation.'' The UN-OAS committee was established under the terms of accords reached by Central American presidents calling for demobilization of the Contras in exchange for fair elections in Nicaragua. Contras who want to take part in elections scheduled for Feb. 25 must return to Nicaragua by Feb. 5. Other Nicaraguans, mostly civilians, have returned under a different amnesty program. Fley, 39, was an attorney for the Contras and a top official at the Contra office in Tegucigalpa, Honduras. He was better known by his nom de guerre ``Commander Johnson,'' and for a time controlled journalists' access to the border camps in Honduras where the Contra army is based. The Central American accords guarantee returnees civil and political rights. Asked if he felt safe in returning, Fley told reporters, ``I think so.'' In a scene showing how war can split relatives, Fley was met by his family, including two brothers who are officers in the Sandinista army: Capt. Francisco Fley, 32, and Lt. Jorge Fley, 29. A third brother, Enrique Fley, was killed two years ago at age 28 in a Contra ambush. The Contras have been fighting to topple the Sandinista government with U.S. support, and Fley said the conditions that caused the war have not been solved despite the accords. ``The causes of the war have not disappeared because conditions of liberty, justice and democracy do not yet exist,'' said Fley, reading a statement during his arrival at Managua's airport. The nine arrived on a commercial flight and were met by UN and OAS representatives; the Nicaraguan ambassador in Honduras, Francisco Lacayo; and by Commander Luis Guzman of the Interior Ministry. Fley and the others negotiated for their return with Guzman, the international representatives and Lacayo. Guzman was sent to Honduras specifically for the negotiations. ``Most of the group did not have major information'' about the Tela accords and the guarantees included in them, Guzman said. ``Undoubtedly, on the part of the Contra leaders there has been no intention of letting their members know about the extent of the accords.'' Guzman said there were talks now taking place for more Contras to return to civilian life in Nicaragua. A document given Fley and the others spells out a series of guarantees: their constitutional rights are restored; they can resettle anywhere and can move throughout the country without any hindrance; they have a right to a passport and to travel outside the country without restrictions; they can join the political party of their choice and will not be prosecuted for any past political or military activity. UN representative Werner Blatter of Switzerland said the UN-OAS committee is charged with keeping track of those who return ``for any problem that could arise.''

DOC.HEAD: Windy, Warm, Wet In Northwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for Spokane-dated story on AM-News Advisory
DOC.TEXT: A series of storms packing heavy rain and high wind rolled across the Northwest over the weekend, cutting electricity to thousands of customers, ripping down trees and derailing a freight train. Two deaths in Oregon were blamed on the storms. Wind reached 92 mph at Rattlesnake Ridge on the Hanford nuclear reservation in south-central Washington, said National Weather Service meteorologist Darrol Lewis. A gust to 94 mph was reported at a Pacific Power & Light Co. gauge in Astoria, Ore., late Sunday and 72 mph gusts were reported early Monday in the area of Pendleton, Ore. Lewiston, Idaho, had a gust to 69 mph. Many schools were closed Monday in Idaho, Oregon and Washington and others opened later than usual because they were without electricity or had transportation problems caused by limbs and trees across roads. But the storms supplied much-needed snow for Wyoming ski resorts. One vigorous storm front moved through the region Saturday night, a slightly weaker front arrived late Sunday, and another one was possible Tuesday. In Wyoming, high wind knocked 35 railroad flatcars off the tracks between Cheyenne and Laramie on Sunday, Union Pacific spokesman John Bromley said moday. Only one of the cars carried any cargo, he said. ``We estimated winds were gusting in the area in excess of 70 miles per hour from the north,'' Bromley said from his Omaha, Neb., office. ``Nobody was hurt.'' Work continued Monday to right the cars, he said. Two other sets of tracks enabled the railroad to keep traffic moving, said Bromley. The Interstate 82 bridge across the Columbia River at Umatilla, Ore., about 30 miles south of Kennewick, Wash., was closed after a semi-trailer truck was blown over by the wind, the Washington State Patrol said. Utility crews scrambled Monday to restore power to large areas of eastern Washington, where trees and flying limbs snapped lines. Parked cars and buildings were hit by falling trees, and roofs were blown away. Electricity was cut to communities along the Washington-Idaho border and to the city of Spokane, Wash., said Pat Lynch of Washington Water Power Co. at Spokane. In Moscow, Idaho, ``only one of our schools had power this morning,'' said School Superintendent C.L. Sutton. ``Those big pine trees in the older section of town that have been there forever were pulled up by their roots.'' Radio stations throughout the Lewiston-Moscow area of Idaho were knocked off the air. Sections of downtown Walla Walla, Wash., were without power and scattered power outages were reported in the lower Yakima Valley. The wind also caused isolated power outages in southeastern Idaho, around the Pocatello area, and in the Idaho Panhandle. In Oregon, at the height of the storm Sunday, 10,000 customers were without power in the Albany-Corvallis area and 5,000 still didn't have electricity this morning. In the Dallas area, 6,500 customers had power knocked out and 3,000 didn't have electricity Monday, Donnelly said. The wind was accompanied by heavy rain. Bremerton, Wash., received 2.29 inches of rain in the 24 hours ending Sunday afternoon. Eugene, Ore., reported nearly 4.5 inches of rain in the 48 hours beginning at midnight Saturday. In addition to the rain, unseasonably high temperatures averaging 20 degrees above normal were recorded around Washington, raising the possibility that melting mountain snow could add to the rain swelling rivers. Wind and rain Saturday night caused mudslides and fallen trees that briefly blocked highways in parts of Washington. A mudslide closed Oregon 38 about 14 miles eas\ qf Reedsport late Sunday, the Douglas County sheriff's department reported. The storms dumped more than 1 foot of snow on the mountains of northwestern Wyoming, great news at the Jackson Hole Ski Corp., which in recent weeks has fought rumors that it was closing because of a snow shortage. ``The skiing has dramatically improved,'' said Bill Lewkowitz, the resort's national sales manager. After receiving 8 inches Friday, the resort collected an additional 11 to 15 inches from the storm that arrived Sunday night, said Lewkowitz. The snow prompted the Wyoming Highway Department to close Teton Pass west of Jackson, and high wind and heavy snow forced the closure of Wyoming 28 over South Pass.

DOC.HEAD: Musicians Want Accordion to Be City's Official Instrument
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Meeting begins at 5 p.m. EST, serenade likely at end, time uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: A band that wants the accordion designated the city's official instrument says the humble, pleated bellows is as much a part of the city history as earthquakes, clipper ships and cable cars. Players with Those Darn Accordions! revival band planned to serenade the mayor outside City Hall on Monday as the city considers a proposal to proclaim the music box the official instrument of San Francisco. ``There should be an official city instrument because we have official city songs and we need an instrument to play them on. It should be the accordion because of its rich history here and because it was invented here,'' said Tom Torriglia, a band member leading the effort for official recognition. The 13-member band, whose repertoire includes ``Volare,'' ``Hernando's Hideaway'' and ``The Godfather'' theme, planned to pla{@a`Our Lady of Spain'' beneath Mayor Art Agnos' window while San Francisco Supervisor Willie Kennedy introduced a proposal giving official status to the instrument. ``Mayor Agnos may be Greek but he is first and foremost a San Franciscan,'' said Torriglia, a free-lance publicist andotertainment reviewer. Despite the lyrical claim of the Starship band that ``it built this city on rock 'n' roll,'' Torriglia said the accordion more than the guitar, the piano or even the beatnik bongos of the 1950s deserves the official nod. Classical musicians still harkened back to European traditions in 1907 when Italian immigrants by the name of Pietro Deiro and Colombo Piatenesi fitted an old button accordion with a vertical piano keyboard and created the piano accordion that became as common at Italian family picnics as the vino, said accordion historian Ron Flynn of San FrancisCoV The Chinese, inventors of the musical reed, originated the principles of the accordion, whichpw]s recreated by Germans and Italians, said Flynn. In the 1800s, piano keys were added on the right, with cords and tones played on buttons on the left. Deiro's improvement on that design spawned an accordion industry in San Francisco that in its 1920s heyday included eight accordion manufacturing firms and teachers famed nationwide and in Europe. Few remnants of that era remain, said Torriglia, who blames the British rock 'n' roll invasion and ``schmaltzy'' Lawrence Welk with the waning popularity of the accordion. The instrument remains a favorite in Chicago's immigrant communities, with Cajun and Brazilian bands and in other regions, Flynn said. But in the San Francisco Bay area, the Colombo & Sons repair shop in Marin County is one of the few remaining descendants of the days when the renowned Guerrini Accordion Co. flourished in the heart of San Francisco's North Beach neighborhood. Torriglia says the ``um-pah um-pah'' sound of the accordion pushing wind through its vibrating reeds is an expressive sound that enables him to convey his most passionate emotions. Besides, he said, the accordion is part of a tradition even older than Italian picnics or Chinese ingenuity, ``It's a good way to meet girls.''

DOC.HEAD: Ideology Chief Says Lithuanian Party Independence Hurts Perestroika
LaserPhoto MOS6
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin's ideology chief told Lithuanian Communists on Monday their break with Moscow is a blow to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform program at its most critical moment. Vadim A. Medvedev, a member of the ruling Politburo, made the comment as he laid the groundwork for a trip to Lithuania this week by Gorbachev, a visit that will test Gorbachev's ability to end one of the worst political crises of his nearly five-year tenure. Violence along the Soviet-Iranian border meanwhile was reported to have reignited and spread to an area that also is close to Turkey. Soviet Azerbaijani protesters reportedly destroyed more border posts. Medvedev told Communists and workers at a factory in Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania, that their party's decision Dec. 20 to declare independence from the national party has ``effects on the problems of interethnic relations and national-state structure and economic reforms,'' Tass said. In a dispatch paraphrasing him, the official news agency did not say how economic reforms would be damaged. ``The decisions made by the 20th Congress of the Lithuanian Communist Party are a blow to the Soviet Communist Party's unity, to the construction of a revitalized federation and to all of perestroika,'' Tass said, paraphrasing Medvedev. The decision is seen as a possible precursor to secession by the Baltic republic of 3.7 million people. The Kremlin is clearly extremely concerned over the prospect that the entire Soviet federation could break apart if other republics follow Lithuania's move. Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev said in an interview Monday with Interfax, a news service of Radio Moscow, the Lithuanian move might cause a ``domino effect'' _ implying that Communists in the 14 other republics might also break from Moscow. Medvedev said the split cuts off Lithuanians from democratic processes throughout the country and ``cannot be assessed otherwise but as an expression of no-confidence in the Soviet Communist Party and its course for perestroika, as a blow to perestroika at the most critical time of its development.'' In remarks carried by Soviet TV, he asked Lithuanian Communists to compromise, saying, ``Nobody is against independence. But let this be together with the Soviet Communist Party. ``We have to unite, then we will have nothing to fear.'' Gorbachev is expected to arrive in Vilnius on Wednesday and spend three days trying to persuade the Lithuanians to return to the fold. The Lithuanian grassroots movement Sajudis is calling for a giant demonstration during the visit show the people's determination to pursue independence. Gorbachev has blasted the split, saying the Communists were giving in to ``separatists.'' Leaders of the breakaway party who met with him in Moscow last week said, however, he promised not to interfere if they stuck with their decision. The government daily Izvestia said Monday that Azerbaijani protesters destroyed border posts at Ilichevsk, continuing a wave of unrest that began Dec. 31. Protesters demanding to cross the Aras River, which borders Iran, confronted guards who set up armored personnel carriers and trucks to blockade a bridge. But the guards retreated to ``avoid bloodletting,'' Izvestia said. After the protesters passed through, they destroyed the border posts so that the frontier of Azerbaijan's Nakhichevan region with Iran is without defenses, according to the newspaper. Thousands of protesters demanding open borders and unification with their ethnic brethren in Iran have destroyed guard observation towers, electronic alarms and communications lines along the border. Elsewhere in Azerbaijan, Tass said sabotage, hostage-taking and sniper fire continued in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh district. A highway bridge between Agdam and Askeran was blown up Thursday and four days later, an explosion damaged a railway bridge near Agdam, forcing suspension of traffic. Strikes and violence have torn the mountainous Nagorno-Karabakh territory for two years as majority Armenians fight Azerbaijanis for control.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Demands Proof Secret Police Being Disbanded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to include figures on Leipzig, other rallies; picks up 5th `A near-frenzy'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: Pro-democracy groups forced early adjournment Monday of weekly talks with the Communist Party on East Germany's future, demanding proof that the hated secret police were being disbanded as promised. About 100,000 reformers rallied at Leipzig, in the first of its regular Monday evening demonstrations after a three-week break. As at previous Leipzig demonstrations, the crowd was divided between those favoring reunification with West Germany and those opposed. Rally sponsors canceled the usual speeches to prevent a confrontation on the issue. In the crowd were banners with such slogans as ``Down with the SED'' _ the Socialist Unity Party, the Communists' formal name _ and ``Gysi out,'' a reference to party chairman Gregor Gysi. About 50,000 people rallied at Karl-Marx-Stadt and thousands demonstrated in Schwerin, Halle, Neubrandenburg and Cottbus, said ADN, the official news agency. ADN said the first indictments against 30 former top Communists were expected next month and more investigations would be completed in March and April. A near-frenzy against corruption and abuse of power has developed since Erich Honecker, the 77-year-old Stalinist party chief, was deposed in October after 18 years in power. The agency said it could not predict when charges could be expected against Honecker, who also is the object of a criminal investigation, but it denied there was any intentional delay in pursuing his case. Honecker is hospitalized, the agency reported, but it did not say where. Last week, ADN said he had a malignant kidney tumor. Monday's confrontation illustrated the wariness with which reformers regard the transitional government of Hans Modrow, the Communist premier. Two major opposition groups _ including the largest, New Forum _ have threatened to leave the talks because of what they call government efforts to preserve the secret police. Failure of the talks could set the stage for new political turmoil. A majority of delegates supported a motion by New Forum to end the Monday session an hour early and block consideration of other topics until officials provide details on the dissolution of the once-feared secret police. Delegates demanded unanimously that the government submit a report about internal security at the meeting Jan. 15. Democratic Awakening, an opposition group, initially demanded that Modrow and other top officials appear at the meeting within two hours to clear up the matter. That was abandoned because Modrow was traveling to Bulgaria. Rolf Henrich of New Forum revealed what he said was a draft message prepared by secret police agents in Gera on Dec. 9, urging authorities in East Berlin to ``paralyze'' the opposition. Henrich said he did not know whether the message had been sent. Opposition delegates demanded the government disarm agents of the former State Security Office by Jan. 19 and cancel plans to establish a successor agency before free elections in May. Modrow has said a new security agency was needed to counter what his government claims is an increase of neo-Nazism in East Germany. ADN reported several weekend incidents of neo-Nazi graffiti and vandalism. It said Franz Schoenhuber, leader of the extreme-right Republican Party in West Germany, was turned back by border police Monday when he tried to enter East Berlin. ADN did not say why Schoenhuber wanted to visit East Germany. Markus Meckel of the opposition Social Democrats accused the government of sowing ``hysteria'' with warnings of neo-Nazism, to try to preserve the secret police. Konrad Weiss of Democracy Now was quoted by the West German newspaper Bild as estimating the number of neo-Nazis in East Germany at 1,500 or more and describing them as ``a serious threat.'' At Monday's negotiations, Peter Koch, named by the government to oversee the dissolution of the secret police, said authorities would confiscate all the former agency's arms by the end of January. Skeptical delegates bombarded Koch with questions and he agreed to let opposition observers visit his commission. He said citizen committees and opposition representatives throughout the country were ensuring against a return of the domestic spying, including telephone bugging, used by the Communists for 40 years to control the population. The talks, involving about 40 delegates, were begun Dec. 7 as a way for the opposition to express grievances and have a say in running the country until the elections May 6.

DOC.HEAD: Columnist Wins Lawsuit Over `Coming to America'
LaserPhoto WX14
DOC.TEXT: Art Buchwald won his lawsuit against Paramount Pictures on Monday when a judge ruled the humorist's original script idea was the basis for Eddie Murphy's box office bonanza ``Coming to America.'' Superior Court Judge Harvey Schneider's decision means Paramount will have to pay Buchwald a share of profits from the film, which has grossed more than $300 million since its 1988 release. Buchwald, a Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist, filed a $5 million suit against Paramount a year ago, claim9n[ the studio breached a 1983 contract to purchase his script idea. A second accounting ... of the trial will examine profits on ``Coming to America'' and determine the plaintiffs' share. ``The courT oncludes that `Coming to America' is a movie that was based upon Buchwald's treatment `King for a Day,''' Schneider said in a 34-page written ruling. Buchwald called the decision a victory for writers everywhere. ``I am very, very happy. This thing is not only an important thing for me. I think it's really important for writers,'' he said in a telephone interview from Washington. ``I didnwtknow what I was getting into when I started because those guys play rough, and we beat them. And that makes me very happy,'' Buchwald said. ``I doubt if I"`nt to get involved with Hollywood for some time.'' Paramount issued a statement saying it would appeal Monday's ruling. *`gWe don't think there's any similarity between these two works _ it's like `Godzilla' and `Cinderella,''' said Paramount attorney Robert Draper. ``The only similarity is that both (of the characters in the Buchwald and Murphy scripts) are black. We think that the law is clear on it, and we think that the evidence that came in on it was clear and we intend to present that to the appellate court.'' Buchwald attorney Pierce O`Donnell suggested the accounting phase of the trial would ``take the lid off Hollywood creative financing.'' Paramount claims ``Coming to America,'' with its gross profits over $300 million, has shown no net profits. ``If you believe that,'' quipped Buchwald, ``then there's a wonderful S&L I'd like to sell you.'' O'Donnell said Buchwald and Buchwald's partner, producer Alain Bernheim, could collect between $5 million to $10 million as their share of the film's net profits and called the decision a victory for Hollywood's creative community. ``I've never seen such a decisive victory for a writer,'' he said. ``It's a landmark decision.'' ``I am delighted that the little man kicked the big guy,'' added Billy Wilder, a Buchwald ally, the director and co-writer of Paramount's 1950 classic ``Sunset Boulevard'' and a frequent visitor to the courtroom during the trial. Schneider emphasized that his decision was not intended to disparage the creative talent of Eddie Murphy, who said he wrote the script. ``The court desires to indicate what this Ca^Ke is and is not about,'' the judge said. ``It is not about whether Art Buchwald or Eddie Murphy is more creative. It is clear to the court that each of these men is a creative genius in his own field and each is a uniquely American institution.'' Schneider stressed that Buchwald's contract dispute was with Paramount, not Murphy. Murphy co-star Arsenio Hall testified at the trial that he and Murphy independently conceived the idea for ``Coming to America.'' Schneider found that Buchwald's idea and Murphy movie were substantially similar. Buchwald's 1982 script synopsis optioned by Paramount involved a young member of royalty from``Pmythical African kingdom who comes to the United States and is deposed in his absence. He winds up in a Washington ghetto working in a fast food restaurant where he meets and marries a young black woman. In Murphy's movie, a prince from a mythical African kingdom comes to New York in search of a bride, winds up in a ghetto working in a fast food restaurant, meets a young black woman and marries her.

DOC.HEAD: Gap-Toothed Comic Actor Terry-Thomas Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Terry-Thomas, the consummate upper-class rotter in dozens of film comedies, including ``It's a Mad Mad Mad Mad World,'' died Monday at age 78, after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. The actor, whose trademarks were a gap between his upper front teeth, a well-brushed mustache and a long cigarette holder, died at a nursing home in Godalming, Surrey, according to the Parkinson's Disease Society. On screen ``he was a terrific cad. He was the ultimate cad,'' said actor Nigel Havers. ``He was the last of the great gentlemen on the cinema along with, in my experience, people like Fred Astaire and David Niven,'' said Lionel Jeffries, who appeared with Terry-Thomas in ``Rocket to the Moon'' in 1967. Terry-Thomas had been diagnosed as having the degenerative muscle disease in 1971 and had not appeared in films since ``The Hound of the Baskervilles'' in 1978. The cost of his care eventually forced him to sell his luxurious home on the Mediterranean island of Ibiza. In London, he lived in an apartment provided by a charity. The star of films including ``I'm All Right, Jack'' and ``It's a Mad Mad Mad Mad World,'' had been too ill to attend a benefit in his honor in London last April, which raised $51,000 for his care. In films, Terry-Thomas was often the upper-class cad or silly ass murmuring ``jolly good show,'' as in his role as Sir Percy in ``Those Magnificent Men in Their Flying Machines.'' He once denied that he was ``typically English.'' ``That makes me a bit of a sham I suppose. Because as you know I have made all my money, or most of it anyway, by sending up pompous Englishmen,'' he said. He was born Thomas Terry Hoar Stevens on July 14, 1911 and took his first two names for stage use until too many people thought he was related to actress Ellen Terry. He got his start in the theater in an amateur dramatic society associated with the Union Cold Storage Co., where he was a meat salesman. Even then, his appearance was splendid: a cigarette holder, a silver-topped Malacca cane, suede shoes and yellow leather gloves were part of the ensemble. ``I felt that my impeccable appearance more than compensated for my habitual late arrival at the office,'' he wrote in his book, ``Filling the Gap.'' His first film appearance was in ``Helter Skelter'' in 1949. Terry-Thomas' career took off in 1956 with the role of a commanding officer in the farce ``Privates Progress,'' which required him to handle such lines as ``You're an absolute shower.'' He appeared in ``The Green Man'' the same year and then in 1957 teamed with Ian Carmichael in ``Brothers in Law'' and ``Lucky Jim.'' In 1958, he appeared with Peter Sellers in ``Tom Thumb'' for MGM and in the British spoof ``Carlton Brown at the F.O.'' Terry-Thomas played the fatuous factory personnel manager to Sellers' communist shop steward in ``I'm All Right, Jack'' in 1959. Terry-Thomas' first marriage, to ballet dancer Ida Patlanski, ended in divorce in 1962. A year later he married Belinda Cunningham, who was 27 years younger, and they had two sons, Tiger and Cushan. In an interview in 1984, Terry-Thomas was resigned about his illness. ``It's no good asking why this had to happen to me,'' he said. ``There aren't any answers. The only thing we know definitely is that things get worse. There is no way of improving. You ask me how it feels ... there is a whole plethora of symptoms. Now I have said that ... other times I cannot say the simplest possible word, like lavatory paper.'' He is survived his wife and his two sons.

DOC.HEAD: FAA May Require That Infants, Toddlers Have Tickets
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration said Monday it intends to revise safety requirements for infants and toddlers traveling on airliners, but is not sure what form the rule will take. FAA Administator James Busey said the agency's eventual action, which could be two years away, may mean that adults traveling with children under age 2 will have to buy tickets for the youngsters and, perhaps, have them secured in FAA-approved child seats. Current FAA quidelines allow a child under age 2 to ride for free on an adult's lap. Busey, asked if the revised requirements would disallow that practice, replied, ``We want to know what the public wants. ... That's part of the problem .'' He also told reporters at a transportation convention, ``I can't make a rule that requires the airlines to provide free seats.'' If Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Dole approves the FAA proposal to write rules for the airlines' youngest passengers, a formal notice will be printed in the Federal Register. The public will then have 90 days to comment. An FAA spokesman said hearings may be held. A representative of the Association of Flight Attendants, which strongly supports putting children under age 2 in some sort of restraints, commented after Busey's announcement that ``it's ludicrous that there are FAA regulations in place to restrain carry-on baggage while babies are allowed to fly around the cabin during a crash.'' Nancy Gilmer, air safety coordinator for the association, praised the FAA for moving quickly on efforts to improve safety for small children and said many parents don't understand the problem of unrestrained youngsters. ``It's not unusual to be getting ready to take off and some little kid is running down the aisle,'' she said. ``As a flight attendant, it's something you learn to deal with.'' A spokeswoman for USAir said the airline is neutral on the subject of toughened safety requirements for small children. Spokeswoman Susan Young said a majority of parents traveling with children under age 2 carry them on the adults' laps, although some parents bring their own carriers and buy tickets for their children. Interest in airliner child restraints rose after the July 19 crash of United Airlines Flight 232 at Sioux City, Iowa. Five children under age 2 were traveling on adults' laps; one was a 23-month-old boy who died after his mother lost her grip as the plane cartwheeled across a runway, split apart and burst into flames. The child died of smoke inhalation. Busey also said told reporters that within 18 months the public can expect to see airport security devices that will detect plastic explosives. The technology to detect such explosives exists and is in use for baggage checked into airliner cargo space at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York and will soon be installed in Miami. He said that the equipment is still too cumbersome to be used for carry-on luggage but that the devices are becoming smaller and soon will be standard equipment in all airports.

DOC.HEAD: Permanent Members of U.N. Security Council to Meet on Cambodia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 9 `Vietnam says' to CORRECT to end of September, sted April. Picks up 10th pvs, `In an...'
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of the U.N. Security Council's five permanent members will meet in Paris next week to consider ways of bringing peace to Cambodia, diplomatic sources said Monday. They said the two-day talks would focus on an Australian proposal to replace Cambodia's Communist government with a U.N. administration until formation of a new government after free elections. Deputy foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France are to participate in the Paris meeting Jan. 15-16, the diplomats said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Michael Costello, Australia's deputy foreign minister, met with Premier Hun Sen of Cambodia on Monday about the proposal. The official Cambodian news agency SPK said they met in an ``eastern province of Cambodia'' and agreed to the idea of involving the United Nations in an interim administration. Guerrilla attacks in western Cambodia have increased international pressure to find ways of preventing a return to power by the Khmer Rouge, who conducted a reign of terror from the end of the Indochina war in 1975 until the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia in December 1978. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said talks among the five countries would take place ``in the near future,'' but would not confirm the date or place. ``Reports of stepped-up military activity by the Khmer Rouge underscore the need to move quickly toward a diplomatic solution,'' she said. ``We believe that a comprehensive settlement is thae best way to ensure that the Khmer Rouge do not enhance their influence in Cambodia by means of force.'' The Khmer Rouge is allied with two non-Communist resistance groups backed by the United States in a coalition led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former ruler. They are fighting the Hun Sen government, which Vietnam sponsors. Vietnam says it completed withdrawing its occupation army from Cambodia at the end of September. In an intrerview broadcast by Cambodian state radio Sunday, the defense minister acknowledged guerrilla advances in western areas near the Thai border, and said his forces had left some positions to concentrate defenses on major towns and roads. ``The enemies have been gradually advancing in their attacks against a number of our positions along the border,'' Gen. Tea Banh said. ``We have lost some positions. We cannot stay in every village. We have to abandon some and keep some strategic ones.'' Peace efforts, notably an international conference last summer in Paris, have failed in large part because the Hun Sen government refuses to include the Khmer Rouge in an all-party interim administration. Sihanouk argues that excluding the Khmer Rouge, the strongest guerrilla group, would only ensure continued fighting. Australia suggests about 200 administrators be sent to govern Cambodia, supported by a 7,000-member peacekeeping force. The Khmer Rouge has ignored the Australian proposal. On Jan. 3, Sihanouk said he would agree to an interim U.N. administration and vacate the Cambodian seat at the United Nations, which the guerrilla alliance holds, if the existing government was dismantled at the same time. The Australian plan cannot be put into effect without the approval of all five permanent members of the Security Council.

DOC.HEAD: Researcher: Noriega Said Snub Of Contra Plea Led US to Seek Ouster
With AM-Noriega-Impact, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A researcher who met with Manuel Antonio Noriega last year says Noriega told him ``the United States began its campaign to remove me'' after he refused to allow Panama to be used as a base for the U.S.-backed Nicaraguan Contra rebels. Saul Landau, a senior fellow at the Institute for Policy Studies, a Washington think tank, said Noriega told him last fall that John Poindexter, President Reagan's national security adviser, visited Panama in 1985 seeking Noriega's support for the Contras. ``Poindexter came to see me about what he said was a very urgent matter,'' Landau, in a report in the February-March issue of Mother Jones magazine, quoted Noriega as saying. According to Landau's account in Mother Jones, which provided an advance copy of the article to The Associated Press, Noriega continued: ``The admiral wanted to use Panamanian territory to train and launch Contra against Nicaragua. I explained to him why we could not become a launching pad for the Contra without causing turbulence in the region. I explained to him that if Panama assumed such a role in the area it would not help, but rather hurt, U.S. interests.'' Noriega, according to Landau, said Poindexter was visibly angered by Noriega's refusal. ``Poindexter grew quite indignant, right in my office,'' Landau quoted Noriega as saying. ``He took out his pipe and banged it on the table. I'm not sure if he broke it. After that incident, the United States began its campaign to remove me.'' Landau said he spoke to Noriega at a reception during a seminar Noriega had organized on U.S. intervention in Third World countries. Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. authorities last week after evading caputure during the U.S. invasion of Panama, is being held in Florida on drug-related charges. Poindexter is scheduled to stand trial later this month on charges stemming from his role in the Iran-Contra scandal. His attorney did not immediately return a telephone message left Monday by The AP. The statements attributed to Noriega by Landau are similar to an account Noriega gave in February 1988 on the CBS-TV program ``60 Minutes.'' In that interview, Noriega said he met with Poindexter on Dec. 17, 1985, and refused a Reagan administration request that Panama be used as a training ground for the Contra rebels trying to overthrow Nicaragua's Sandinista government. Noriega told ``60 Minutes'' that Poindexter told him the United States would harm Panama politically and economically if the request was turned down. In a speech days before that interview, Noriega said that Poindexter had asked him for unspecified cooperation in Central America and that when he refused Poindexter told him to ``expect the consequences.'' In the speech, Noriega said he considered his indictment on the drug charges the consequence.

DOC.HEAD: Precede JOHANNESBURG
With AM-Mandela Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with Jackson response
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson said Monday he would travel to South Africa soon, following announcement that the government there would grant him a long-denied visa. Jackson said the visa decision and the recent release of several leaders of the banned African National Congress demonstrated that ``some walls have come down.'' South African Foreign Minister Pik Botha said Monday the government had told Jackson that he ``will be welcome to come to South Africa and the necessary visa will be issued to him to travel to South Africa at a mutually convenient time.'' ``I've been trying to return for ten years ... and since President (F. W.) de Klerk met with Nelson Mandela obviously some walls have come down,'' said Jackson. Since taking office in August, de Klerk has freed several of Mandela's colleagues from the African National Congress guerrilla movement and has indicated Mandela's release will follow. ``The walls must come down in South Africa just as they have come down in Europe so people can get beyond the violence of separation to the constructing of a society where black and white people can live together without fear and mistrust,'' he said in a telephone interview. The civil rights leader and former presidential candidate has visited several countries in the region but always was turned down when he requested a visa for South Africa. Asked when he would visit the country which he has criticized for its apartheid policies of racial segregation, Jackson said: ``It will be soon but the date and time has not been established.'' Jackson said he would visit as the guest of the South African Council of Churches which recently reissued a longstanding invitation. Jackson also noted that the Dutch Reformed Church, which he said had until recently provided ``the theological underpinnings'' of apartheid, had also invited him to visit the country. ``I hope that the American policy and the decisions from within South Africa can hasten the day that the system will end without bloodshed.'' said Jackson.

DOC.HEAD: Government Seeks To Hinder Morris Defense As Jury Selection Begins
LaserPhoto SUC1
DOC.TEXT: The computer tampering trial of an Ivy League student accused of crippling thousands of computers nationwide opened Monday with jury selection and federal prosecutors seeking to limit defense evidence. Opening arguments were to begin Tuesday morning in the U.S. District Court trial of Robert T. Morris Jr., a 24-year-old suspended Cornell University graduate student. The Arnold, Md., man is the first person to come to trial under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act. If convicted, he faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Morris is accused of designing and setting loose a so-called ``worm'' program that replicated wildly, immobilizing an estimated 6,000 computers linked to the Internet research computer network, including those at Air Force and National Aeronautics and Space Administration facilities. In a motion filed Monday, Justice Department lawyers sought to hinder Morris' expected defense that he did not intend to paralyze the computer network by allegedly introducing a rogue program into it on Nov. 2, 1988. The prosecutors asked Judge Howard Munson to limit examination of witnesses on Morris' state of mind, specifically whether it was his intent to prevent authorized use of Internet and to cause any loss or damage to the system. ``The evidence of lack of intent to cause loss, or lack of intent to prevent the authorized use of the victim computers, however, is simply not relevant to any issue in this case,'' the motion said. Munson did not immediately rule on the motion. But when defense attorney Thomas Guidoboni raised the question of intent in a pretrial motion to have Morris' indictment dismissed, Munson rejected the argument that the defendant's intentions were pertinent to the indictment's legality. Guidoboni contends the law is unclear as to whether criminal intent means intent to cause damage or simply intent to gain access to computer systems. Justice Department attorneys Ellen R. Meltzer and Mark D. Rasch declined to comment on their own motion outside the courtroom. The first 10 potential jurors questioned from a pool of 93 were dismissed due to objections by Munson or lawyers, but all parties were able to agree on the next 12 candidates, finishing jury selection in less than three hours. Morris, who was a first-year doctoral student in computer studies before his suspension, sat attentively as lawyers questioned potential jurors. His father, Robert T. Morris Sr., chief scientist at the National Computer Security Center in Bethesda, Md., and mother also attended. Prosecutors also asked the court to allow witnesses to explain what the worm program was designed to do. ``Evidence that Morris designed earlier versions of the computer virus are relevant to the charges,'' the government said in its motion. The earlier versions were not launched. The trial is expected to last about two weeks. The government presented the court with a potential list of about 20 witnesses, and Guidoboni named at least four witnesses in court. A Cornell University commission concluded that Morris was guilty of ``reckless disregard'' for creating the program. Although the university commission found him responsible, Morris has never publicly admitted creating the worm program or introducing it into Internet.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders of Political, Ethnic Groups Urge End to Agitation
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Communist Party, opposition and ethnic groups united in appealing Monday for an end to protests and strikes over the decision to restore rights to Bulgaria's ethnic Turks. Consultations about settling the ethnic dispute began Monday and will continue all week, the official news agency BTA reported. Politburo member Mincho Yovchev said ``unrest over the ... decision'' Dec. 29 to restore religious rights to 1.2 million ethnic Turks and withdraw the requirement that they take Bulgarian names had created the ``first serious crisis'' since reforms began two months ago. Petar Mladenov, who replaced Todor Zhivkov as party chief Nov. 10 and ended 35 years of Stalinist rule, defended the policy reversal in a meeting with Slav nationalists. He told leaders of the Council for the Defense of National Interests that the 1984 decisions restricting the rights of ethnic Turks, most of whom are Moslems, ``were very grave errors,'' BTA reported. ``One result of these errors has been Bulgaria's complete international isolation,'' Mladenov said, and the only way out of that situation was ``to restore the constitutional rights of all citizens,'' the agency reported. Yovchev, a deputy premier, said the ``wounds inflicted on Bulgarian society as a whole'' by Zhivkov's persecution of ethnic Turks ``turned out to be much more serious than we assumed.'' After Zhivkov granted passports last May, 325,000 ethnic Turks fled Bulgaria for Turkey. About 96,000 have returned, complaining of poor housing and lack of jobs. ``Pressed for time, we were unable to accompany our decision in principle (Dec. 29) with a comprehensive program on the ethnic issue,'' he said in a television interview. His comments reflected the predicament of a leadership caught between demands by the ethnic Turkish minority for rights and protests by tens of thousands of Slav nationalists against concessions. ``Different forces take advantage of this to discredit the new leadership of the Bulgarian Communist Party and the state'' and the Politburo is seeking a ``practical solution'' to the ethnic problem, Yovchev said. He and others have hinted that Zhivkov loyalists incited ethnic unrest. Foreign Minister Boiko Dimitrov of Bulgaria and the Turkish foreign minister, Mesut Yilmaz, are to discuss the problem at a meeting Tuesday in Kuwait. At Monday's meeting of delegates from all groups concerned with the ethnic conflict, trade union official Krasniu Petkov urged that demonstrations and strikes cease ``during this week of dialogue,'' BTA reported. Petkov said all participants in the talks at the National Assembly supported Petkov. About 200 people demonstrated in front of the parliament building, demanding the restrictions on ethnic Turks continue. They displayed placards with such nationalist slogans as ``One People, One Language, One Flag.'' Nationalists have expressed fear their own culture would at one time be overshadowed by that of the Turks, whose birth rate is increasing as that of Slavs declines. Mistrust of Turks has lingered in Bulgaria since 500 years of occupation by the Ottoman Empire ended a century ago. Nationalist demonstrators deny pro-Zhivkov elements are behind the protests. ``I am sure local party officials have had nothing to do with this movement,'' Nelli Dimitrova, a 22-year-old university student, told an Associated Press reporter outside Parliament. Viktor Orlinov said, in contrast, that demonstrators from southern provinces told him Communist Party officials paid their fares to the capital. Orlinov is an ethnic Turk who works for state television in Sofia. ``The old apparatus of Zhivkov is still dangerous for Turks'' and party officials in the south, where many of the ethnic Turks live, are ``much more conservative and chauvinistic'' than those in the capital, he in a cafe. Demonstrations against Turkish rights have been held in Sofia and at least seven other cities.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia Denies US Attempting a Blockade as Part of Drug War
With AM-Colombia-US Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said publicly Monday it was not planning a naval blockade off Colombia as part of its fight against drug trafficking, and the Colombian government said it had received private assurances as well. A statement issued by the Colombian Embassy said the United States had said it would not interfere with Colombian flag ships, even on the high seas, without the permission of Colombian Defense Ministry. Other Colombian officials had accused the United States of moving toward a naval and air blockade, generating some confusion over the weekend as to the respective positions of the two governments. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the administration is considering use of the Navy but she said a blockade is not among the options. ``A blockade would mean shutting down everything, and that, obviously, is not our intention,'' she said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, traveling with President Bush on a trip to Orlando, Fla., said that two U.S. ships had left port and were on maneuvers in the Atlantic but that future deployment near Colombia would depend on talks with the Barco government. He said no agreement had been reached in preliminary discussions and praised the Colombian government for prior cooperation. Dismissing the significance of suggestions that Colombia would reject a U.S. naval role off its coast, Fitzwater said, ``I think the problem is we haven't had a chance here to really explore it with them.'' He said the United States was not taking blocking action now. Meanwhile, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney plans to unveil the administration's plans for military involvement in the anti-drug battle next week. Bush has looked at sending U.S. warships off the Colombian coast to help monitor and interdict narcotics traffickers, Pentagon sources have said. The aircraft carrier USS John F. Kennedy has been chosen to lead such an effort if the White House gives the signal to move forward, the sources have said. However, it has been unclear whether Colombia will agree to the plan. The State Department spokeswoman said there have been no more than low level consultations on the subject of increased U.S. efforts in the area thus far with Colombian officials. Ms. Tutwiler said that no interdiction effort will be carried out without full consultations with other governments which may be affected by such activity. Williams, asked about reports that two U.S. warships were on their way to Colombia to lead an anti-drug interdiction effort, said the USS John F. Kennedy and guided missile cruiser USS Virginia were on ``routine training exercises.'' He said he could not discuss any future operations the vessels may be called upon to undertake.

DOC.HEAD: Market Plunges 53 Percent, Economic Outlook Darkens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to RECAST lead, minor editing thereafter to tighten. Picks up 15th, `The economic...'
DOC.TEXT: Prices on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange plunged an average of 53 percent in value Monday when the market in economically wracked Argentina reopened for the first time in more than a week. Meanwhile, the government said inflation in December soared 40 percent, bringing the official 1989 rise in the cost of living to a record 4,923 percent. The two figures bode poorly for the government of President Carlos Menem, which is implementing its fourth austerity plan since Menem came to office in July and promised to sell off inefficient state-owned industries, cut the burdensome budget deficit and steady the national currency. But the austral, the national currency, slipped Monday against the U.S. dollar to 1,650-1, down from 1,400-1 last Friday. The austral, which replaced the inflated peso, traded at parity with the U.S. dollar when the government of President Raul Alfonsin introduced it in 1986. The sudden devaluation of the austral two weeks ago ignited the latest price hikes of 100 percent and more in most supermarket and department stores. Last February the austral traded at 17-1. January inflation is expected to be at least 40 percent also, said Moises Iconikoff, planning secretary at the Economy Ministry. Analysts said the fall in stock prices, the steepest in percentage since 1949 for the exchange's 16 major companies, was in part because of the shortage of australs in circulation. Last week, the government's latest economic team decreed a cutback in the amount of australs it would allow to be printed to reduce supplies of the national currency and force up the value of the austral. Economic indicators however continue to deteriorate. Real wages are about half their level of a year ago, and investors continue to put their earnings in dollars, a traditional haven for Argentines in time of economic uncertainty. Total volume Monday on the stock exchange, as usual, was low: about 6.3 billion australs, or $3.9 million. In an economy where inflation has been triple-digit in 14 of the last 15 years, few people invest in stocks to protect their money, and few companies count on the market to raise funds. The market, last open on Dec. 28, was closed two days for national holidays, two days by bank holidays and two days by its board of directors, which feared a sell-off due to the austral shortage. The independent news agency Diarios y Noticias said the stock market plunge of 53 percent was a ``historic session that had no precedent.'' The Board of Business Wholesalers in a statement said the economic situation was ``a crisis that is almost terminal,'' and urged the government to cut the national budget deficit. Inflation in 1989 was the worst Argentina has experienced since 688 percent in 1984. The economic convulsions are taking on political and social dimensions. On Friday, telephone workers staged a demonstration in front of the state company Entel's headquarters to oppose the government's plan to sell the company. The hoped-for sale of Entel, the state carrier Aerolineas Argentinas, the state railroad and other money-losing public companies is the heart of Menem's plans to steady Argentina's economic situation. Meanwhile, critics said the latest stabilization plan will exacerbate an existing recession, and the low level of wages might touch off food riots and social unrest. Such unrest convulsed this country in May and June. ``The intention to combat hyperinflation with hypermonetarism will only end in hyperrecession,'' predicted national deputy Jesus Rodriguez, who served briefly as economy minister during the 1983-89 Radical Civic Union government of Alfonsin. Alfonsin's election ended the military's nearly seven-year reign. The military has intervened six times since 1930 to cut short Argentine governments.

DOC.HEAD: Winds Whip West, Snow Covers West Virginia
DOC.TEXT: High winds whipped the Northwest on Monday, blowing trucks off highways and snapping tree limbs and power lines, and thick snow blanketed West Virginia and northern Virginia. Unusually large snowflakes fell in West Virginia, the National Weather Service reported. ``It's just unbelievable,'' said meterologist Dan Houser said. ``I've never seen flakes this big. I've seen some today maybe 3 inches long and an inch and a half wide. ``The conditions for these humongous snowflakes to develop has to be exactly right: temperatures, moisture, wind,'' Houser said. Strong winds that buffeted the Northwest over the weekend continued Monday with winds gusting to 90 mph near Pinehurst in northern Idaho; 76 at Pendleton in northeast Oregon; 72 at Casper in central Wyoming; 70 at Reno, Nev.; 68 at Scottsbluff in western Nebraska; and 58 at Broomfield, Colo., north of Denver. The Umatilla Bridge crossing the Columbia River in northeast Oregon was closed Monday when a truck was overturned by wind gusts. There were numerous reports of wind damage to building, power lines and trees in the area. Three cars and a truck were blown off a highway near McCammon in southeastern Idaho. Winds blew a 4-by-4 foot hole in the roof of a school gymnasium at Cheyenne, Wyo., Central High School. No one was hurt. The National Weather Service posted warnings for gale force winds along the northern Pacific Coast. Wind warnings were also issued for southeast Washington state, Idaho, parts of Montana, southeast Wyoming, northeast Colorado and the Nebraska panhandle. Rain was forecast for West Virginia but snow fell instead, up to 9 inches in Charleston. Snow advisories were posted for parts of West Virginia, Maryland, and Virginia, Pennsylvania and central New Jersey. Rain stretched from much of Maryland and Delaware across the remainder of Virginia and over northern North Carolina. Rain mixed with snow was scattered over north-central Minnesota. Rain fell MOnday across northwest Utah. High temperature records were set Monday in Duluth, Minn. (44 degrees), Eau Claire, Wis. (46), Miami (86), Reno, Nev. (62), and Sacramento, Calif. (66). St. Cloud, Minn., with a 46-degree reading, broke the record of 45 set in 1900. The nation's low in the Lower 48 states was minus 3 in Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 25 degrees at Limestone, Maine, to 86 degrees at West Palm Beach, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: COMECON Faces Radical Overhaul or Disintegration
DOC.TEXT: COMECON, seemingly left behind by the reforms in Eastern Europe, will face radical changes when its leaders meet here Tuesday in a bid to save the Soviet-dominated trading bloc from disintegration. The two-day conference of the 10-nation organization, which includes the seven Soviet bloc countries, Cuba, Mongolia and Vietnam, is the first after last month's ouster of Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and the decline of Communist power elsewhere in Europe. Founded in 1949, COMECON _ the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance _ aimed to ensure the Marxist members' economic growth so they could match or even outshine the West. But 41 years later, COMECON, largely because of the unwieldiness of central planning and the absence of profit-based enterpreneurship and vision, needs a radical overhaul or it will crumble. Critics say COMECON is nowadays nothing more than a means for its member states to survive the free-market evils of an increasin7lE competitive world economic system. The bloc isn't held together by Socialist solidarity, they say, but by Eastern Europoai countries' inability to earn enough hard currency to buy energy and raw materials from anywhere but the Soviet Union.
