DOC.TEXT: If it's ``Love Letters,'' it must be Lynn Redgrave. Or was it Colleen Dewhurst, Elaine Stritch, Swoosie Kurtz or Stockard Channing? And was she joined by Richard Thomas, Jason Robards, Christopher Reeve or Cliff Robertson? A different cast starred each week in the A.R. Gurney play on and off-Broadway, an idea its producers hope to continue as the two-character comedy-drama multiplies in other productions across the country and perhaps heads for London later this year. More than 60 performers appeared in the play during its New York run that began last Valentine's Day at a special benefit performance starring Kathleen Turner and John Rubinstein and ends today after a 3-month engagement at Broadway's Edison Theater. In between there were twice-weekly performances at the Promenade Theater off-Broadway that later became eight shows a week before the move to the Edison. But it's not the end for the play, which looks at a man and woman _ two upper-class WASPs _ through their letters to each other from the ages of 7 until they are about 60. _A company is now playing in San Francisco, where the actors rotate every two weeks. Among the performers playing there have been Polly Bergen, Robert Vaughn, Alexis Smith and Fritz Weaver. _Another troupe opens in Boston on Feb. 20 for seven weeks with seven different casts. _Also in February, ``Love Letters'' will be performed Sundays and Mondays at the Pasadena Playhouse in California with a regular run scheduled to start in a Los Angeles theater in mid-March. _A Chicago company is also under discussion, as is a national tour in the fall. Richard Frankel, who produced the play with Roger L. Stevens, Thomas Viertel and Steven Baruch, describes that as unique. ``We're going to be booking the show into normal Broadway road houses,'' he says. ``For example, we might do two weeks at the Kennedy Center or two weeks in Philadelphia or a week in Lexington, Ky., but they won't necessarily be continuous, and they might be overlapping, and they almost certainly will be with different actors.'' It would be an unconventional tour for an unconventional play that playwright Gurney insists must be read, not acted, by its stars. ``These are two lovers who communicate through their letters,'' Gurney says. ``They are both liberated and trapped in their own mail. When they get together physically, with one exception, it's normally bad. The letters are the windows through which they wave at each other.'' The play can be performed almost anywhere. It requires no scenery and only a few props _ a table, two chairs, two small lecterns, a water pitcher and two glasses. The actors even wear their own clothes. ``Love Letters'' was first done at the New York Public Library in March 1988 with Holland Taylor and Gurney himself reading the play. ``I was supposed to make a speech at the library but told them I wanted to do the play instead,'' he recalls. ``Since it runs longer than a speech, I broke it into two parts and told everybody they could leave if they wanted to. Nobody seemed to want to, so I knew the play interested people.'' If the show has a minimum of props, it has required a maximum of effort behind the scenes to cast each week. ``The hardest part of the New York production was that it was like an opening every week,'' says Frankel. Linda Wright works for Frankel as an assistant but she took over casting chores for the New York run as well as the out-of-town assignments. ``The most difficult thing is getting the right people together,'' she says. ``You can't do it with a much older man and a much younger woman. These people supposedly went to school together.'' Originally, most of the New York casts were in their early 40s and stretched into their 50s. But it has been done successfully by younger actors such as Timothy Hutton and Elizabeth McGovern. The actors all got the same amount of rehearsal time, one three-hour afternoon session in Frankel's office with director John Tillinger going over the play. Tillinger read through the play with the newcomers each week. ``The two stars don't have approval of their other halves,'' Frankel says. ``Sometimes we start with a pair. We approach them both at the same time. Sometimes we'll talk to one person, and they will suggest partners. It's a friendly negotiation process.'' John Rubinstein had never met Stockard Channing before they did ``Love Letters.'' He had done the show before with Joanna Gleason; Channing had performed it with Bruce Davison. They both had other commitments and arrived at the theater 40 minutes before the curtain went up. ``They barely had time to say hello before going to work,'' Frankel says. A few husbands and wives also have done the play _ among them Nancy Marchand and Paul Sparer, as well as Lynn Redgrave and John Clark. Word is now out among the acting community about what an excellent showcase ``Love Letters'' can be for a performer. ``Actors like to do it because it's a good way for producers and agents to get a look at what they can do,'' Frankel says. The commitment for only a week appeals to many performers who have family or long-range show business commitments. Some of the actors have appeared in different cities and may work again on the various tours. Robert Vaughn and Polly Bergen did it in San Francisco and then did it in New York. Lynn Redgrave and John Clark, having performed the play in New York, also will work in San Francisco. ``The thought of doing material this good and not having to learn it was fabulous,'' Redgrave says. ``Plus the play was something that my husband and I could do together after all these years. We haven't acted together since we met 23 years ago.'' Frankel insists the play stays remarkably the same even with its different performers. ``Because it is a new cast every week who are directed by the same director, I think it has strayed less than a normal show does during a long run,'' he says. ``There is someone going back to the book every week, instructing the actors how it is to be done. ``Having said that, the show is totally different with different people doing it. Liz McGovern and Timothy Hutton will be different from Jason Robards and Colleen Dewhurst. Everybody brings their own experience to it.'' By the time ``Love Letters'' finishes its journey around the country, there will be a lot of alumni. The New York alumni already have a souvenir. Each received a very preppy crew neck sweater for their week's work.

DOC.TEXT: Richard Chamberlain's Hawaii-based medical series is undergoing cosmetic surgery to make it more attractive to the audience. In the near future, his character of Dr. Daniel Kulani in ``Island Son'' will spend more time away from the hospital and become more involved with people. The CBS show also has new opening credits and new music. That went into effect when ``Island Son'' moved from Tuesday to Thursday in mid-December. ``When we go back into production after the first of the year we'll open up the show and spend more time out of the hospital,'' says Chamberlain. ``You'll see those changes around February.'' Chamberlain says this will take ``Island Son'' closer to its original concept of a man who was educated in modern medicine yet still honors the Hawaii traditions and folk medicine of his upbringing. ``These are things we've been asking for for a long time,'' he says. ``The drop in the ratings seems to support me. Now everyone has the same idea. The interesting thing to me as an actor is the human side, not the medical drama. I think people have seen enough faulty gall bladders and hematomas. ``Even doctors have a life outside the hospital, which may come as a surprise to some people. I'll be involved in closer relationships with the residents, and some surprising things will happen in my life. My ex-wife is going to come back and cause me some severe emotional difficulties.'' Besides family and human relations, the show will have fast cars and martial arts. Chamberlain is no stranger to hospitals, of course. His first and only other series, ``Dr. Kildare,'' was one of television's earliest and most successful medical dramas. Since that series in 1961-66, Chamberlain made a name for himself as a classical actor in England, starred on Broadway, made a number of feature films and became the king of television miniseries. He was interviewed during a visit to the mainland while ``Island Son'' was temporarily out of production. Even before starting the series he had moved to Hawaii. ``I've always wanted a house by the sea. Everything I looked at in Malibu was impossible; you can't get into Malibu for less than $3 million. I found this place in Hawaii. It's beautiful and off the beaten track. After doing a miniseries it was a place for me to go and recuperate. It's very healing and soothing.'' The actor says he's been traveling consistently for 25 years and ``wouldn't have missed a second of it.'' But he adds: ``I wanted to put down some roots. I wanted to stop living out of a suitcase. Besides staying put, another reason I wanted to do a series was that I wanted to be involved on the production side. I'm co-executive producer of `Island Son.' That makes the job even more interesting for me.'' The miniseries Chamberlain has done have taken him all over the world. ``Centennial'' landed him in Colorado, ``Shogun'' in Japan, ``Wallenberg: A Hero's Story'' and ``The Bourne Identity'' in Europe and ``Dream West'' in the American West. ``The Thorn Birds,'' an Australian story, was the only one Chamberlain made in California. Two films, ``King Solomon's Mines'' and ``Allan Quartermain and the Lost City of Gold,'' took him to Africa for many months. Recently he went back to Spain, where he had done ``The Three Musketeers'' and ``The Four Musketeers,'' for ``Return of the Musketeers.'' He plays Aramis. Chamberlain's Hawaii-based show had been in development for a long time. There were extensive delays in finding a suitable writer. Nigel and Carol Evan McKeand, who had done ``Family,'' were signed as executive producers only five weeks before production began. Chamberlain would like it much better if the writing and production staff would move to Hawaii but he knows that will never happen. ``It's difficult to grasp the feeling of the islands if you've never lived there,'' he says. ``Our original idea was somewhat different from what's been seen so far. We were going to have more of Hawaii itself in it and more of its healing arts. Kulani is a man who was adopted by a traditional Hawaiian family and raised in this culture. ``I think the first script stressed that too much and Lorimar Television and CBS got anxious. So we're bringing that back. We didn't intend to be so confined to the hospital. We're opening that up.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, Jan. 14, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Economic Woes Cause Education Crisis in Brazil
DOC.TEXT: Years of national economic decline have plunged Brazil's educational system into a crisis that officials fear will deprive the country of the brainpower needed to ensure social stability in the future. Illiteracy is creeping back up, the student dropout rate is rising and schools are forced to close for lack of money. Schools that survive are turning out ill-informed, unskilled graduates, the officials say. A small elite of college graduates, frustrated by shrinking job markets, is fleeing the country to pursue post-graduate degrees and jobs in the United States and Europe, a brain drain expected to hinder Brazil's development for decades. Dr. Paulo Alvim, secretary general of the Education Ministry, estimates that the deteriorating system will ``adversely affect the quality of the labor pool and slow the nation's progress in scientific fields.'' ``The educational deterioration has a devastating social impact,'' Alvim added. ``Young people are losing touch with society and their leaders, leading them into the black holes of drugs, alcohol and crime. By allowing our school system to deteriorate, we are in effect creating a marginal population that will eventually strain the government's social programs.'' The rising cost of education, even though teachers' salaries remain low, is another area of difficulty. Last year, students protesting tuition increases clashed with police in major cities. ``The system simply can't get any worse than it is now. We've hit absolute rock bottom,'' said Fatima Cunha, secretary general of education in Rio de Janeiro state. According to a United Nations survey, Brazil, which has the Western world's eighth-largest economy, has one of the highest illiteracy rates in South America _ 27 percent in 1988, up from 25 percent in 1986. It is believed to have risen even further in 1989. Brazil, a nation of 150 million people, had been making headway against illiteracy. According to Alvim, illiteracy in Brazil had been declining progressively since 1872, when the rate was 83 percent. Fifty percent of the population was illiterate in 1950. In 1960, 40 percent of Brazilians were illiterate. A UNICEF study released in December said Brazil had the seventh highest grade school dropout rate in the world, behind only Haiti, Yemen, Chad, the Central African Republic, Bangladesh and Burma. It said only 23 percent of pupils completed grade school in 1985-87, although the law requires children to remain in school until they are 18. About 27 million elementary school students are attending private and public schools. Nationwide, only 3.4 million students attend public and private high schools and 1.5 million are enrolled in private and public universities. A recent survey by the Brazilian Institute of Public Opinion and Statistics found other dark spots in the educational system: _Eleven percent of high school teachers have not finished grade school. In several states in the poor Northeast, the rate is 40 percent. _Nearly three-quarters of the country's school buildings are unfit for use. Blame for the crisis is placed essentially on Brazil's plunge since the mid-1970s into the worst economic crisis in its history. It now has a $110 billion foreign debt, a 1,765 percent annual inflation rate and an economy in stagnation. The government spends just 2.8 percent of revenue on education _ roughly the equivalent of $9.8 billion _ compared with an average of 4 percent in the rest of Latin America. The U.S. federal outlay for education _ not counting state and municipal expenditures _ was about $22 billion for 1988. Even though Brazilian government outlays for education already were low, officials recently cut by 40 percent the money allocated for public universities and special education programs. And federal funds often get lost in huge state bureaucracies and never reach the classroom, Secretary General Cunha of the Rio ministry said. President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello, a conservative who takes office March 15, has pledged to build schools and spend more on education. But with 90 percent of federal revenues now earmarked for government employees' salaries, there isn't much likely to be available anytime soon for schools. Grammar and high school teachers in major cities earn the equivalent of $100 a month. In outlying areas of the poor Northeast, such as in the village of Jerumenha in Maranhao state, grade school teachers make just $6 a month. Many teachers give extra night classes to make extra money. Others sell perfume, jewelry and jeans in school hallways during class breaks. ``It's hard to look your students in the eye afterwards,'' said Maria Luiza de Vitergo, 29, a high school history teacher. ``You're supposed to be their role model _ not a peddler.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, Jan. 14, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: RIO DE JANEIRO: a peddler.''
DOC.TEXT: Private schools, often packed with 50 students to a classroom, lack desks, chairs, blackboards and chalk. Rarely do all students get the same editions of textbooks, if they are available. Still, private school tuition shot up 524 percent from January to June last year, three times faster than the inflation rate. Students across the country held protest marches, and TV news reports almost nightly showed riot troops clashing with teen-agers. Spiraling tuition costs have led to an exodus of students from private to public schools, further straining the system. In Rio de Janeiro's upper middle-class Flamengo district, half of the once-reputable Amaro Cavalcanti high school building was condemned because of cracked walls and ceilings, electrical failure, rats in classrooms and broken stairways, said Angela Blemiro, the public school's principal. However, classes are still held there. Last year, strikes by teachers and school employees brought classes to a halt for up to six months in some states. In the southeastern state of Sao Paulo, strikes forced the state's Education Council to give 1,800 students high school degrees without their having completed the term. ``There were no teachers to give classes,'' explained Wagner Rossi, the Sao Paulo state Secretary General of Education. ``The students cannot be penalized for that.'' The miserable wages and long work hours discourage teachers from giving their best, said Francilio Pinto Paes Leme, general secretary of the 25,000-member Teachers' Union in Rio de Janeiro. ``A mediocrity pact exists between professors who fake teaching, students who fake learning and school employees who fake working,'' said Solange Ikeda, president of the Federal University of Mato Grosso state. Most dropouts leave school to help support their families, in a country where 73 percent of the work force makes less than $180 a month. The squeeze also makes college education impossible for all but the elite. As a result, some 4 million students nationwide are resorting to home radio and TV courses and earning grade school and high school equivalency diplomas through the mail. One program on Globo TV, the nation's largest network, offers courses at 6:30 a.m. and 8:30 p.m. to allow high school students who work to study at home. At semester's end, final exams are mailed to the Education Ministry for grading. The program has one of the network's highest ratings, said Jose Renato Monteiro, president of the Roberto Marinho Foundation, created by media tycoon of that name. ``TV is helping to bypass the crisis by filling a gap in the educational system,'' Monteiro said in an interview. ``It's a poor country's solution to an old problem.'' Proponents of education reform are pushing state governors to decentralize city schools from the national network, raise teachers' salaries, impose stricter standards for teachers, and rebuild schools, especially in the impoverished countryside. ``Education can be improved here,'' said Paes Leme of the teachers' union. ``It's a question of learning to set priorities straight.''

DOC.HEAD: Role Models Resurrected To Lead Chinese Down Communist Path
DOC.TEXT: Saints, martyrs and spirits have been brought to life as China's leaders try to teach their people to be good Communists in these times of sinking fortunes for communism around the world. The role model _ selfless, hard-working, plain-living and loyal unto death _ is a time-honored educational tool in Communist China. Now, as China's hardline leaders seek absolute allegiance to a system where absolutes no longer exist, the party has again called on its paragons to lead the way. They are a counterweight both to the anti-party, pro-West sentiments of the crushed pro-democracy movement of Tiananmen Square last spring and the political changes that have swept Eastern Europe. Some, like perfect soldier Lei Feng, perennially return at times of ideological strife. Others, such as the young martyr Lai Ning, are newcomers to the party pantheon. There are also ideals, such as the ``spirit of Yanan,'' that hark back to a simpler day when party leaders sought to serve rather than corrupt and young people dedicated lives to socialist idealism rather than Western materialism. These are a few of the legends now in vogue: LEI FENG Nearly two decades after his death, Chinese today offer blood, sweep streets and give free haircuts in the name of peasant soldier Lei Feng. Lei, who according to a children's song ``walks 1,000 miles and does 1,000 good deeds,'' was killed in 1962 at age 22 when he backed his truck into a utility pole. But a year later Chairman Mao Tse-tung proclaimed him a Communist saint in the first of many campaigns titled ``Learn from Lei Feng.'' According to legend, the fervent patriot secretly washed the clothes of his comrades, donated his savings to help peasants hit by floods and once gave his coat to a woman and her child during a freezing rainstorm. For his latest reincarnation, the People's Liberation Army has distributed 300,000 copies of his diary ``with a view to launching a new upsurge in the army on learning from Lei Feng.'' The PLA Daily, newspaper of the People's Liberation Army, said some supporters of ``degenerate Western bourgeois concepts'' have tried to denigrate Lei by saying he's outdated. But it added: ``If all soldiers can be like Lei Feng, have unparalleled loyalty to the party and the people, and give matchless love to socialism ... then our army will become an indestructible steel Great Wall.''

LAI NING He died at age 14 in 1988 while trying to put out a forest fire near his home in northern China. This past October he headed a list of the nation's 10 best Young Pioneers, a party-led youth organization, and was described by the party's official newspaper, People's Daily, as ``a flaming torch'' of revolutionary spirit. Among the attributes praised about Lai is one that he hoped to be a geologist so he could excavate precious metals from mountains around his home and ``contribute to our motherland.'' ``Study the hero Lai Ning'' meetings are being held across the country. The city of Beijing has issued a book, ``The Heroic Youth Lai Ning,'' and has organized ``Study Lai Ning Detachments'' in schools.

MODEL WORKERS Last fall 2,000 model workers were assembled at the Great Hall of the People for the first national ceremony in three decades to honor such exemplars of labor. The official press, meanwhile, is filled with tales such as the one of ``Sweeper Uncle'' Jiang Daoping, a retired colonel and war hero who shot down seven enemy planes in the Korean War but took a job as a janitor at Shanghai's Tongji University after retiring. His daughter, worried she couldn't get a boyfriend with her father in such a lowly position, tried to dissuade him, but Jiang reportedly replied: ``It is no shame to do whatever I can for the society. It will benefit both my body and soul.'' Then there is ``Flying Li'' Songzhi, a policewoman who at 52 still leads a task force against pickpockets. ``Riding the bicycle at full speed, I can keep up with a bus when a thief is riding on it,'' she is quoted as saying. ``In so doing, I feel that I have regained my youth.'' Another is Qiu Tiandao, a young army medic who reputedly is so skilled at acupuncture that he uses both hands to stick needles in two patients at the same time. ``It's my happiest thing to see the sufferings of the patients eased under my hands.''

LEARN FROM DAQING This common call during the ultra-leftist 1966-76 Cultural Revolution refers to the perseverance of those who built the nation's largest oilfield in the wastelands of northeastern China. Wang Tao, head of China National Petroleum Corp., pledged at ceremonies this past fall to mark the 30th anniversary of the Daqing fields that he would initiate a campaign to revive the Daqing spirit. He said: ``This is necessary to clear away the influence of serious mistakes made by Comrade Zhao Ziyang.'' Zhao was purged as the Communist Party last June for supporting Western liberal ideas. State-run television is now showing a nightly drama depicting the feats of ``Ironman'' Wang Jinxi, another revolutionary hero who refused to give up his quest even after experts said there was no oil under the frozen plains of what was to become Daqing.

THE SPIRIT OF YANAN Yanan, in the dusty hills of northwestern China, was Mao Tse-tung's revolutionary base for 13 years in the 1930s and 1940s when the Red Army was fighting the Japanese as well as Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists. Young Chinese are now told to emulate the spirit of those days, when Mao and the other Communist leaders lived in caves and worked among the Yanan peasants. ``The Yanan spirit is the national treasure of the Chinese people,'' the People's Daily said. ``During the Yanan period, the whole party established the good tradition of hard work, and the style of plain living was in particular advocated.'' A recent exhibition on the ``Spirit of Yanan'' in the provincial capital of Xian was said to have been seen by 100,000 students. One student wrote in the visitors' book: ``University students in the 1980s should study the Yanan spirit and let the spirit blossom in radiant splendor in them.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, Jan. 14, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Food Emergencies Again Threaten Ethiopia And Sudan
DOC.TEXT: War and nature's caprice are conspiring to create food shortages that again threaten millions of people with starvation in Ethiopia and Sudan. Drought and the depredations wrought by two long civil wars have imperiled as many as 4 million people in northern Ethiopia, according to relief officials there. Similarly, in neighboring Sudan where as many as 250,000 died of hunger in 1987-88, a resumption of fighting in a 6-year-old civil war has raised fresh fears of another famine despite an extensive and, by all accounts, successful United Nations-led relief operation last year. Men at war, not nature, have become the biggest threat to those in need, with governments and guerrillas preventing a helpful international community from getting food to hungry peasants. Holding back the relief effort in Ethiopia is the government's resistance to delivering food to people behind rebel lines in the rebellious province of Eritrea and most particularly in the province of Tigre, leaving an untold number of people beyond the reach of aid agencies. Diplomats and relief workers fear that if a way is not found to feed these people, Ethiopia could suffer a repeat of the great famine of 1984-85 when as many as 1 million people died. ``It has the potential if nothing is done about it,'' said David Morton, the U.N. World Food Program's representative in Ethopia. ``If food is not gotten in there in some way, everyone is concerned we'll have a famine situation resulting from a drought situation,'' said Morton. ``We can't say how many would die because we still don't know how many are affected, but clearly very large numbers.'' The United Nations has appealed for an initial 700,000 tons of emergency food aid, about a third of which has been pledged by foreign donors. More food may be needed if later assessments show the situation worsening. Morton says his agency recently began moving 60,000 tons to distribution points in the northernmost province of Eritrea, much of which still remains in government hands. Tigre, Eritrea's southern neighbor, is the main problem, Morton says. The province, home to an estimated 2.6 million people, is entirely in rebel hands and consequently inaccessible to relief agencies. The rebel Tigre People's Liberation Front, which has been fighting since 1975 to oust President Mengistu Haile Mariam, gained control of its home province early last year. Since August, the rebels have made their greatest gains, pushing southward and westward into neighboring provinces and moving ever closer to Ethiopia's capital, Addis Ababa. Ethiopia has conscripted hundreds of thousands of men to fight the Tigrean rebels, who pose the greatest military threat to Mengistu's government. Relief officials nonetheless say they are encouraged by the government's recent request that several indigenous relief and church agencies study ways to get food to those behind rebel lines in Tigre and report on their findings. However, there is the lurking fear that the government is not sincere about wanting to feed those it considers the rebels' support base. Limited amounts of food can be moved to Tigre through neighboring Sudan. But aid officials express a concern that if food shipments are not begun soon, peasants will begin long and treacherous walks across embattled barren territory in search of food at government-sanctioned distribution centers outside Tigre. Weakened by their migration and lack of food and unable to return home, the peasants could create vast overcrowded and unhygenic famine camps similar to those of 1984-85 in which more people died of disease than of starvation. Similar fears surrounded the 1987-88 relief operation when crop failures also threatened millions with starvation. But during that emergency, the government still had control of some of Tigre and much of Eritrea and food got through to those in need before mass migrations began. ``We can't avoid drought, but we can avoid famine,'' Morton said. Long-term prospects, however, are not encouraging. ``We've got a situation of increasing population year after year and stagnant production of food,'' said one aid official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The long-term outlook on present trends isn't good.'' In southern Sudan, the resumption of fighting between the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army and the government has derailed relief efforts credited with averting a repeat of the 1988 tragedy. Observers say the nearly 100,000 tons of food ferried into the embattled region between April and November through ``corridors of tranquility'' staved off widespread death. Both warring parties declared a series of cease-fires to permit the shipments. However, that informal truce broke down in late October when fighting flared. And in early November the government declared a ban on all relief flights, saying it wanted to investigate the aerial bombing of a rebel-held town. The Sudan rebels have no planes. Bombings have continued in many southern towns being helped by the United Nations and the government, never happy about food being given to areas under the rebels' control, has accused relief workers of delivering arms, ammunition and spare parts under the cover of humanitarian aid. Although Sudan's military leadership has promised a conference to consider allowing the resumption of relief flights, aid workers fear the worst. ``Unless we continue our efforts through the next season, southern Sudan could fall back to a life-threatening situation,'' said Vincent O'Reilly, spokesman for the U.N.-led Operation Lifeline Sudan. Ironically, nature has provided the region with plenty of rain. Given tools and seeds, the peasants could grow nearly twice as much food this year as was delivered by the emergency operation, O'Reilly said. In its second phase, he added, Operation Lifeline Sudan planned to deliver $2 million worth of seeds and hand tools. But the fighting has made this impossible, leaving the region in a perilous state, he said. The food deliveries ``have maintained people in place,'' O'Reilly said. ``We have not addressed the underlying agricultural problem and the impact of the war.'' ``Unless we do, we could face a return to a famine situation.''
