DOC.HEAD: Automakers Cater to Today's and Tomorrow's Elderly Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Large digital instruments are in and tiny buttons are out as aging drivers command more attention from automakers as they design and market cars for a swelling segment of the driving population. The number of licensed drivers over 65 grew by 45 percent, from 14.3 million in September 1978 to 20.8 million in September 1988, according to the most recent figures from the Federal Highway Administration. Older drivers account for 12.7 percent of the total licensed drivers on the road. That's a market segment automakers can't ignore. ``I think it will be one of the greatest opportunities that they've got,'' said Jim Wangers, president of Automotive Marketing Consultants Inc. of Vista, Calif. Reflecting the importance of the market, Chrysler Corp. decided to switch the bulk of its undisclosed advertising budget for Chrysler cars to print from broadcast media, in part to attract older buyers, said Jim Jandasek, manager of Chrysler-Plymouth national advertising. ``Print, with the media consumption patterns of the mature market, is going to deliver more of those people.'' About 70 percent of Chrysler brand advertising is dedicated to print media, dramatically more than other automakers. A key reason for buying more print ads this year was because advertising the engineering features of 1990 model Chryslers is more suited to print than broadcast, Jandasek said. Advertising for General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. are along more traditional, broadcast-oriented lines. Print ads for full-size cars, the most popular among senior citizens, are targeted at media reaching those consumers. Advertising, however, is irrelevant if the product doesn't suit the buyer. And that goes for any age. Automakers are carefully watching trends as the ``baby boomers,'' born in the late 1940s and early '50s, mature. The look of American cars popular with older drivers is changing with them. When Ford introduced a redesigned Lincoln Town Car in August, traditional hard edges on the fenders, the bumpers and the roof were gone. Chrysler will be smoothing out its cars targeted for senior citizens in a few years. For now, it is sticking with a proven winner with older drivers. During the introduction of the 1990 Imperial, a squared-off full-size car, Chrysler executives said they were aiming the car at a loyal segment of the market that shuns rounder, less traditional-looking cars. That will change in the mid-1990s when the company introduces cars made with smoother lines offered on some Ford and GM cars of today. The changes are inside, too. Dave Rees, interior design director for Ford, said research is telling him what older people want. ``If we think about the mature driver, the primary area would be ergonomics _ the layout of controls, the location of controls and the ease of operation,'' he said. ``They have very set tastes,'' Wangers said, ``and I think they are going to be very difficult to get off of their traditional thinking.'' Many of those senior-oriented features are obvious _ wide-swinging doors; a minimum number of buttons, switches and knobs; and familiar location of some controls, especially headlight switches. One recent development has caught on with senior citizens: ``Mature drivers tend to prefer the large, easy-to-read electronic clusters,'' Rees said. Don Massey, owner of Don Massey Cadillac Inc., in Plymouth, Mich., says he likes the big displays on the Cadillac Brougham. ``I'm 61 years of age and for the first time in my life, I've wondered why numbers on telephones aren't larger,'' Massey said. ``I think the psychological impact of the larger readout on the Brougham is welcome to the older driver.'' The Brougham, the longest of all Cadillacs, has a larger digital speedometer display than other models.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Jan. 11, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: New Service Opens World of Television to Blind
DOC.TEXT: For millions of visually impaired Americans, televisions are little more than over-sized radios _ worse, really, because of Hollywood's heavy reliance on visual images to propel plots. ``I'm about as totally blind as you can get,'' says Dale Lamar, vice president of a support group for the blind in Oklahoma. ``Most shows I can keep up with fairly well. But when you get into an action show with lots of car chases and shootings, you end up missing half the show.'' But imagine a TV show where narrative is sprinkled between the dialogue, describing the stealthy movements of a murderer, the outcome of a chase. That's the vision of Jim Stovall, president of Narrative Television Network. ``I started losing my sight when I was 17,'' Stovall said. ``I'm 31 now and totally blind. About a year and a half ago, I was watching an old Bogart film and somebody shot somebody else and I was lost. ... I thought with a little bit of narration, this could work. It just kind of exploded on us.'' The network's programs have been shown at 11 a.m. and 11 p.m. EST every Sunday since Aug. 20. They can be seen on the Nostalgia Channel, available in about 7 million homes, and on independent stations in 500 cable markets. The narrated network uses Nostalgia's production facilities in Dallas. Nostalgia Network Inc., which sees its prime market as older viewers, is a natural partner for NTN. Demographers say 60 percent of the 11.4 million visually impaired Americans are older than 45. ``We feel that narrative television has enhanced our value as a cable channel,'' said Joe Schramm, Nostalgia marketing director. ``The cable operator has a commitment to the community to provide a service, and this certainly is a service.'' There are few advertisers, in part because Nostalgia broadcasts movies uninterrupted. ``We are just now approaching some national advertisers,'' said Stovall. ``Adapting commercials isn't as big a problem as people would think. A lot of radio commericals are just television commercials without the picture.'' He has won support from such Hollywood legends as Kirk Douglas, Katharine Hepburn and Charlton Heston, and has been praised by cable magnate Ted Turner, important since Turner acquired the rights to the MGM Library. Currently, the network narrates public domain films or those to which Nostalgia has acquired rights. Last month, it broadcast Frank Capra's ``It's a Wonderful Life.'' ``The way we narrate these programs,'' Stovall said, ``is to try and determine what is important and present that to you as unobtrusively as possible without interjecting our opinion.'' In the premier narrated episode of ``Matlock,'' featuring Andy Griffith as an Atlanta lawyer, a man stalks a young woman and stabs her to death. The first dialogue, though, comes minutes into the plot _ after the stabbing and just before the woman's boyfriend is arrested in her death. The narration fills the void: ``The silver-haired man pulls a long knife from its holder,'' the narrator says. ``His face is drenched with sweat. ... As the young man showers, the silver-haired man enters the bedroom holding the knife. ``The young woman stirs awake, sees him and begins to scream. He puts his hand over her mouth. He stabs her.'' Lamar, who rented the episode on videotape, said that until the narrated version, the show was difficult to follow. ``There's nothing but music for the first three minutes or so. If it wouldn't have had the narration, I would've missed the fact that Dick Van Dyke was the killer.'' While the network is a boon to the blind, supporters point to another group sure to benefit, Schramm said. ``It's also for the visually impaired who have a spouse or family members or loved ones whose lives have been taxed or tied to the visually impaired because they had to interpret these shows.'' The Narrative Television Network is a spin-off of Narrative Video Network, a 1988 innovation that coupled narration with popular TV series on videotape. ``We did `Matlock,' `Big Valley,' `Andy Griffith,' `Gomer Pyle,' '' Stovall said. ``The response was so huge, we couldn't get enough tapes out or do enough to keep everybody happy.'' Response to NTN is difficult to express, he said. ``The reaction has been very emotional. If you've never seen television _ it's very difficult for someone like yourself to understand _ to be able to sit and watch television is a very emotional experience for most people.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Jan. 11, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Narrative TV Brings American Institution to the Blind
With BC-PRI--Narrative Television
DOC.TEXT: Here is a sample of the narrative from the Narrative Television Network's premiere of ``Matlock,'' starring Andy Griffith: ``Our story opens in a high-rise building. A young man and woman stand in a darkened bedroom kissing passionately. ``A silver-haired man in a business suit stands across the street viewing the couple through binoculars. He puts the binoculars down and walks across an empty living room. ``Episode Entitled `The Judge.' ``He puts on a raincoat, a tweed hat and sunglasses. The silver-haired man walks out of the building. He uses a key to enter the back door of the other building.'' Sound of a door closing. ``The young couple in bed: The silver-haired man, no longer wearing the sunglasses, pulls on black gloves and walks along a hallway. ``He uses a key to enter the apartment, steps inside, closes the door and pauses to take a breath.'' Suspenseful music. ``In the kitchen, the silver-haired man pulls a long knife from its holder. His face is drenched with sweat. The young couple lie in bed kissing. ``The silver-haired man holding the knife waits. ``The young man kisses the young woman. He leaves the bed and enters the bathroom. ``As the young man showers, the silver-haired man enters the bedroom holding the knife. The young woman stirs awake, sees him and begins to scream. He puts his hand over her mouth. ``He stabs her. She falls limp. ``The young man continues to shower. ``In the hall outside the apartment, the silver-haired man, no longer wearing the tweed hat and overcoat, sets down a brown garbage bag. He uses his handkerchief to pick up a phone.'' ``Lobby, Hobson speaking.'' ``Get up to 1102 right away. There's a woman screaming for help. Something terrible has happened. Hurry.'' ``He hangs up the phone. ``The young man walks out of the shower, sees a bloody knife on the floor in the bedroom. He bends down and picks it up. He sees the young woman covered with blood.'' Sound of a doorbell. ``A security guard uses his key to enter the apartment. He sees the young man holding the bloody knife and the young woman's lifeless body. ``The young man drops the knife.''

DOC.HEAD: Make a Resolution You Can Stick To _ Eat Healthy
DOC.TEXT: Jane Weston Wilson is the author of the lifestyle cookbook ``Eating Well When You Just Can't Eat the Way You Used To,'' Workman Publishing.

As a child, believing in magic, I thought if I wrote down New Year's resolutions it was the same as doing them. ``Don't talk back to your grandmother, brush your teeth, practice the piano every day after school...'' As adults, the same belief in magic may hold true, especially when it comes to resolutions involving health and fitness. Go on a strict diet! Get to a gym! Such promises often are made as we reach for a third chocolate mocha truffle or savor a second piece of Aunt Sara's Oyster Loaf while watching the bowl games. There's no doubt few of us get through the holidays without overdoing. But there are other occasions for splurging: birthdays, bar mitzvahs, anniversaries, travel, a favorite restaurant... Do we go on the teeter-totter route of dieting, then putting the weight back on? Or do we develop a new style of eating that maintains a healthy weight over a lifetime, even when metabolism slows and it is easier to gain weight and harder to lose it _ a way of eating that allows for special times to splurge and makes every day the occasion for feasting lightly. My solution is not to deprive ourselves of good food. That never works. It is simply to change portions and proportions. Choose two-thirds of your food from the Vegetable Kingdom _ grains, beans, vegetables and fruits, abounding in color, variety, vitamins and minerals _ and one-third from the Animal Kingdom: meat, fish, fowl and dairy products, with more calories from fat and cholesterol. By becoming aware of this simple formula when we plan meals and shop, the healthful balance is achieved without having to count calories, a resolution that soon goes by the board. Following are three recipes that use this formula, one you can easily adapt in your own cooking.
DOC.HEAD: Thai Shrimp or Chicken with Cashews (Serves 4)
Ingredients:
DOC.TEXT: { pound cooked shrimp, finely chopped, or { pound cooked chicken, finely chopped 1 cup finely chopped scallions 1 cup peeled and shredded carrots 1 cup finely chopped Chinese or regular cabbage \ cup finely chopped cashews 2 teaspoons corn oil 1 teaspoon sesame oil 1 teaspoon curry powder { teaspoon ground cumin salt and freshly ground pepper, to taste

1. In a medium bowl, combine the shrimp or chicken with the scallions, carrots, cabbage and cashews. 2. In a large saucepan over medium heat, heat the oils. Add seasonings and saute one minute, stirring. 3. Add the shrimp or chicken mixture and saute until heated through, about five minutes. 4. Transfer to a serving platter and serve hot. Leftovers can be served hot or cold.
DOC.HEAD: Skillet Fish on a Bed of Peppers and Onions (Serves 2)
Ingredients:
DOC.TEXT: { pound firm fish fillet such as scrod, cod, salmon, halibut, weakfish or sea bass, washed and patted dry 2 tablespoons freshly squeezed lime juice \ teaspoon dried leaf thyme 1 teaspoon unsalted butter 1@3 cup finely chopped yellow onion 1@3 cup finely chopped green pepper 1@3 cup finely chopped red pepper { tomato, coarsely chopped 2 slices of lemon with rind, coarsely chopped 1 tablespoon coarsely chopped fresh basil or snipped dill for garnish

1. In a medium glass bowl, place the fish, lime juice and thyme. Marainate for a half-hour at room temperature or an hour in the refrigerator. 2. In a medium skillet over low heat, melt one teaspoon butter. Add the chopped onions and peppers and saute until translucent, about three to four minutes. 3. Add the fish, cover and cook for about seven minutes or until the fish flakes with a fork. 4. Add the tomato and lemon and continue cooking for two to three minutes longer. 5. Transfer to a serving platter and serve hot. Note: This dish can also be prepared with chicken instead of fish, and you can add other seasonal vegetables for color and variety.
DOC.HEAD: Robusto Pasta and Chicken Salad with Red and Green Peppers
DOC.TEXT: (Serves 2)=
DOC.HEAD: Ingredients:
DOC.TEXT: 2 cups cooked fusili { pound poached boneless chicken breasts cut into cubes 1 medium sweet red pepper, seeded, cut lengthwise into {-inch-wide slices and then cut into thirds 1 medium green pepper, seeded, cut into {-inch-wide slices, and then cut into thirds 3 scallions, peeled and finely diced 4 ounces pitted black olives
DOC.HEAD: Dressing
DOC.TEXT: \ cup olive oil \ cup freshly squeezed lemon juice 1 teaspoon oregano 1 tablespoon snipped fresh dill

1. In a large bowl, combine the cooked pasta, chicken, peppers and scallions. 2. In a small bowl, whisk together the dressing ingredients. Pour over the salad and mix. 3. Serve at once or refrigerate, covered, until serving time.

DOC.HEAD: Catalog Time's Here _ Sit Back, Enjoy the Wonders
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: George Bria retired from the AP in 1981 after 40 years that included coverage of World War II from Italy.

It's catalog time for gardeners, the season to sit back and enjoy this year's parade of matchless wonders and breeding triumphs. I once needed only one catalog to fuel my dreams. Now I've gotten choosy, leafing through a half-dozen before I decide which tomatoes, beans and lettuce will grace my garden come summer. There's a catalog for everyone, some quite artistically illustrated, and you learn where to look for special things. The Tomato Growers Supply Co., of Fort Myers, Fla., for example, offers 170 tomato varieties plus 41 peppers. For a foreign touch, numerous catalogs will bring Europe or the Orient to your backyard _ among them, Thompson & Morgan, of Jackson, N.J.; The Cook's Garden, of Londonderry, Vt.; and Shepherd's Garden Seeds, of Felton, Calif. Not to be outdone, such a venerable seed house as W. Atlee Burpee & Co., of Warminster, Pa., now has an international vegetable section in its catalog. A catalog buff can unlock the gate to just about anything in a wide-ranging volume by Barbara J. Barton of San Francisco, ``Gardening by Mail.'' Published by Tusker Press, it lists more than 1,200 nurseries and seed companies and more than 300 garden supply and service companies in the United States and Canada, indexed by plant, product and location. For some of us, nothing equals nurturing our own tomato plants from tiny seeds to fruit-laden glory. But we're becoming a diminished breed. More and more are foregoing the seed catalogs and opting for ready-to-go plants. Much gets sacrificed in this choice. Variety, of course, suffers. But the joy of gardening itself seems diminished. To a purist, growing from purchased plants is like painting from numbers, putting a roll in the pianola or wearing snap-on bow ties. Pure snobbery, you might say, with more than a little justification. The nursery-acquired plant still needs tender loving care _ fertilizing, weeding, watering. Experts familiar with gardening trends see many causes behind the phenomenon. Nona Koivula, executive director of the National Garden Bureau in Willowbrook, Ill., which promotes gardening from seed, says time-saving is a prime reason for picking up a flourishing flat at the nursery instead of a seed packet. In tomatoes, you save three months of work by buying plants ready to set in the ground. Also, home vegetable gardens have shrunk dramatically in size. A Gallup poll for the National Gardening Association, of Burlington, Vt., showed the typical plot nowadays reduced to 200 square feet from 595 square feet 10 years ago. Trimmed-down gardens just don't have room for multiple varieties. And the number of vegetable gardens also declined, from 33 million to 31 million. In the 1980s, ``people found there were more bullish investments than a vegetable plot in the backyard,'' the association's magazine said. Whether the garden is small or large, tomatoes remain the overwhelmingly favorite crop, followed by peppers, onions, cucumbers, beans, lettuce, carrots, corn, radishes and cabbages, the poll showed. Curiously, broccoli, a powerhouse nutritionally and easy to grow, doesn't rank at all in backyard popularity. Every year, catalogs abound in new and improved varieties, each introduced with a drumroll of amiable hype. Breeders appear to be concentrating on disease resistance, with more and more maladies conquered by stalwart new entries. People who think flavor is bred out this way can find seedhouses that specialize in heirloom varieties. Or scan seed-swapping sections of gardening magazines on the chance of discovering an old-time favorite offered for trade. Now and then, studying the catalogs produces a winner. A couple years ago, I found a broccoli called ``Romanesco,'' which takes a long time to mature but climaxes in a glorious chartreuse head, cauliflower texture and great taste. You won't see it in the supermarket and it's not likely to show up at the nursery. You've got to raise it from seed. But it's not really ``new.'' A bit of research showed it's an heirloom Italian variety just now appearing in U.S. catalogs.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Jan. 11, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Divorce Could Leave Many Older Women Poorer Than Today
DOC.TEXT: A greater share of elderly women will be divorcees in future years and they generally will have fewer financial resources than older women who are married or widowed, researchers say. ``Older women living outside marriage, especially those who are divorced, experience much lower standards of living than married women,'' Teresa Cooney, Peter Uhlenberg, and Robert Boyd, of the University of North Carolina, reported in the January issue of the Journal of Gerontology: Social Sciences. Divorcees are less likely to have owned their own homes, have fewer assets to fall back on and may lose assets accumulated during years of marriage, they said. A historical study of divorce rates indicates that a much larger proportion of those reaching old age in the future will have been divorced, they said. One woman in eight will have her first marriage end in divorce after she reaches 40, with the probability of remarriage after divorce declining sharply with age, the study said. In 1985, for example, fewer than 3 out of 100 divorced women aged 45 to 64 remarried during the year. ``If current rates persist, only a minority of women who enter midlife divorced, or who divorce after midlife, will ever remarry,'' Uhlenberg, Cooney and BoydWhile espousing free trade and open markets, the president also promised ``to maintain a safety net to protect farmers from conditions beyond their control.'' The president promised Florida farmers they can count on the federal government's help in recovering from the ``terrible loss'' of their citrus and winter vegetable crop from last month's freeze. ``You won't be doing it alone,'' he said. Bush said farmers have bounced back from trying times in the 1980s, with help from the 1985 farm legislation that led to lower federal crop subsidies and more land in production. ``Surpluses have declined dramatically, and most of of good land has been brought back into production,'' he said. ``Net farm income reached a record level last year. ... The farm credit situation has greatly improved, bringing more financial stability to rural America.'' But Bush added that market-oriented farm policies ``are only a part of the agricultural picture. We've got to expand markets and enhance productivity. We've got to assure the public that America's food is the safest in the world, and we've got to protect our precious environment.'' ``We must recognize that productive agriculture and a sound environment can be compatible, especially in terms of water quality,'' the president said. The administration has already initiated a five-year effort to protect groundwater from contamination by fertilizers and pesticides running off farms, he said. ``We must keep your good land in business _ without unreasonable burdens _ but we must also keep it good land,'' he said. ``I am counting on your leadership as we work to expand farm productivity while safeguarding the environment.'' Without giving details, Bush said the administration also is drafting legislation ``to protect the food supply without overwhelming the agriculture industry.'' He noted that farmers have a major stake in U.S. efforts to foster free trade, including its recent ``bold proposal in the Uruguay Round'' of international trade talks that would phase out export-subsidies in five years and other trade-distorting practices in 10 years. ``Any agreement we sign will be an agreement that's also good for American agriculture,'' he promised. Bush toured high-tech agriculture and ocean exhibits at Walt Disney's Epcot Center nearby before his return to Washington. The trip was Bush's first public appearance since ex-Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega surrendered last Wednesday to face trial in the United States on drug-trafficking charges. It comes as U.S. officials acknowledged they are having ``some difficulties' arranging an increased role for the U.S. military in the Caribbean off the coast of Colombia to help intercept drug smugglers' sea and air routes. Bush, asked Sunday as he went jogging about reports that the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and other ships were steaming toward Colombia, said, ``I will address myself ... to that question at a future date.'' When a reporter suggested that Colombian officials were upset, Bush said, ``We don't know all that.'' National security adviser Brent Scowcroft said discussions with Colombian authorities have not begun, and White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said today: ``I think the problem is we haven't had a chance here to really explore it with them.'' However, Bogota's El Tiempo published a communique Sunday by the government of President Virgilio Barco that said the Colombian ``government has not participated, nor will it participate, in any joint operation with United States military forces, air or naval, in the Caribbean Sea.'' ``In international waters it has not participated, nor will it, and in territorial waters it has not authorized (the operations), nor is it considering authorizing them,'' the statement added.

The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent last month as gains in service industries offset the ninth consecutive monthly drop in manufacturing jobs, the Labor Department said. The steady civilian jobless rate, which ended 1989 just under the level where it began, gave private analysts hope Friday that the economy's current sluggish growth will not worsen into a recession.

Orders to U.S. factories for manufactured goods reached their second highest level in November, the government said. Analysts said Friday the report showed the longest peacetime economic expansion is continuing. ``This confirms our expectations that the economy won't drop into a recession,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an economist with WEFA Group, a forecasting organization.

Stock prices in the Far East fell sharply on the news that Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev had canceled foreign engagements to deal with domestic worries. But the jitters Friday were less severe in other world markets. In Tokyo, the 225-share Nikkei index tumbled 600 points before recovering to finish 438.12 points lower at 38,274.76. The decline measured 1.1 percent and was the worst showing since Oct. 16, when the key index lost 647 points.

Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. denied ``with all my heart and soul'' that he used a tax-sharing arrangement at his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association to siphon off $94 million. The arrangement between the now-collapsed thrift and its holding company, American Continental Corp., is a centerpiece of regulators' contention that Keating was illegally using Lincoln as a ``piggybank'' for his massive real estate ventures. Testifying Friday on his suit seeking to overturn the government's takeover of the $6 billion thrift last April, Keating said the tax arrangement was intended only to bring stability to the various subsidiaries of his empire.

West German automaker BMW AG is ready to move service and used-car sales networks into Eastern Europe as the Iron Curtain crumbles, company officials said. The moves are the first steps the automaker plans to take before setting up manufacturing sites in any of the newly emerging non-Communist countries, BMW Chairman Eberhard von Kuenheim said Friday.

American Express Co. said it will receive a $200 million cash infusion from Nippon Life Insurance Co., strengthening an alliance between the two financial services giants that began more than two years ago. Under terms of their agreement announced Friday, Nippon will purchase American Express exchangeable preferred shares, which can be converted at any time to American Express common stock at a share price of $42.50. Should Nippon exercise those rights, as well as a warrant issued in 1987 allowing it to purchase 2 million American Express shares at $50 apiece, the Japanese insurance giant would have a 1.6 percent stake in American Express.

Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. won a reprieve as the Western Australian Supreme Court dismissed a government petition to liquidate the media, brewing, natural resources and real estate empire. The court ruled Friday against the State Government Insurance Commission, which had asked the court to appoint a provisional liquidator for Bond Corp. on the grounds that the company controlled by financier Alan Bond was insolvent. A judge ruled that the insurance commission had failed to prove its claim.

The Agriculture Department announced the rates for advance federal payments when farmers begin to sign up for 1990 crop programs later in the month. Keith Bjerke, executive vice president of the department's Commodity Credit Corp., said Friday the advance payments will be reduced by 1.4 percent as required by the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989.

Socialism is not to blame for China's poverty, and the nation will eventually triumph over its capitalist rivals, the Communist Party daily newspaper said. The lengthy commentary Friday in the People's Daily came less than a month after a small group of university students, in a bold gesture of dissent, unfurled a banner in front of the state television station reading ``Motherland, why are you so poor?'' It is also part of a government propaganda campaign to convince the populace that China must stick to the socialist road, suppress political dissent and reject the reforms now sweeping Eastern Europe.

Stock prices declined Friday in the face of economic uncertainties and worries over political developments in the Soviet Union. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 22.83 points to 2,773.25. The dollar staged a turnaround, closing mostly higher in domestic dealings. Prices of long-term government bonds sank on new inflation fears. Heating oil futures prices plunged more than 5 cents a gallon for the second straight day; orange juice futures and precious metals were sharply higher; pork futures surged while cattle futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Poling: Ford Opting for Air Bags Rather Than Automatic Belts
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. will give up on automatic seat belts by the mid-1990s, opting instead for air bags in all of its cars for drivers and front-seat passengers, Vice Chairman Harold Poling says. ``All of our tests have shown that when the passenger is properly positioned with the active belt plus the use of the air bag, it provides the greatest protection in the event of an accident,'' Poling said Sunday night at a news conference. His comments came before he spoke to the opening session of an annual industry meeting sponsored by the trade weekly Automotive News. Currently, Ford offers air bags on about half of its 2 million or so car fleet. Chrysler Corp. makes driver-side air bags standard on all of its North American-made cars, and General Motors Corp. has the devices as standard equipment on about 15 percent of its fleet. By the 1993 model year, federal regulations require automakers to have so-called passive restraint systems in place for drivers and front-seat passengers, whether they are air bags with manual seat belts or automatic seat belts and no air bags. The government required that cars made after Sept. 1, 1989, be equipped with either a driver-side air bag used in conjunction with manually operated seat belts for front-seat riders, or automatic seat belts. As the automakers were introducing their 1990 model cars, they announced price increases of up to 5 percent over 1989 prices, blaming most of the boosts on the safety devices. Direct comparisons of the cost of an air bag and an automatic seat belt system are difficult because of the wide variety of vehicle designs. However, air bags cost more to install and replace than do automatic seat belts. Poling said he didn't know how much it would cost to equip Ford's entire automobile fleet with driver- and passenger-side air bags by the mid-1990s. He estimated, however, it would add $400 to $600 to the cost of making each car, about half of the cost of air bags now. Poling, who on March 1 succeeds Donald Petersen as Ford's chairman, also said that the company doesn't plan any major acquisitions in the near future. During the second half of 1989, Ford spent nearly $6 billion to acquire the British luxury carmaker Jaguar PLC and the Associates Corp., a financing company. However, Poling said Ford's 25 percent stake in Mazda, the Japanese automaker which which it jointly makes cars, may grow. ``If the opportunity occurred over time to increase our equity position with Mazda,'' Poling said, ``we would look at it favorably.'' In his speech, Poling said the European auto market shows more potential for growth during the 1990s than does the North American market, with projected increases of 1.5 percent and 1 percent, respectively. That, combined with increased production capacity, adds up to a rough decade for automakers. ``The combination of excess capacity and slow growth in the automotive market will present a severe competitive challenge for car and truck manufacturers around the world,'' he said. However, Poling said, automakers should have the chance to crack newly emerging markets, including Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Corp. Willing To Listen to American Businessman
DOC.TEXT: Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. is willing to hear from an American businessman who announced over the weekend that he wanted to take control of the Australian company, a spokesman for the troubled holding company said. Bond Corp. executive Peter Lucas said Sunday the company ``looked forward to the next communication'' from Jeff Reynolds but added that so far the proposal was lacking in detail. On Saturday, Reynolds, 28, announced in Los Angeles that he was prepared to invest $250 million in Bond Corp. and in return take control of the company, whose Australian brewing interests are now in the hands of receivers. Bond Corp. also owns G. Heileman Brewing Co. of La Crosse, Wis. He said he was confident he could refinance the company's $6 billion debt and would talk again with millionaire businessman Alan Bond, who has controlling interest in Bond Corp., once the Victorian Supreme Court hearing into the receivership is over. In a telephone interview Sunday in Houston, Reynolds said he planned to travel to Perth in coming weeks to discuss details of the bid with Bond. ``I'm scheduled to go back over to Perth shortly to work out definitive agreements,'' Reynolds said. ``This is something we've been working on since September.'' Reynolds, chairman of Los Angeles-based Weatherby Investments, said he has been in Houston for several months visiting relatives. He said California Pacific International Holdings Co. Pte Ltd., the Singapore-based parent firm of Weatherby, had been interested in buying Bond Corp. for some time. ``We had been looking for a lot of opportunities,'' Reynolds said. ``We had a manager in Singapore who had some relationship with Bond and we opted to pursue that.'' A report in Saturday's London Times said Reynolds got the idea for a Bond Corp. takeover from California Pacific's managing director, Chew Chin Han, a friend of Australian businessman Kerry Packer. Reynolds said in the interview with The Associated Press that he believed Bond's brewery interests remain healthy. ``We're willing to inject some capital into it and we're also willing to restructure some of their debt,'' Reynolds said. ``This is part of our long-term goals. We hope to develop some financial services there in Australia and in Asia.'' But he declined to disclose any other investors involved in the project ``until we've got things sewn up.'' Reynolds said Weatherby's main interests included oil, gas and financing. A London broker who was not identified in the Times report said his company's Far East office was baffled by Reynolds' interest. ``We have had people studying Singapore for eight years,'' the broker was quoted as saying. ``They know all the companies, listed and unlisted. But they haven't heard of California Pacific, Weatherby or Jeff Reynolds.'' In other developments Sunday, Lucas said an urgent weekend meeting with U.S. creditors to its brewing empire had been inconclusive. The lenders of the $650 million credit facility met in New York on Saturday with Bond Corp. executive Peter Mitchell who urged them not to put Bond Brewing Holdings into liquidation. Speaking on an Australian business television program Sunday, Lucas said the talks were attended by 70 percent to 80 percent of the creditors, which include major investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Bank of Boston. ``There was not much progress out of the meeting, (but) lots of questions were asked, lots of questions given,'' Lucas said. He said the creditors had been asked to wait until the end of January for a deferred interest payment of $41 million, which has been frozen by the Victorian Supreme Court, a state court in Australia. The creditors demanded immediate repayment of their loan Friday and indicated they would support the decision by National Australia Bank on Dec. 29 to put the brewing arm into receivership. Bond Corp. has challenged the receivership, with the Victorian Supreme Court scheduled to begin the second week of hearings Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Bank Of New England Negotiating Sale Of Operations To Fleet-Norstar
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. reportedly is close to selling some of its operations in several states to Fleet-Norstar Financial Group Inc., The Wall Street Journal reported today. Bruce P. Crooks, a spokesman for Fleet-Norstar, which reportedly has been negotiating with Bank of New England, declined to comment on the report when reached at home early today. J. Terrence Murray, the bank's chairman and chief executive, could not be reached by telephone at home or at the office. A Bank of New England spokeswoman also declined to comment, according to the Journal, which cited an individual familiar with the talks for its information. Fleet-Norstar is seeking to buy Boston-based Bank of New England's operations in Maine and southern Massachusetts, and possibly Connecticut, the newspaper said. Negotiations continued last week with the final scope and terms uncertain, it said. Although Fleet has consumer loan offices in Massachusetts and a branch in downtown Boston that serves primarily as a commecial loan production office, ``we've had interest for a number of years in Massachusetts,'' Crooks said. Fleet-Norstar has been stymied by the failure of the Massachusetts Legislature to pass a bill that would allow banks from outside of New England to expand in that state. Fleet, because of a 1988 merger, has extensive banking operations in New York state that technically make it a non-New England bank under current Massachusetts law. Fleet ran into a similar problem in Connecticut, but an order that it divest United Bank has been put on hold while a legislative committee studies the entire issue of interstate banking, said Robert W. Lougee Jr., Fleet's director of corporate communications. He also refused to comment on any possible deal with Bank of New England or to discuss any timetable for conclusion of the talks. Bank of New England last month said it expected to post a large loss for the year, with $1.6 billion in non-performing assets, mainly bad real estate loans. Both it and Fleet-Norstar have assets of about $31 billion, but Fleet-Norstar has managed to avoid the region's severe real estate lending problems and its nationwide financial services operations have provided a more stable earnings base. The Journal said its source indicated several possible structures for the deal are being considered, including one in which Fleet-Norstar would receive a stake in Bank of New England in return for a capital infusion and another using securities whose value would depend on the future financial performance of the purchased operations.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Lower at Midday
DOC.TEXT: London share prices were lower at midday Monday, pushed down by a lack of buying interest and concern over the short-term direction of British stocks. With no clear lead emerging from the stock index futures market, attention focused on the volume of buy orders, which were significantly below recent levels. Cautious British weekend press comment on the market's prospects, combined with a number of downgradings on specific stocks, persuaded the market to retreat. By about noon London tine, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index stood 13.5 points, or 0.6 percent, lower at 2,431.0 points, well down from an earlier high of 2,445.6 points. At its lowest during the morning, the index dipped to 2,429.2 points. ``The market is in a rather delicate position,'' said one dealer. ``It can't decide if it is headed higher or at the beginning of a significant downward correction.'' Volume amounted to 209.0 million shares by midday, compared with 277 million shares at the same time Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Soup Heir Restates Desire for Continued Independence
DOC.TEXT: The daughter of former Campbell Soup Co. Chairman John T. Dorrance Jr. has reaffirmed her vow to fight any attempt by rival family shareholder groups to sell the food industry giant. In a statement released Sunday by their New York law firm, Mary Alice Malone and her husband, Stuart, owners of about 10 percent of the company's outstanding stock, confirmed their ``commitment to the continued independence of Campbell Soup Company.'' ``We have always considered our investment in Campbell to be long-term,'' said the statement attributed to Ms. Malone. Signs of a possible rift in the Dorrance family, which has controlled the Camden, N.J.-based company for nearly a century, has fueled speculation that major stockholders are split on the issue of whether to sell the company. Ms. Malone, a company director, and her two brothers, John T. Dorrance III and Bennett Dorrance, together hold about 31 percent of the company's outstanding shares. In recent weeks, a group comprised of Dorrance cousins has announced its intention in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission to press for a sale of the company. Last week, Campbell filled its long-vacant top spot by hiring David W. Johnson, former head of Gerber Products Co., as its new chief executive officer. ``We are extremely excited about David W. Johnson's immense managerial talents and his contagious enthusiasm,'' Ms. Malone's statement continued. ``In particular, we are inspired by his proven track record of dealing successfully with the myriad of complex intangibles that arise in very large family-held companies.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.TEXT:
Editors:
Citibank and First National Bank of Chicago say they have reduced their prime lending rate to 10 percent from 10.5 percent. A story slugged PM-Interest Rates will move within 10 minutes.
AP Business News

Stock prices were broadly lower today, but blue chips steadied as some major banks lowered their prime lending rates. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 293 up, 726 down and 462 unchanged. By contrast, the Dow Jones average of 30 big-name industrials edged up .64 to 2,773.89 in the first half hour of trading. Volume on the Big Board came to 22.59 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The First National Bank of Chicago and New York's Citibank reduced their prime rates this morning from 10.5 percent to 10 percent. They were the first major banks to take that step, which had been predicted intermittently since late last fall as the Federal Reserve moved gradually to relax its credit policy. The prime is used as a reference point from which interest rates on numerous types of loans are calculated. But while the news came as a psychological lift to the market, analysts said it didn't allay all the Street's new worries about where interest rates are headed in the future. Open-market money rates, which reflect the most current sentiment among investors and would-be lenders, were little changed to moderately higher in today's activity. Pacific Telesis rose { to 48\ in active trading. The company announced a new program to buy back as many as 25 million of its shares. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .38 to 194.26. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .51 at 381.94. On Friday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.83 to 2,773.25, reducing its gain for the week to 20.05 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 3 on the NYSE, with 573 up, 936 down and 453 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 158.53 million shares, against 177 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau Reportedly Abandons Attempt to Sell Bloomingdale's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout to include denial of story by Campeau spokeswoman, add details.
DOC.TEXT: A Campeau Corp. spokeswoman today denied a report that the company has abandoned its three-month effort to sell its Bloomingdale's department store chain. ``As far as we know, this report is wholly unfounded,'' Campeau spokeswoman Carol Sanger said. The Canadian retail and real estate company, which has said it might seek bankruptcy court protection for its U.S. retailers, has changed its mind about selling the chain because it has attracted only inadequate offers, the Financial Times said in today's edition, quoting unidentified financiers closely involved in Campeau's restructuring. Campeau was believed to be seeking around $1.5 billion for Bloomingdale's, a well-known 17-store chain. Toronto-based Campeau revealed in September that it was having financial problems and decided to put Bloomingdale's up for sale to raise cash. But offers have come in too low, partly because of the sluggish U.S. retailing sector and a glut of department stores on the auction block, the newspaper said. A committee overseeing a restructuring of Campeau apparently persuaded creditors that selling Bloomingdale's at a cheap price would only weaken Campeau's balance sheet and reduce its cash flow, the newspaper said. Campeau, headed by flamboyant financier Robert Campeau, burst onto the U.S. retailing scene by buying Federated Department Stores Inc. in 1988 for $6.6 billion, Bloomingdale's parent company, and Allied Stores Corp. two years earlier for $3.4 billion. Ms. Sanger, the Campeau spokeswoman, said the second stage of the auction process is under way. Campeau has previously said that no more than five or six finalists would advance to the second round bidding for Bloomingdale's. By the Dec. 8 deadline for initial offers, Campeau said it had received a number of expressions of interest. A definitive announcement on the sale was expected sometime in February. Separately, Ms. Sanger confirmed that the Campeau board of directors is meeting in Toronto today. She declined to comment on what might be discussed at the meeting and said she doesn't know of any announcements planned. The Wall Street Journal reported today that the board would be urged not to pay apparel manufacturers whose bills are due Jan. 10. The newspaper, quoting unidentified sources, said Campeau's banks and financial advisers oppose making the payments now because they believe it's just a matter of time before Campeau seeks protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code. ``What they're (the Campeau board members) urged is not the issue. What they do is the issue,'' Ms. Sanger said.

DOC.HEAD: Telecom-USA to Acquire ALC Communications
DOC.TEXT: Telecom-USA Inc. of Atlanta announced today it has signed a letter of intent to acquire Michigan-based ALC Communications Corp. in a cash and stock transaction worth about $97.1 million. Under terms of the proposed transaction, all outstanding capital stock of ALC would be converted into units of Telecom-USA common stock and cash. Those holding ALC common stock and series B and C preferred stock would receive Telecom-USA units worth $3 a share. Holders of ALC series A preferred stock would get units valued at $20 a share plus accrued unpaid dividends. ALC currently has 13.7 million shares of outstanding common stock, 2.5 million shares of series A preferred stock and 1 million shares each of series B and C preferred stock. The proposal is subject to a definitive agreement, regulatory and shareholder approvals and other conditions. Telecom-USA is the nation's fourth largest long distance company with 500,000 customers. ALC Communications, based in Birmingham, Mich., is the parent company of Allnet Communications, a nationwide company serving mainly the Northeast, upper Midwest and West. It serves 400,000 customers. Atlanta-based Telecom-USA was formed in 1988 from the business combination of two regional long-distance companies, SoutherNet of Atlanta and Teleconnect of Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Oppose Disbanding Comecon; Ryzhkov to Attend Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to insert that meeting to be in Bulgaria.
DOC.TEXT: Parts of Comecon are obsolete and need radical changes but the Soviet Union opposes disbanding the East bloc trade alliance as some nations have suggested, a Soviet spokesman said today. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov indicated what the Soviet response would be to appeals by Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland for a major overhaul of Comecon when it meets Tuesday in Sofia, Bulgaria. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov will lead the Soviet delegation despite his mother's recent death, Gerasimov told reporters. Gerasimov blamed poor implementation of good past decisions for many of Comecon's woes. ``There is no dynamism, there is no sign of improvement in the trade structure, there is no technological progress,'' he said. ``And so we believe there must be radical measures to restructure the mechanism of cooperation.'' But, he added, ``As far as the direct answer to whether we need Comecon or not, yes, we need it,'' Gerasimov said. Czechoslovak Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus said Thursday there was no reason for Comecon to exist. Polish Foreign Trade Minister Marcin Swiecicki echoed Klaus' views Friday, saying the organization was outdated and should be replaced by something less rigid. Comecon, which stands for the Council of Mutual Ecoomic Assistance, was formed under the guidance of the Soviet Union in 1949 and has since controlled trade among Soviet-allied countries. Its member nations are the Soviet Union, Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania and Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Three Silicon Valley Companies Introduce Machines that Use Unix
DOC.TEXT: Tandem Computers on Monday announced a new computer that uses Unix, a standard operating system for controlling internal housekeeping functions of computers. Tandem's action, along with similar announcements expected Monday from two other influential Silicon Valley companies, signals a key trend in the computer industry toward the use of Unix, analysts said. Unix allows customers to avoid being locked into buying proprietary hardware and software available from just one vendor. Tandem, the Cupertino-based company known for reliable ``nonstop'' computers, introduced its new Integrity S2 system, which will cost from $172,000 to $248,000. Capable of performing 12 million instructions per second, it is based on the R2000 chip from Mips Computer Systems and has three separate processors, allowing it to keep running if one fails. ``Buyers have tended to balk at using Unix-based systems for mainstream business purposes because they couldn't count on the systems being up and running,'' said Jeffrey Beeler, an analyst at Dataquest. ``It appears that Tandem has done the best job of addressing reliability problems.'' The other two companies are Hewlett-Packard Co. and Intel Corp. In addition, Sunnyvale-based MasPar Computer Corp. planned to debut a new class of machine Tuesday that approximates the power of a multimillion-dollar supercomputer at a fraction of the price. Palo Alto-based Hewlett-Packard was expected to unveil two computer workstations that use a new version of a Motorola microprocessor chip to perform 12 million instructions per second for a 50 percent increase for the HP product line. The desktop model will start at $8,995. Intel, the Santa Clara-based company widely known for microprocessor chips, is introducing new machines that can have from eight to 128 processors. But they can get hefty speed boosts from the powerful i860 microprocessor from Intel's 80386 used in personal computers. The systems range from $265,000 to more than $1 million. The largest configuration can perform 7.6 billion operations per second. MasPar, one of the best-funded computer startups in recent Silicon Valley history, was scheduled to unveil its MP-1 System _ a box 55 inches high and 23 inches wide, attached to a Digital MicroVax computer, that can perform up to 1.5 billion calculations per second _ all for $170,000 to $810,000. The Intel and MasPar machines link independent processing units together to address problems, resulting in tremendous speed. Similar machines have been used to help design nuclear weapons and break codes, and others are already used for financial analysis on Wall Street. Some observers expect them to become an important force in commercial computing. ``The MasPar and Intel machines represent the new wave in computing,'' said Gary Smaby, an independent computer analyst in Minneapolis.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Appeal by Movie Company in Antitrust-Related Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by a movie company that faces a $100,000 fine in an antitrust-related case. The court, without comment, refused to free Twentieth Century Fox Film Corp. from the penalty for a contempt finding against one of the corporation's regional managers. The case has its origins in 1938, when the Justice Department accused Twentieth Century and seven other major movie companies of violating federal antitrust law. The companies allegedly engaged in practices aimed at preventing small competitors from obtaining choice first-run films. One common practice, the government said, was ``block booking,'' in which theater owners were forced to accept less popular movies if they wanted to receive more popular ones. The government and the motion picture companies settled the suit in 1951 under a court-approved consent agreement barring the companies from engaging in illegal practices. But in 1988, Leila Goldstein, Twentieth Century's manager for Indianapolis, Milwaukee and Minneapolis, was accused of violating the agreement. She was charged, for example, with insisting that theater owners show the movie ``Black Widow'' if they wanted to run the more popular ``Mannequin.'' Ms. Goldstein was fined $5,000 for contempt, and Twentieth Century was fined $500,000 plus legal costs. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in August ruled that the movie company could be held in contempt for Ms. Goldstein's behavior even though Twentieth Century had taken steps to make sure its employees complied with the 1951 court order. ``It is this rule of vicarious liability that encourages companies to establish compliance programs,'' the appeals court said. But it ruled that the maximum fine that could be imposed against Twentieth Century without a jury trial is $100,000. The case is Twentieth Century Fox vs. U.S., 89-661.

DOC.HEAD: L.L. Bean Purchases Hampden Site; Building On Hold
DOC.TEXT: L.L. Bean is delaying plans to build a large distribution center because 1989 sales fell below expectations, a company spokesman said. The Freeport, Maine-sporting goods outfitter bought a 200-acre site in Hampden and announced in June 1988 that it would build there. Initial plans called for the center to be operational by 1992, and to employ 2,500 full-time workers and 200 to 300 seasonal workers during the Christmas shopping period. But plans have been put on hold, said spokesman D. Kilton Andrew Jr. ``Now we'll sit tight and see the lay of the land as far as our business growth goes,'' said Andrew. The distribution center in Hampden definitely will be needed at some point, he said. ``When we're ready, Hampden will be sitting there waiting,'' Andrew added. Andrew told the Bangor Daily News that Bean would do nothing at the site during 1990 and that he could not specify when development might occur. The Hampden site occupies the southern half of the 500-acre Ammo Industrial Park. Access to the site would be from a proposed road off U.S. Route 202 in Hampden. A 500,000-square-foot building planned for the site, which would cover about 11 acres, would be used to help handle Bean's mail-order business. Bean President Leon A. Gorman said previously that several factors led to selection of the Bangor-area site. ``The Hampden site has been developed for regional industrial use and is one of only a few in the state large enough for our facility,'' Gorman said. ``The site also has access to I-95 and to Bangor International Airport for expeditious receipt of merchandise and for rapid shipment of customer orders by truck or air.''

Stock prices declined slightly today in a muted response to cuts in the prime lending rate by several large banks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 1.07 to 2,772.18 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 528 up, 691 down and 525 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 47.23 million shares at midmorning. The First National Bank of Chicago and three New York banks reduced their prime rates this morning from 10.5 percent to 10 percent. They were the first major banks to take that step, which had been predicted intermittently since late last fall as the Federal Reserve moved gradually to relax its credit policy. The prime is used as a reference point from which interest rates on numerous types of loans are calculated. But while the news came as a psychological lift to the market, analysts said it didn't allay all the Street's new worries about where interest rates are headed in the future. Open-market money rates, which reflect the most current sentiment among investors and would-be lenders, were little changed to moderately higher in today's activity. Pacific Telesis rose \ to 48. The company announced a new program to buy back as many as 25 million of its shares. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .49 to 194.15. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .94 at 381.51.

DOC.HEAD: Futures Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices for grain and soybeans were mostly higher early in the session today at the Chicago Board of Trade. Analysts attributed the rise in wheat prices to news that China and the Soviet Union were buying more of the U.S. commodity. The U.S. Agriculture Department this morning confirmed rumors that China had bid for 300,000 tons of wheat and market rumors persisted that the Chinese would bid for an additional 300,000 tons. The Soviet Union was also said to be in the market for 500,000 tons of export bonus wheat. Also firming wheat prices were weather reports calling for mild conditions that would make the winter crop vulnerable to a cold snap, analysts said. Soybeans' advance was led by a soyoil rally as India returned to the Malaysian palm oil market, analysts said. Corn, which was steady to slightly higher, was supported by wheat trading, dealers said. In early trading, wheat was } cent to 2 cents higher, with the contract for March at $4.11 a bushel; corn was { cent lower to { cent higher, with March at $2.38 a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent higher, with March at $1.52, and soybeans were 1{ cents to 3 cents higher, with January at $5.66} a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle prices were mostly lower while pork complex futures continued their rally. In early trading, cattle were .35 cent lower to .35 cent higher, with the contract for February at 76.52 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent higher to .20 cent lower, with January at 84.55 cents a pound; live hogs were . .05 cent to .68 cent higher, with February at 51.50 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were 1.10 cents to 2.00 cents higher, with February at 55.47. On Friday, cattle prices were mixed, while pork complex futures soared higher.

DOC.HEAD: Court To Decide Television, Radio Licensing Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 4-14, The court also, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether the federal government may give special licensing preferences to television and radio stations owned by women and minority members. The justices said they will use a Florida case to review the Federal Communications Commission's policy of treating such ownership as a favorable factor in its licensing decisions. In a separate case from Connecticut, the court said it also will review the commission's policy of letting broadcast stations facing a license revocation sell the license, at a reduced price, to minority-owned firms. The court also agreed today to decide whether governors may withhold state National Guard units from peacetime training ordered by the federal government. The court said it will hear an appeal by Minnesota officials who opposed Central American training missions for the state's National Guard troops. The justices last April rejected a similar appeal by Massachusetts officials. In other action, the court: _ Refused to force a revival of the ``fairness doctrine'' and require radio and television stations to present all sides of controversial issues. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the Federal Communications Commission acted within its authority when discarding in 1987 the obligations it had imposed on broadcasters since 1949. _ Let stand a ruling that people have no constitutionally protected right to privacy when at home speaking on a cordless telephone. The court, without comment, turned away arguments that law enforcement agents acted unlawfully when, without obtaining a court warrant, they monitored an Iowa family's cordless-telephone conversations. _ Rejected the appeal of a Tennessee high school student pulled from a race for student council president after giving a speech officials deemed disrespectful. The court, without comment, let stand rulings that officials at Unicoi County High School in Erwin, Tenn., did not violate Dean Poling's free-speech rights. _ Agreed to review a dispute over how much welfare aid some needy families are entitled to receive. The court said it will hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at limiting the payments in a Virginia case. At issue are features of the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program. In conflicting rulings earlier this year, different three-judge panels of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here upheld the FCC's licensing preferences policy but struck down the so-called distress sale program. The FCC in 1986 began reviewing its policy of giving preferential consideration to firms owned by women and racial or ethnic minorities when awarding broadcast licenses. But in late 1987 then-President Ronald Reagan signed an appropriations bill in which Congress barred the commission from spending any money to continue its review of _ or make any change in _ its ``affirmative action'' policies. The congressional action also insulated from commission review its policy, adopted in 1978, of allowing bankrupt or otherwise troubled TV and radio stations to sell their licenses to firms owned by women or minorities. Such transfers, if approved by the commission, can be made without consideration of competing applications for the same license. The policy of giving firms owned by women and minorities preference over competing applicants for broadcast licenses was challenged by Metro Broadcasting Inc. after its 1983 application for a license to operate a new Orlando UHF television station was rejected. The license instead was awarded to Rainbow Broadcasting Co., owned by two women and a man, all Hispanic. An FCC review board said the minority and ``slight female ownership advantage'' enjoyed by Rainbow outweighed factors in Metro's favor. The commission's licensing decision was upheld by a 2-1 vote of a federal appeals court panel last April 21. On March 31, a different three-judge panel of the same court voted 2-1 to strike down the distress sale program. The appeals court ruled that Alan Shurberg and Shurberg Broadcasting were treated unfairly when the commission in 1984 rejected his attempt to get a license for WHCT-TV in Hartford, Conn., and instead allowed WHCT's owner, Faith Center Inc., to make a distress sale to Astroline Communications Company Limited Partnership. The appeals court ruled that the commission's action violated Shurberg's equal-protection rights, citing recent Supreme Court rulings that trimmed the scope of affirmative action programs. ``The distress sale policy is not narrowly tailored to remedy past discrimination because its effect is unrelated to the need for such a remedy,'' the appeals court said. ``It provides no procedures for ensuring that ... beneficiaries have actually suffered from the effects of past discrimination.'' The appeals acted on today were filed by Metro Broadcasting in the Florida case and Astroline Communications in the Connecticut case. Bush administration lawyers acknowledged that the rulings in the two cases are based on ``conflicting rationales'' but urged the justices to leave both rulings intact. They said the entire U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia should settle the ``intra-circuit conflict'' after President Bush fills three vacancies. About the Florida case, the government lawyers told the justices that Astroline Communications is in bankruptcy proceedings and ``might well not be able to hold the license for Channel 18 regardless of whether the distress sale at issue were ultimately upheld.'' They added that Congress recently held hearings on the soundness of the FCC's minority ownership policies and is set to review the FCC's minorities policies by next October. ``Where Congress is revisiting this complex and sensitive area of law, intervention by this court at this time is not necessary,'' the government lawyers said. The cases are Metro Broadcasting vs. FCC, 89-453, and Astroline Communications vs. Shurberg Broadcasting, 89-700.
