DOC.HEAD: Waterford Wedgwood Confirms Talks
DOC.TEXT: Financially troubled china and crystal maker Waterford Wedgwood Group PLC Monday confirmed it is holding talks that might lead to a cash offer for a major but not controlling interest in the company. Waterford Wedgwood shares gained 5 pence, or 8 cents, to 58 pence on London's Stock Exchange on the news. There has been widespread speculation for some time that Waterford has been searching for a minority shareholder to give it a much-needed cash infusion to help reduce some of the company's substantial debt. The likely suitor is Fitzwilton Holdings PLC, a medium-sized cash-rich Irish industrial conglomerate, said to be willing to take up to a 30-percent holding in Waterford Wedgwood, weekend press reports said. A spokesman at Fitzwilton who wasn't identified in accordance with British practice, declined to comment. However, Dublin-based sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that only Fitzwilton's chairman, Tony O'Reilly, and a group of high-powered investors have made an informal approach to the company. O'Reilly also serves as chairman and chief executive of Pittsburgh-based H.J. Heinz Co. Regardless of who takes up the stake, the sources said that about 120 million Waterford Wedgwood shares would be offered, or 30-percent of the company, at about 40 Irish pence, or 63 cents, a share, a deep discount from its current trading price of 62 Irish pence in Dublin. Waterford Wedgwood has been suffering from serious financial problems in recent years. An audit performed in late 1988 showed that accounting errors were made that significantly overvalued the company's inventories by up to $33 million. Waterford Wedgwood Chairman Paddy Hayes resigned after these revelations. The company also has suffered from a decline in retail demand for its products in the United States and Britain. The appreciation of the Irish pound against the dollar has hurt the company's fortunes. Last December, the company warned that its would suffer a significant pre-tax loss in the second half.

DOC.HEAD: Court, in NY State Case, Refuses to Revive Fairness Doctrine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf pvs, For years, to elaborate on fairness doctrine.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to force reinstatement of the ``fairness doctrine'' that required radio and television stations to present all sides of controversial issues. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the Federal Communications Commission acted within its authority in 1987 when it discarded the doctrine it had imposed on broadcasters since 1949. The fairness doctrine was based on the assumption that broadcast frequencies were less available than print media outlets such as newspapers, which never have been subjected to such requirements. For years, radio and TV could be punished _ even denied license renewals _ for violating the doctrine, which required that broadcast stations selling air time for the expression of one point of view on a controversial issue had to present contrasting views on that issue, either by selling ads or making free time available to groups with opposing views. The appeal acted on today stemmed from a fairness-doctrine complaint filed by an anti-nuclear group against Syracuse, N.Y., television station WTVH in 1984. The FCC said the station aired a series of editorial advertisements that described construction of a nuclear generating plant as a ``sound investment'' for New York without adequately presenting contrasting viewpoints. But the commission at that time had begun to question the permissibility of the fairness doctrine, and in 1987 concluded that forcing broadcasters to be fair violates constitutionally protected free-press rights and ``contravenes the public interest.'' The commission dismissed the complaint against the Meredith Corp., owner of WTVH. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here upheld the commission's action last Feb. 10 without reaching the issue of the fairness doctrine's constitutionality. Congress is considering legislation that would force the commission to revive the fairness doctrine by explicitly writing it into federal law. Similar legislation was vetoed in 1987 by then-President Reagan. President Bush has said he, too, would veto such a measure. The appeals court, agreeing with the commission in this case, ruled that nothing in the Communications Act of 1934 or its later amendments requires retention of the doctrine. Lawyers for the anti-nuclear group, the Syracuse Peace Council, said the appeals court ruling, if not reversed, would subvert ``the long-established public trustee concept for broadcasting.'' They argued that a 1959 amendment to the Communications Act gave the FCC no choice but to enforce the fairness doctrine. ``In that amendment, Congress specifically recognized that the public interest standard of the 1934 act embodies the bedrock fairness obligation,'' the appeal contended. Bush administration lawyers urged the high court to reject the appeal. They said the doctrine should not be enforced ``at a point when the commission determines that it has become counterproductive.'' The case is Syracuse Peace Council vs. FCC, 89-312.

DOC.HEAD: Big Banks Drop Prime to 10 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, The move ..., with two grafs to UPDATE with Manufacturers Hanover lowering rate and to separate banks taking action. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, The Fed ...
DOC.TEXT: Several big banks lowered their prime lending rate a half percentage point today to 10 percent, the first reduction in nearly half a year, signaling cheaper loans for a broad range of consumers and businesses. The move reflected the declining cost of money that banks have enjoyed in recent weeks, the result of a more liberal credit policy by the Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank. Citibank and First National Bank of Chicago were the first to cut the key rate. They were later followed by Morgan Guaranty Trust Co., Bankers Trust Co., Continental Bank Corp., Mellon Bank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. The Fed has been moving to ease interest rates recently in order to forestall a dramatic economic downturn. Lower rates encourage businesses and consumers to borrow money. The prime rate is a benchmark that many banks use to calculate a range of other popularly known loan rates, including variable rate home equity loans. ``To Joe and Joan Average Consumer who have some of their loans tied to short-term rates this is good news,'' said F. Ward McCarthy, an economist at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. ``Many people have home equity loans or car loans tied to the prime ... and monthly payments should go down by next month.'' The move today, effective immediately, marks the first time the rate has been changed since July 31, when banks lowered the prime to 10.5 percent from 11 percent. Most economists predicted other banks would follow suit by at least by Tuesday, saying today's move was long overdue. There was little reaction in the stock or bond markets, indicating that such a drop had been anticipated. ``It comes as no surprise. I think it was in keeping with current money market rates,'' said William V. Sullivan, an economist with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Sullivan said banks had the incentive to trim their prime just after Christmas when the Fed moved to lower the federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, to the 8.25 percent level. He said banks put off any cut in the prime because seasonal demands for higher cash reserves had pushed the fed fund rate above 9 percent. David H. Resler, chief economist for Nomura Securities Inc., predicted that most banks will have lowered their prime by Tuesday, after executives have had a chance to meet on the subject. However, McCarthy, said he wouldn't be surprised if some banks continued to put off any action or lowered their prime only a quarter of a percentage point. McCarthy said the so-called yield spread, which is the difference between banks' borrowing costs and the rate at which they lend their money, ``is not outlandish'' based on current economic conditions. After today's prime cut it fell to 1.75 percentage points from 2.25 percentage points based on current fed fund rates. McCarthy said that when the economy is sluggish it's not unusual to see the yield spread at around 2 percentage points. When the economy is expanding, banks can afford to keep their rates lower since loan volume is usually brisk, McCarthy explained. But as economic conditions weaken so do the need for loans, and that means banks make up for a lower volume by keeping rates higher.

DOC.HEAD: Twelve Indicted in Scheme To Avoid State Fuel Taxes
DOC.TEXT: A former vice president of a top Wall Street brokerage and 11 others were charged Monday with using money from an earlier fraud to organize a $1.1 million tax evasion scheme in upstate New York. Mark Stahl, who was sentenced to five years in prison in 1987 for mail fraud at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., and the others were charged with setting up companies that conspired to evade $1.1 million in state fuel taxes, said Nancy Connell, spokeswoman for Attorney General Robert Abrams. They were charged with enterprise corruption under an organized crime statute that carries a maximum sentence of 25 years in jail and fines. The alleged scheme involved several companies set up to deliver fuel to the Big Apple and Big M truck stops in the Albany suburb of Glenmont, Connell said. The defendants allegedly bought home heating oil and had it sold as diesel fuel at the truck stops, Connell said. Through this process, they avoided paying diesel fuel taxes, which are much higher than home heating oil taxes, she said. They also were accused of hiding from authorities the amount of diesel fuel they brought into the truck stops, evading still more taxes, she said. Stahl was convicted of transferring more than $1 million in Shearson funds to various bank accounts he controlled in 1986 and 1987. He admitted in court, however, to a much larger scheme involving more than $18 million. Money from that fraud allegedly was used in the heating oil scam, according to the indictment.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Lower
DOC.TEXT: Share prices fell Monday on London's Stock Exchange on disappointment that a January rally had failed to materialize. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index finished 13.2 points, or 0.5 percent, lower at 2,431.3 points. The high for the day was 2,445.6 points, the low 2,423.8. Volume was 396.4 million shares, compared with 471.5 million shares Friday. Many market watchers had expected stocks to jump higher in repetition of a 1989 New Year rally. Its inability to do so in 1990 has knocked some confidence out of the market, they said. In addition, dealers said pessimistic weekend press comment on the future prospects for stock prices depressed the market.

DOC.HEAD: Jaguar Appoints Two Ford Directors to Board
DOC.TEXT: Jaguar PLC said Monday that two directors of Ford Motor Co., which acquired the British luxury car maker in Nohouse, then an art teacher, said she had begun to detect a great deal of sexual and moral confusion in the minds of her students over what they had seen on TV. Her main target was the publicly financed BBC. Nearly a half-million people signed a petition in 1964 calling for closure of the BBC, accusing it of broadcasting ``propaganda of disbelief, doubt and dirt.'' The BBC stayed on the air, and barred Mrs. Whitehouse from its programs for 15 years. Its director-general at the time, Sir Hugh Greene, said years later that her only contribution had been to raise the national level of intolerance. Critics still accuse her of trying to be the nation's censor. ``Young people are not driven to excesses by explicit scenes of sex on the screen. She's a very sincere lady, but one of the most misguided,'' said Harry Turner, managing director of Television South West, an independent company. Mrs. Whitehouse insists her only demand is that broadcasters fulfill their responsibility not to offend against good taste and decency or incite crime. ``It isn't that one's against sex, or showing on TV that men and women love each other, but it's the kind of close-up voyeurism that people are sick and tired of,'' she said. Her speeches draw capacity audiences. And with influential figures such as Mrs. Thatcher speaking out against overly explicit TV, Mrs. Whitehouse has come closer to representing mainstream British values. In 1988, in what was widely seen as a backlash against permissiveness, the government created the Broadcasting Standards Council, an agency to monitor ``sex and violence, taste and decency.'' Mrs. Whitehouse claims to have secured legislation to ban child pornography, control pornography in shop windows and on magazine covers, and classify videotape rentals. In December, her association succeeded in getting the government to introduce legislation to bring broadcasting under the obscenity laws. Mrs. Whitehouse's latest goal is to ensure that satellite TV, recently launched in Britain, does not beam in sexually explict programs from abroad.
DOC.HEAD: PERSONNEL NOTES
Share Named President of Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel
DOC.TEXT: William F. Share was promoted Jan. 4 to president of Journal-Sentinel Inc., publisher of The Milwaukee Journal and Milwaukee Sentinel. Share, who had been senior vice president for marketing, replaces Robert A. Kahlor, who was named vice chairman of the board. Beverly Klein was named senior vice president-marketing; Jack Koller was named vice president-advertising, replacing Klein; and Barry Slavsky was named to a new position of senior vice president-publishing operations. Koller had been advertising sales manager and Slavsky had been marketing manager. Robert M. Dye, who had been communications manager for the newspapers, was named director of corporate commucations for Journal Communications, the parent company of Journal-Sentinel Inc. He replaces Jack E. Knake, who is retiring.
DOC.HEAD: Hume Named Editor and Publisher in Schenectady
DOC.TEXT: John E.N. Hume III has been named editor and publisher of the Daily Gazette. Hume, who has worked at his family's newspaper since 1966, has been editor since 1985. The Gazette has not had a publisher since the 1964 death of John C. Green, who was publisher and president of the parent company. In other changes, Ernest Grandy, assistant general manager, was promoted to general manager and Bruce Donadio was named assistant general manager.
DOC.HEAD: Frock Named Publisher in Miami, Okla.
DOC.TEXT: Rebecca E. Frock, advertising director of the Miami News-Record since November, has been appointed publisher of the newspaper. She replaces Donald L. Coppedge, who resigned. Ms. Frock became an advertising saleswoman in 1983 for The Daily Reporter in Derby, Kan., and was promoted to advertising manager two years later. She was named general manager of the paper in December 1988, then moved to the News-Record two months ago. Coppedge, formerly publisher of the Waxahachie (Texas) Daily Light, had been publisher of the News-Record since 1977. He did not announce his plans.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Met to Buy Restaurant Sites; May Sell Brewing Interests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to ADD announcement of restaurant site acquisitions; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: Precede London
DOC.TEXT: Grand Metropolitan PLC, seeking to turn Burger King into a major international brand, said Monday it plans to buy 20 Wimpy franchised restaurants in the United Kingdom and convert them to Burger King outlets. The British food and liquor conglomerate, which owns the Minneapolis-based Pillsbury Co., also said Monday that it has met with a number of parties over the possible sale of its brewing interests, although it also is considering other options to meet government anti-trust recommendations. In announcing the Wimpy restaurants' purchase from Allied Leisure PLC, London, Grand Met said the sale was scheduled for completion Jan. 29. It did not disclose terms of the deal. ``These 20 prime locations in London and the south coast of England will significantly strengthen our planned expansion of the Burger King brand in the United Kingdom,'' said Ian A. Martin, chief executive of Grand Metropolitan's U.S. operations and chairman of the Burger King subsidiary. ``Following our acquisition of U.B. restaurants in October 1989, which included more than 800 restaurants in the United Kingdom and Europe, this is the latest step in our strategy to build Burger King as a major international brand,'' Martin said. In the past three months, Burger King has doubled the number of its outlets in the United Kingdom and now operates 60 restaurants there. These include 23 former Wimpy counter service outlets which were purchased as part of the U.B. Restaurants acquisition. Burger King anticipates having over 200 owned or franchised outlets in the United Kingdom by the end of 1990. Burger King operates approximately 6,000 restaurants worldwide, including more than 5,400 in the United States. Regarding its brewing interests, Grand Met, which has 5,000 public houses, said it was trying to determine how to meet recommendations of last year's Monopolies and Mergers Commission report, which said brewers should be allowed to operate only 2,000 public houses, or pubs. ``But selling our brewing interests is only one option, and no decisions have yet been made,'' the company said. Grand Met said it has held discussions with a number of company's which might lead to asset sales, including Courage Ltd., the British brewer owned by Elders IXL of Australia. It is rumored that a potential deal with Courage may involve the company swapping some of its public houses for Grand Met's brewing interests. Grand Met brews a number of brands under license for a range of international companies, including Elders' Fosters lager. Grand Met last year bought Pillsbury, which owned Burger King, in a deal valued at $5.75 billion. In addition to Burger King and Pillsbury, Grand Met's U.S.-based subsidiaries include Haagen-Dazs, Alpo, Carillon, Heublein, Paddington and Pearle.

Futures prices for grains and soybeans were mostly higher at the close Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade. ``There was a pretty good rally in soy oil that gave soybeans a good boost,'' said Joel Karlin, analyst with Research Department Inc. ``India bought into the palm oil market. African countries have shown some interest in vegetable oils, too.'' Corn was supported by a rumor that the Soviet Union might be interested in as much as 1 million tons, he said. Export news sent wheat prices higher, said Susan Leighty, grains analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The U.S. Agriculture Department confirmed rumors that China had bid for 300,000 tons of the U.S. commodity, and rumors persisted that the Chinese would bid for 300,000 tons more. The Soviet Union was also said to be in the market for 500,000 tons of export bonus wheat, she said. Also firming wheat prices were weather reports calling for mild conditions in the next few days that might make the winter crop more vulnerable to a cold snap later, Mrs. Leighty said. DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses To Revive Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores two dropped grafs at bottom
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to revive a lawsuit by Chattanooga, Tenn., public utility officials against companies that made electrical equipment containing hazardous chemical PCBs. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the Electric Power Board of Chattanooga waited too long to sue. The 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals threw out the suit last July. The appeals court said most of the equipment was purchased 10 or more years before the suit was filed. Tennessee law requires such suits be filed within four years of the discovery of the alleged injury, the appeals court said. The power board sued for more than $10 million, the estimated cost of replacing transformers and other equipment containing PCBs. Utility officials said the equipment manufacturers lied about or concealed the toxic effects of the chemical compounds. But the 6th Circuit court said power board officials were aware of the dangers of PCBs at least as early as 1976. They did not sue, however, until after federal environmental officials adopted new PCB regulations in 1985. The utility officials had opposed the regulations because of the likely cost of complying, the appeals court said. ``When the regulation they had feared was passed in 1985, only then did they become outwardly concerned about the hazards of their uses of PCB equipment,'' the appeals court said. The appeals court also rejected arguments intended to let the power board use a federal environmental law as the basis for the suit. The appeals court said deadlines for suing under the federal law were almost identical to Tennessee law. The companies sued by the power board were Monsanto, General Electric, McGraw-Edison, Central Moloney Inc., Wagner Electric, Westinghouse Electric and Sangamo Electric. The case is Electric Power Board vs. Monsanto, 89-694.

DOC.HEAD: Paramount Ordered to Pay Buchwald for Story Idea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with detail on how much Buchwald seeking, box office take, add background. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `The Chaplin...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Paramount Pictures Corp. must pay Art Buchwald for the script idea the humor columnist claimed was the basis for the hit Eddie Murphy movie ``Coming to America,'' a judge tentatively ruled today. ``The court concludes that `Coming to America' was based upon a material element of or was inspired by Buchwald's treatment,'' Judge Harvey A. Schneider wrote in a 34-page statement released this morning. The decision becomes official in 10 days unless attorneys on either side raise issues not covered by it. After that, the ruling could be appealed. In his ruling, Schneider did not specify how much Buchwald should be paid but did say that the amount will not include punitive damages. The Los Angeles County Superior Court judge also took pains to specify that Murphy contributed considerably to the finished film. The judge ordered a new phase of the breach-of-contract trial to determine how much money Paramount owes Buchwald. ``We don't agree with the judge's decision,'' Paramount said in a statement. The company said there would be an appeal. Murphy was at work on a movie on location in Modesto and could not be reached for comment. Buchwald expressed joy at the ruling, but quipped that he wouldn't write any more movie ideas for the next 10 years. ``I am very, very happy. This thing is not only an important thing for me. I think it's really important for writers,'' he told the Associated Press in a telephone interview from Washington. ``I didn't know what I was getting into when I started because those guys play rough, and we beat them. And that makes me very happy,'' Buchwald said. Pierce O'Donnell, Buchwald's attorney, said Buchwald and his partner, producer Alain Bernheim, could stand to collect $5 million to $10 million in their share of the film's profits. Paramount maintains the film, which has grossed in excess of $300 million since its 1988 release, has yet to show a profit. In his opinion, Schneider ruled that the humorist did not base his idea, entitled ``King for a Day,'' on a 1957 Charlie Chaplin movie entitled ``A King in New York.'' The Chaplin film, which defense lawyers compared to Buchwald's story, is about an aging European king's adventures in the city after he flees his country, while ``Coming to America'' and Buchwald's story concern the Stateside adventures of a African prince or king. ``The court concludes that `Coming to America' is a movie that was based upon Buchwald's treatment `King for a Day,''' Schneider said. However, he carefully specified in the ruling that he was not denigrating Eddie Murphy's creative talent and stressed the term ``based upon,'' since Buchwald did not write a complete script. He also said Murphy was not to blame for the dispute with Buchwald. ``It is Paramount and not Murphy that obligated itself to compensate Buchwald if any material elements of Buchwald's treatment was utilized in or inspired a film produced by Paramount,'' the decision stated. ```Coming to America' is no less the product of Eddie Murphy's creativity because of the court's decision than it was before this decision was rendered,'' he said. In his decision, Schneider rejected the argument that Paramount was guilty of bad faith and fraud and turned down a request by Buchwald's attorney for separate punitive damages based on such action. ``The court is unable to conclude that Paramount's conduct was in bad faith, let alone fraudulent, oppressive or malicious,'' Schneider wrote. In addition, he rejected the suggestion that Murphy ``stole'' Buchwald's idea, saying that the case did not revolve on such a claim. ``The court desires to indicate what this case is and is not about,'' the judge said. ``It is not about whether Art Buchwald or Eddie Murphy is more creative. It is clear to the court that each of these men is a creative genius in his own field and each is a uniquely American institution. ``This case is also not about whether Eddie Murphy made substantial contributions to the film `Coming to America,''' he added. ``The court is convinced he did.'' The judge said he also concluded that the case was not about whether Murphy stole Buchwald's concept ``King for a Day.'' ``Rather, this case is primarily a breach-of-contract case between Buchwald and Paramount (not Murphy), which must be decided by reference to the agreement between the parties and the rules of contract construction.'' Schneider noted that there was no question in his mind that Murphy knew about Buchwald's idea and that he discussed it on at least three occasions with at least one Paramount executive. He found that the Buchwald idea and the Murphy box office blockbuster ``Coming to America'' were substantially similar and Paramount remains liable for provisions of the contract, which promised Buchwald compensation if his idea became a movie.

DOC.HEAD: USAir Ups Prices to Reflect Bigger Fuel Bill
DOC.TEXT: USAir Group Inc. announced Monday it will follow the trend of other major carrier and increase fares by 4 percent to cover higher fuel prices. The nation's seventh-largest airline said the higher prices will be in effect for coach and supercoach fares with tickets purchased on or after Jan. 11. Excursion fares will go up on Feb. 1, the Arlington, Va.-based carrier said. The company said jet fuel prices, which have increased 40 percent in the last six weeks, were responsible for its decision. Each one penny per gallon fuel price hike translates into an additional $13 million in operating costs for the airline, the announcement said. Other airlines announced higher fares last week.

DOC.HEAD: New Company to Process and Sell Recycled Paper Fiber for New Products
DOC.TEXT: Jefferson Smurfit Corp., the leading recycler of waste paper, and Waste Management of North America Inc. on Monday announced a joint venture to process and market recycled paper fiber. ``A major obstacle to the successful recovery of paper fiber from the nation's waste stream has been our inability to find stable markets and consistent demand for this valuable material,'' said William P. Hulligan, president of Waste Management of North America, the largest provider of recycling collection services in the United States and Canada. Hulligan said that Waste Management's collection systems, facilities and technologies should result in greater efficiency and a constant source of raw material for customers. The companies have signed a letter of intent to form Smurfit-WMI Recycling Co., based in St. Louis. Under the agreement, Jefferson Smurfit's Reclamation Division would become an independent business owned equally by Jefferson Smurfit and Waste Management of North America, a subsidiary of Waste Management Inc. of Oak Brook, Ill. The company will sell reclaimed paper fiber to Jefferson Smurfit and its affiliates, as well as other paper and paperboard mills for use in new paper products. St. Louis-based Jefferson Smurfit is one of the largest paper and paperboard packaging companies in the United States. Its Reclamation Division has 32 processing plants and markets more than 3.7 million tons a year of corrugated containers, old newsprint and other products. Waste Management of North America provides residential collection of recyclables from more than 1.2 million homes through contracts with 142 municipalities. The company's Recycle America and Recycle Canada residential and commercial programs collect more than 750,000 tons of recyclable materials a year through more than 315 divisions in North American. It operates 35 processing plants across the country. In addition to paper, the company recovers aluminum, glass and plastics. The new company will continue to operate Jefferson Smurfit recycling centers and market other recycled commodities. Waste Management will provide corrugated, newsprint and other papers recovered through its collection programs.

DOC.HEAD: Czechs To Get Visa Cards
DOC.TEXT: Visa International said Monday it will begin offering Visa cards in Czechoslovakia next year, making it the first Eastern European country to let its citizens use an international payment card. The Visa cards will be offered by Zivnostenska Banka, the country's oldest retail bank. The bank initially intends to offer cards to customers with foreign currency incomes. Czechoslovakia's currency isn't convertible into western currencies. ``This not only marks a significant breakthrough to a new Eastern European market, it is a graphic illustration of the payment card as an international currency,'' Jean-Jacques Desbons, executive vice president of Visa International, said in a statement. Czechoslovakia would follow the Soviet Union and China in accepting an international payment card. The cards in Czechoslovakia will be debit cards, with purchase amounts billed immediately against the customer's own accounts, Visa International spokesman David Brancoli said. Czech customers will be able to use the card at any of the 7.5 million Visa merchant locations worldwide, he said. Since 1988, Visa has issued a few thousand debit cards in the Soviet Union to foreign residents and Soviets who travel abroad. Those cards can be used worldwide. Sberbank, the largest Soviet bank, also offers a Visa debit card for domestic use. Last month, Visa announced an agreement with authorities of the Soviet republic of Estonia to introduce a card there. Visa, MasterCard and American Express also have been allowed to offer cards in China since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers in Landmark Cigarette Case Sort Out Appeals Decision
DOC.TEXT: A mixed ruling from a federal appeals court over a landmark smoker-death case drew a two-part chorus of victory Monday from tobacco companies and a man who claims cigarettes killed his wife. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Friday overturned the nation's first money damages judgment against the tobacco industry, removing the only blemish from their nearly 40 years of victory in such cases. But the panel also sent back for trial a reshaped case that will likely put smoking itself in the dock; reinstated claims against two other tobacco companies; and perhaps deepened the well for potential damages. Despite the outcome, the decision adds perhaps years more of legal wrangling in a 7-year-old case. ``For this case, it's the lawyers' unemployment act,'' said Donald J. Cohn, an attorney for cigarette-maker Liggett Group Inc. As lawyers on both sides study the opinion, they are preparing for discussions with federal trial judge H. Lee Sarokin on the next step. ``Quite frankly, I think the opinion is terrific for the litigation generally,'' said Marc Z. Edell, the lead lawyer suing Philip Morris Inc., Lorillard Inc. and Liggett. The companies made cigarettes smoked by lung-cancer victim Rose Cipollone, whose husband, Antonio, carried on the case that blames the companies for his wife's death at 58 in 1984. ``It's unfortunate that we had to sacrifice the verdict to get that kind of opinion. But for the big picture, it's extremely helpful,'' said Edell. After a four-month trial, the jury in June 1988 awarded Cipollone $400,000. Philip Morris and Lorillard, owned by Loews Corp., were absolved, but Liggett was found liable for violating advertising promises to Mrs. Cipollone. A number of issues did not reach the jury because of rulings by Sarokin. Several of those rulings damaging to the cigarette companies were reversed by the appeals court. The panel found that Edell should have been allowed to argue the ``risk-utility'' theory _ which holds that if a product's danger outweighs its usefulness, the manufacturer can be held liable. When that argument is introduced at retrial, ``This will be the first time that a jury will actually make a determination as to whether or not cigarette smoking is something our society thinks should be around,'' said Edell. Philip Morris and Lorillard will also have to face this claim, broadening the potential for damages. Edell said he would introduce evidence about the generally harmful effects on society, such as statistics on mortality, disease and the financial cost to businesses. Two factors, though, may prevent the Cipollone case from breaking ground in risk-utility. On Dec. 28, a Mississippi judge ruled in favor of such an argument. The case is expected to go to trial in April. And the New Jersey Supreme Court is also considering the issue on an appeal in a state case brought by Edell. If he loses, risk-utility would be out of the case, but the federal ruling would still help plaintiffs in other states. Cohn said the risk-utility decision is not a boon to plaintiffs because the circuit court said a jury must also be convinced that the ``ordinary consumer'' wasn't aware of the dangers of smoking. Cohn said the opinion puts cigarette plaintiffs back at square one, and that it will only help evaporate similar lawsuits, which have dropped to below 60 from 150 in 1987. Litigation analyst Calvert Crary, of Labe, Simpson & Co., downplayed actual numbers of cases. Anti-tobacco lawyers have adopted the strategy of, ``You take 200 cases, throw' em up against the wall and see which ones stick,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Ready To Welcome 300,000 Tourists Annually, Official Says
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Iran is ready to accommodate 300,000 tourists and earn more than $210 million a year under the first stage of a tourism plan, a government official said Monday. Mahdi Hashemi, director of the tourism department of the Mostazafan Foundation, said in Tehran the number of tourists could be doubled later, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. IRNA, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Hashemi as saying the first batch of foreign tourists will arrive from Italy early in the spring. Negotiations are under way for other arrivals from Moslem and third world countries, he said. A separate report by Tehran Radio, also monitored in Nicosia, said plans have been completed for the exchange of tourists between Iran and the Soviet Union. The Mostazafan, or deprived, Foundation is a government welfare agency that operates its own tourist agency and other businesses to generate income for the poor. Hashemi said the foundation's tourism subsidiary operates 32 hotels in Tehran and other cities that meet international standards. After a decade of self-imposed isolation, Iran recently launched a drive to revive its once flourishing tourist industry to promote a better image to the world and to earn badly needed foreign currency. Iran catered for about 1 million tourists a year before the Islamic revolution of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini overthrew the pro-Western government of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Big Banks Drop Prime to 10 Percent; Lowest Level Since Fall 1988
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, Many economist ..., with two grafs to show how financial markets closed. Picks up 10th graf pvs, William V. ...
DOC.TEXT: The nation's leading commercial banks on Monday dropped their prime lending rates a half percentage point to 10 percent, marking the first reduction in nearly half a year and paving the way for many cheaper business and consumer loans. The move reflects the overall falling cost of money that banks have enjoyed in recent weeks due to more liberal credit policies by the Federal Reserve. The central bank moved to ease interest rates late in 1989 to help forestall a dramatic economic downturn. Lower rates spur growth by encouraging businesses and consumers to borrow money. The prime used as a benchmark for bank interest rates on a wide range of borrowing by consumers and small- and medium-size companies. The groups likely to benefit most from a reduction are individuals who borrow against the equity in their homes and, to a lesser extent, those with car loans linked to the prime. ``To Joe and Joan Average Consumer who have some of their loans tied to short-term rates this is good news,'' said F. Ward McCarthy, an economist at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. ``... Monthly payments should go down by next month.'' Fixed-rate mortgages aren't expected to be affected by Monday's prime cut, because those rates are pegged to activities in the bond markets. But rates have been declining for the past several months, with average rates on a 30-year conventional mortgage remaining below 10 percent since late October. First National Bank of Chicago and Citibank were the first major banks to cut the prime on Monday. The move was followed throughout the day by other large banks and many smaller institutions. It was the first time the rate has been changed since July 31, when banks lowered the prime to 10.5 percent from 11 percent. The last time the prime stood at 10 percent was in November 1988, before it was raised to 10.5 percent at the start of a year-long, upward trend. Many economists said Monday's reduction was long overdue, given how the Fed had begun moving in early November to push interest rates lower. Stock prices closed higher, while bonds and the dollar declined following Monday's announcement. William V. Sullivan, an economist with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said banks had the incentive to trim their prime just after Christmas when the Fed moved to lower the federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, to 8.25 percent. However, Sullivan said, banks put off any cut in the prime because seasonal demands for higher cash reserves temporarily had pushed the fed funds rate above 9 percent. The central bank can exert strong influences over fed funds by adding or draining reserves from the banking system through the sale and purchase of government securities. Many economists said the Fed would have to be more persuasive in its push for easier credit before any future prime-rate cuts occur. Banks have been under pressure recently to maintain higher cash reserves in the face of problem real estate loans and loans to Third World countries _ which also may have helped delay the latest rate reduction. The so-called yield spread, which is the difference between banks' own borrowing costs and the price they charge for lending money, ``is not outlandish'' based on current economic conditions, said McCarthy. After Monday's prime cut the spread fell to between 1.75 and 1.80 percentage points from 2.25 to 2.30 percentage points, based on current fed fund rates and rates on three-month certificates of deposit _ two key examples of banks' borrowing costs. McCarthy said that when the economy is sluggish it's not unusual to see the yield spread at around 2 percentage points. When the economy is expanding, banks can afford to keep their rates lower because loan volume usually is brisk, McCarthy said. But as economic conditions weaken so does loan demand, and banks make up for lower volume by keeping rates higher.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Tumbles, Gold Declines After Mixed Overseas Trading
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply against key foreign currencies in active trading Monday, skidding to a 20-month low against the strong West German mark amid continued concerns about declining U.S. interest rates. Gold prices also slipped after a mixed performance overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $403 a troy ounce, down $3.30 from Friday. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $401.80 an ounce, off $4.45. Currency dealers said a cut in U.S. commercial banks' prime lending rate Monday, to 10 percent from 10.5 percent, helped depress the dollar in foreign exchange. The prime-rate cut reflects more liberal credit policies by the Federal Reserve since late 1989 and lowers borrowing costs for a number of businesses and consumers. Lower interest rates are seen as bearish for the dollar since they make dollar-denominated investments less attractive to foreigners. At the same time, interest rates have been holding steady overseas, particularly in West Germany, where the crumbling of the Berlin Wall promises to spur economic growth, dealers noted. Stong interest in the mark pushed the dollar to its lowest level against that currency since late April 1988, according to Ronald H. Holzer, a vice president at Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago. The dollar fell to 1.6685 marks from 1.6895 marks late Friday. ``Continued purchases of marks favors a lower dollar scenario,'' Holzer said. ``German rates remain firm ... (while) the Fed policy is stable to easy credit.'' Enthusiasm for the mark also was renewed by Friday's 3.68 percent devaluation of the Italian lire against the other currencies in the nine-member European Monetary System, dealers said. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar closed at 144.52 Japanese yen, up from 144.15. It traded at 144.10 yen in London, and at 144.15 yen in New York, down from 144.50. The dollar also was weaker against the British pound. Sterling rose to $1.6530 in London from late Friday's $1.6375, and to $1.6535 in New York, up from $1.6350. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.5245 Swiss francs, down from 1.5445; 5.6965 French francs, down from 5.7777; 1,250.00 Italian lire, down from 1,276.25; and 1.16035 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16075. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Friday's rates: 1.6685 West German marks, down from 1.6810; 1.5235 Swiss francs, down from 1.5365; 5.6920 French francs, down from 5.7405; 1.8880 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9030; 1,249.00 Italian lire, down from 1,263.00; and 1.1599 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1595. Gold rose in London but fell in Zurich on profit-taking. The late gold bid in London was $404.75 an ounce, up from $404.50 Friday. The late Zurich bid was $404.05 an ounce, down from $405.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $403.05 an ounce, up from $401.85 Friday. Silver prices also were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery closed at $5.244 a troy ounce, down from $5.318 Friday. Silver rose in London to $5.28 an ounce from $5.27.

DOC.HEAD: Icahn Considering Proxy Fight at USX
DOC.TEXT: Carl Icahn, who waged a proxy fight two years ago seeking control of Texaco Corp., is considering a similar battle for USX Corp., a Wall Street source said Monday. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, was expected to decide within a few weeks whether to pursue a proxy fight in hopes of replacing the directors of the steel, oil and gas giant, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. A USX spokesman, William Keslar, said the company had no comment on any potential moves by Icahn. Icahn, who also is chairman of Trans World Airlines, long has been dissatisfied with USX management and believes the company's stock price is too low. The source said Icahn believes USX's position is similar to that of Texaco in 1988, when the takeover strategist failed to unseat that company's board in an attempt to force a restructuring that would boost Texaco's stock price. Icahn, who has argued in favor of USX selling its Marathon Oil & Gas subsidiary, wants shareholders _ not management _ to decide whether the division should be kept or sold, the source said. If he won a proxy fight _ essentially enlisting the support of enough shares to win an election over his proposals _ Icahn could replace the USX board with directors more sympathetic to his stand on Marathon. The proceeds from a Marathon sale conceivably would be distributed among shareholders or used to pay down USX's debt. Either move would enhance the price of the company's stock. USX stock rose 62{ cents to $36.75 a share Monday on the New York Stock Exchange. USX already has decided to sell its Texas Oil & Gas Co. subsidiary. USX Chairman Charles Corry said recently the company would pare down its debt by about $1 billion debt with the proceeds. However, the company so far has been unwilling to sell Marathon. Icahn won federal permission last month to acquire at least 25 percent of USX's stock. He currently owns nearly 34 million, or 13.26 percent, of USX's outstanding common shares. Icahn also reportedly has been considering a bid for the company. He offered to buy USX for $7.2 billion in early 1987, but abandoned the proposal after it was rejected by the USX board. A proxy fight at USX would mirror to some extent Icahn's fight with Texaco. When Icahn became Texaco's biggest shareholder in late 1987, he immediately began fighting with management, charging it was not doing enough to raise the company's stock price. He proposed a takeover of Texaco valued at $14.5 billion and then tried and failed to unseat the company's board in a proxy fight. Icahn said that if he won control of Texaco, the company's assets would be sold and the proceeds distributed to Texaco shareholders. In early 1989, after Texaco undertook a major restructuring that included the sale of billions of dollars in assets and payment of a special dividend to stockholders, Icahn reached a standstill agreement with the company. Several months later, he sold his stake for $2.07 billion, and has since returned his attention to USX. Gregory Drahuschak, a steel industry analyst with Butcher & Singer in Pittsburgh, predicted that USX ultimately would sell Marathon, but ``management wants to determine when it's going to be done.'' Icahn would find some support among USX shareholders who have waited for the company's stock price to go up, ``but it will not go down without a heck of a battle,'' said Drahuschak. George Zimmermann, director of research at Gruntal & Co., said of Icahn, ``he has about a 50-50 chance'' of winning a proxy fight because of a growing trend toward shareholder rights among U.S. corporations. Zimmerman said a sale of Marathon might help boost the price of USX's stock, but he doubted it could go much higher than its current level. He said USX's profits _ which were up more than 20 percent through the first three quarters of 1989 _ were not expected to coninue at that level in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Questions Surround 28-Year-Old With Eye on Bond Corp.
LaserPhoto pursuing
DOC.TEXT: Jeff H. Reynolds, who is seeking control of financially struggling Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. in return for a $197 million investment, has a business address that is a mail-drop. His U.S. company, Weatherby Investments Inc., does not appear to be traded publicly as he contends, officials said Monday. The 28-year-old Texan, little known on the investment scene, said in a news release last week that he was negotiating with Bond Holdings, the Australian holding company. The release listed an answering service as a contact number. The answering service forwarded calls about the offer to Reynolds mother's house in Houston, where he discussed his business and personal history in a telephone call Monday morning. Messages left in later follow-up calls to a brother and an answering machine at the house were not returned. Among the unanswered questions are: _Why his news release said his Weatherby Investments Inc. is an over-the-counter stock and why he said it was traded over-the-counter on the ``pink sheet'' distributed by the National Quotation Bureau. The National Quotation Bureau and the National Association of Securities Dealers have no record of Weatherby, and it is not listed in guides to over-the-counter stocks. Reynolds said Monday Weatherby had earlier been known as California Pacific Industries, and he intended to change the name back. But there was no listing under that name either. _Why the address and suite to which investors are invited to send questions is a private mail-drop box in Beverly Hills, a year-and-a-half after Reynolds says he moved his operations from Texas to California. In the conversation early Monday, Reynolds said his work was done from several offices, including an unspecified location in Century City, but he gave no address and said he is still looking for a central location. Reynolds describes himself as an intensely private businessman, who used to walk in his bankers' side doors because he favored jeans and cutoffs. He says he still feels more comfortable in a sweatsuit, crunching numbers at a computer terminal, than in a suit and tie. ``I've always had a real hardcore attitude about other businesses and banks _ if they're going to deal with me they're going to have to know me and put up with me,'' he said. ``I'm not going to fit into their world.'' Bond, the holding company whose Australian brewing interests are in the hand of receivers, says it will listen to offers from Reynolds, who says Weatherby is a division of Singapore-based California Pacific International Pte Ltd. Reynolds says he is descended from a long line of oilmen in Throckmorton, Texas, and locals there say books have been written about the Reynolds clan and its intermarriages with the even more famous Matthews cattle and oil family. Reynolds said he took freshman English and biology classes at the University of Texas and a few business classes at various colleges before succumbing to entrepreneurial urges. He got started in business by importing ``gray market'' cars, upgrading them to meet American standards and selling them at a profit, he said. ``Actually I was living in Austin and a few of my frat brothers got in with me,'' Reynolds said. ``We had some cash flow and it looked pretty good and I said, `The hell with this' (college career).'' As it stands now, he says he's confident he can find refinancing for Bond's $6 billion debt. Bond says it wants to see more details, and skeptics in the international investment community say they have never heard of Reynolds or his operations. Reynolds says he got a real-estate broker's license in Texas in 1983 and got involved in development companies. He also says he has dabbled in a clay-tile factory in France.

DOC.HEAD: Limit Up for Frozen Pork Bellies, OJ
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices for both frozen pork bellies and orange juice were up the limit on Monday _ a rerun of last week's trading on both markets. In other futures trading, grains were mostly higher, but precious metals and energy products were lower. Prices for frozen pork bellies for four contracts to be delivered by midsummer were all up the 2-cent limit on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange for the third straight day. ``It's a 600 point rally. The market reaction is following through from the USDA's hog and pig inventory report of last week and from better demand for the product,'' said Paul Hare of Linnco Futures Inc. Another livestock analyst in Chicago, Dale Benson of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc, said the rally also has been buoyed by higher prices on the cash market. ``We're talking 55 to 57 cents on the cash market. That's up about 12 cents in five days,'' he said. Futures prices for live hogs followed pork bellies higher, analysts agreed. Cattle prices were mostly lower as traders said they were worried about expectations for reduced demands for beef. Cattle settled .20 cent lower to .25 cent higher, with the contract for February at 76.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent lower to .10 cent higher, with January at 84.67 cents a pound; live hogs were .25 cent to .65 cent higher, with February at 51.62 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were 1.45 cents to 2.00 cents higher, with February at 55.47. Heightened concerns over Florida's frost in December sent frozen orange juice futures up the limit again this morning as the New York Cotton Exchange imposed a brief trading suspension to sort orders and adjust daily trading limits. ``We feel the situation is much more critical than anybody has seen before. We think there might be damage beyond the damage to the foilage _ that there may be some limb or wood damage that could affect next year's crop,'' said Celeste Georgakis, a New York analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. ``There's a lot of anxiety on the part of traders because of the possibility of the damage to next year's crop,'' she said. ``We should know more when the USDA report comes out Thursday.'' Frozen orange juice settled 5 cents to 13.25 cents higher with the contract for delivery in January at $1.93 a pound. Export news helped grain and soybean prices to rise on the Chicago Board of Trade. ``There was a pretty good rally in soyoil that gave soybeans a good boost,'' said Joel Karlin, analyst with Research Department Inc. ``India bought into the palm oil market. African countries have shown some interest in vegetable oils, too.'' Corn was supported by a rumor that the Soviet Union might be interested in as much as 1 million metric tons of the commodity, he said. The U.S. Agriculture Department confirmed rumors that China had bid for 300,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat, and rumors persisted that the Chinese would bid for 300,000 metric tons more, said Susan Leighty, grains analyst in New York with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Wheat settled unchanged to 1\ cents higher to with the contract for March at $4.10 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1{ cent higher, with March at $2.39 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1} cents lower, with March at $1.50}, and soybeans were 1{ cents to 6{ cents higher, with January at $5.70} a bushel. Oil prices plummeted on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Easing of cold weather concerns weighed on heating oil prices while reports of higher OPEC output sent crude futures downward, according to analysts. Crude oil settled 35 cents to $1.46 lower, with the contract for delivery in February at $21.62 a barrel; heating oil was 1.18 cents to 3.50 cents lower, with February at 64.33 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was 2.9 cents to 3.74 cents lower, with February at 58.48 cents a gallon. Lower interest rates and easing of concerns over world trouble spots sent precious metals prices tumbling on the Commodity Exchange in New York, traders said. Several major banks on Monday lowered their prime lending rate from 10.5 percent to 10 percent. Gold settled $3.30 to $3.70 lower, with the contract for delivery in January at $403 a troy ounce; and silver was 7.4 to 7.5 cents lower, with January at $5.24 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices in Steep Slide
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures tumbled Monday, led by a steep slide in prices of wholesale home heating oil and unleaded gasoline. The sell-off on the New York Mercantile Exchange reflected profit-taking, anticipation of lower demand due to milder weather, expectations of a buildup in crude oil stocks and internal market forces, energy market analysts said. Refined petroleum prices experienced the biggest price drops. Heating oil for February delivery plummeted 3.50 cents to 64.33 cents a gallon, adding to the accumulated loss of 10.37 cents suffered in the two previous trading sessions. March heating oil fell 2.83 cents to 59.40 cents a gallon and later delivery months posted more moderate declines. The contract for February delivery of unleaded gasoline plunged 3.74 cents to 58.48 cents a gallon after falling 3.07 cents on Friday. Since last Thursday the contract has lost 8.75 cents. Contracts for delivery during March through May each closed down 3 cents a gallon. The February contract of West Texas Intermediate, the leading grade of U.S. crude oil, fell $1.46 to $21.62 per 42-gallon barrel after losing 33 cents on Friday. Other delivery months also went down. Jim Fiedler, a vice president at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said part of the selling was a sort of reflex action after the sharp runup in prices over recent weeks. ``It probably was overbought and now it probably will be oversold,'' he said. Traders sold to collect profits amassed during the prolonged rally in the energy futures pits, he said. With higher temperatures forecast there also is speculation that demand might not be as great as previously believed. Another incentive to sell came from estimates that industry figures due Tuesday will show a large rise in crude oil inventories. Fiedler said problems that forced refineries to temporarily halt operations in the past week or so caused crude stocks to rise. The American Petroleum Institute will issue its weekly report on production and stocks after the market closes on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Coniston Deadline Arrives On UAL Corp. Buyout Plan
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. shares fell Monday after a deadline set by a major shareholder for the company to come up with a new employee buyout plan arrived without any apparent progress. The stock fell $2.87{ a share to $156.62{ on the New York Stock Exchange. The investor group Coniston Partners said last month that it would press for a recapitalization of UAL unless the United Airlines parent presented a buyout plan, preferably one involving employee stock ownership, by Monday. No proposals were disclosed by late in the day. Coniston leaders and spokesmen for the UAL pilots and machinists unions did not return telephone calls. UAL spokesman Rob Doughty said he couldn't comment on the buyout issue. A spokeswomen for United's flight attendants union said she had no information indicating that any efforts were underway to come up with a plan. ``We know of nothing going on right now with any buyout plan _ we know of no meetings and no dates for meetings,'' said Bobbie Pilkington, spokeswoman for United's chapter of the Association of Flight Attendants. She added that she believed the situation was quiet because ``no one is taking it (the deadline) very seriously.'' UAL last week said it was accelerating its schedule for talks with non-union employees over a possible buyout plan, although the company's schedule indicated it was likely to miss Coniston's deadline. Those talks are to begin Wednesday. UAL management already has met with leaders of United's pilot and flight attendant unions over possible employee buyout of the company. Coniston, which owns 11.8 percent of UAL's stock, said Dec. 20 that it was dissatisfied with progress being made toward sale or restructuring of the company that would boost its stock price. It said that if Coniston and the UAL board couldn't agree on a recapitalization plan, Coniston might proceed with a plan to solicit shareholder consent to oust 13 of UAL's 15 directors and take majority control of the board. A pilot-management plan to buy the company for $6.75 billion, or $300 a share, failed last fall when banks refused to finance it. After that, the board reportedly was seeking employee support for a proposal that would value the company at $240 a share, or $5.443 billion. Samuel Buttrick, who follows UAL for Kidder Peabody & Co. in Washington, D.C., said he viewed Coniston's buyout plan deadline mainly as an attempt to get UAL to move more quickly. ``I've regarded it all along as a soft deadline,'' said Buttrick. ``Clearly if any progress is being made, it is at a very slow pace. ...It's a very difficult deal to bring together.''

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached To Liquidate Boesky Partnership, Distribute Assets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5 grafs for grafs 9-11 pvs bgng, `Other details... to UPDATE with details of settlement; PICKS UP 12th graf pvs, `A Delaware...
DOC.TEXT: Ivan F. Boesky's main arbitrage fund has been liquidated and $248 million distributed to its limited partners to settle one of many claims against the former Wall Street speculator, attorneys said Monday. In addition, some lawsuits against the partnership, CX Partners LP, have been settled and others placed on hold in Manhattan federal court, where more than two dozen class-action lawsuits against Boesky and affiliated entities await resolution. The agreement between CX Partners and its 46 investors was reached after more than three years of discussions and litigation dating to Boesky's November 1986 settlement of insider trading charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission. David R. Herwitz, liquidating trustee for CX Partners, said the agreement was ``a major step in the resolution of disputes stemming from Mr. Boesky's conduct.'' Still pending in the case that rocked Wall Street are completion of an SEC plan to use $50 million paid by Boesky to reimburse individual investors who can prove they were defrauded by his trading. Under the agreement liquidating CX Partners, formerly known as Ivan F. Boesky & Co., most of the limited partners received 100 percent of their investment, Herwitz said. The total equity investment in the fund, which Boesky formed in March 1986 to invest in stocks of potential takeover targets, was $338 million. But Boesky and his wife surrendered all their interests in the enterprise and some partners did not receive full compensation. The limited partnerships included insurance companies, financial institutions and individual investors. Some future disbursements to the partnerships are possible, Herwitz said. Other details of the agreement were not made public, but sources familiar with the case said the Boeskys' interest in the fund totaled around $10 million. Guinness PLC, the largest holder in the fund with a $100 million stake, received just $37 million of its claim, said George Reycraft, a lawyer for the limited partners. Other large stakes in the fund reportedly included $28 million by Jeffrey M. Picower of New York, its largest investor; $10 million by Lincoln National Life Insurance Co.; $10 million by Britain's Water Authorities Superannuation Fund; and $6 million by New York investor Milton Dresner. Monday's settlement included an agreement with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. resolving a series of issues surrounding the limited partners' investments. Drexel had an $8 million equity stake in the Boesky fund and owned $20 million of its debt. Reycraft said Drexel received the full $20 million for the debt but no interest or any of its equity investment. Under the agreement, Drexel will be dropped as a defendant in the Boesky-related lawsuits, he said. But Reycraft said the limited partners planned to proceed with litigation against Boesky and others, including former Drexel financier Michael Milken and admitted securities felons Dennis Levine and Martin Siegel. A Delaware court last year ruled that Drexel was entitled to get its money back before or at the same time as the partners. Drexel spokesman Steven Andreder declined to comment on the agreement, saying it was confidential. Boesky, 52, is due to be released in April from a Brooklyn halfway house where he is completing a three-year prison term. Boesky pleaded guilty to one count of violating federal securities laws and paid $100 million to settle charges he led a network of illegal trading using inside information. The government is using $50 million of the money to compensate investors who can prove they were victimized by Boesky's trading. SEC officials had set Jan. 15 target date to establish a plan to distibute the money. ``We are working toward achieving a plan for distribution of the money but that may or may not have anything to do with an investors' settlement,'' said John H. Sturc, an SEC associate enforcement director. Monday's settlements could help speed resolution of a mountain of lawsuits, including class-action shareholder cases and other litigation, attorneys said. Some of the charges involving CX Partners either have been settled or placed on hold, according to lawyers involved in the case. The lawsuits are consolidated before U.S. District Judge Milton Pollack. ``Some of these lawsuits will be reduced, abated or limited,'' Herwitz said. ``Part of what is happening is people are going to try to save a dollar or two on litgation costs.'' Boesky and the entities he once controlled were inundated with lawsuits after federal authorities disclosed his alleged insider trading activities. Most of the lawsuits are by shareholders who were selling stock at the time Boesky and his associates were buying.

DOC.HEAD: Opening Neighbor's Mail Leads to Insider Trading Charges
DOC.TEXT: A Connecticut man who allegedly traded on inside information obtained when one of his tenants opened someone else's mail agreed to pay almost $20,000 in fines and penalties, federal officials said Monday. The misappropriated information concerned a 1988 tender offer for Stanadyne Inc. by Emhart Corp., the Securities and Exchange Commission said. The SEC accused Thaddeus Pencikowski, 37, of Farmington, Conn., of making $9,093 in alleged illegal profits after buying 750 shares of Stanadyne common stock Jan. 8, 1988 with confidential information allegedly supplied to him by Bruce J. Warren, also 37, of Plainville, Conn. Both men settled the civil charges without admitting or denying wrongdoing. Harry J. Weiss, an attorney with the SEC's Enforcement Division, said no financial penalty was sought against Warren because he did not trade for himself. According to the SEC, Warren agreed to receive a Stanadyne director's mail while the director was away. Warren's computer graphics company and the director's office were in the same building, which was owned and managed by Pencikowski. The SEC accused Warren of violating a ``duty of trust and confidence'' to the Stanadyne director when he revealed the contents of a letter to Pencikowski concerning the Emhart offer. ``The complaint alleged Mr. Warren misappropriated information from the director and then tipped Mr. Pencikowski,'' Weiss said. Pencikowski allegedly bought 750 Stanadyne shares at $26.50 per share on Jan. 8 and sold them for $39 a share on Jan. 11, 1988 _ the day the Emhart offer was made public. According to the SEC, Pencikowski agreed to disgorge $10,847 in alleged illegal profits plus interest as well as a penalty equal to his alleged profits of $9,093. Pencikowski's lawyer, Vincent Dowling, was not in his office when called for comment. Warren's lwyer, Steven Sach, declined comment until he spoke with his client.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Audio Tape Units Previewed at Electronics Show
DOC.TEXT: Digital audio tape decks, which offer the sound fidelity of compact discs along with the capability to record, could be sold in the United States by the summer, two leading Japanese manufacturers say. Both Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., which produces the Panasonic and Technics brands, and Sony Corp. say they hope to introduce the DAT recorders in the U.S. market sometime this year. Sony was vague on its plans, but Matsushita said at this week's Consumer Electronics Show that it will market a home recorder this summer at a price of about $1,300. The recorders, long-awaited by audio buffs, have been on sale for several years overseas, but their introduction to the U.S. market had been held up by record companies, who feared DAT's ability to make high-quality tape recordings will encourage pirating and cut into their compact disc sales. That issue was for the most part resolved last summer, however, when an agreement was reached on new technology that would allow direct copying onto a digital audio tape, but would not allow unlimited copies to be made of those tapes. Manufacturers say they hope to capture a large segment of the high-end audio market with the recorders despite their steep price tag. In addition, blank DAT cassettes will cost $12 to $18, or more than twice the price of conventional blank cassettes. The recording time of the DAT tapes is similar to that of conventional cassettes. ``I think it has the capability of being a very large market,'' said John Bermingham, president of Sony's U.S. tape division. ``Compact discs and digital audio tape will exist together like LP albums and cassettes did before.'' Bermingham said Sony envisions DAT tapes, which are about half the size of normal cassette tapes, being used in its popular Walkman stereos and in car stereos. A consumer could record onto the tapes in his home tape deck and use them in the other applications, he said. ``You have some problems now with (portable and car) CD's with taking them jogging or on a rough road,'' Bermingham said. ``With DAT, you wouldn't have that problem.'' Both DATs and CDs use digital technology to reproduce music, offering little distortion and high dynamic range. In addition, DAT tapes lack the ``hiss'' that plagues conventional tape, and many audiophiles believe it produces a deeper and more rich sound than compact discs. But sales have been disappointing during the three years DAT equipment has beem on the market in Japan because of high prices and initial opposition from record industry groups. Under the July agreement, which still must be codified by federal legislation, new DAT equipment will be able to make near-perfect direct digital recordings from digital sources such as CDs, but will add a ``flag'' signal to the tape to prevent any second-generation copies from being made from the tape. While Sony and Matsushita were both displaying DAT recorders at the electronics show, General Electric Audio Products announced at the show that it has developed what it calls the first compact disc player that allows recording and re-recording. A spokesman for the company, which is owned by Thomson SA of France, called the system the ``first major advancement in the format since CD technology was introduced,'' but said it will not be available to consumers for at least a year. The new system uses magneto optical discs for recording, but is playback compatible with CDs now on the market. Though GE claimed its recorder was the first, Sony said in October that it also had developed a magneto optical CD recorder, thought it also was not yet ready for market.
